SESSION.HEADER.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY‐EIGHTH PARLIAMENT
The Senate, on 27 June 1997, pursuant to resolution, adjourned to Monday, 25 August 1997 at 12.30 p.m. Pursuant to that resolution the Senate met on Monday, 25 August 1997 at 12.30 p.m.

PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 June, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I adjourned my remarks on 27 June I had already dealt with the provisions in this bill which relate to extending the capital gains tax rollover relief to retirement, prospectors' mining rights, a proposed fringe benefits tax incentive for remote area housing for primary producers, an increase in the age limit for superannuation contributions and R&D tax concessions for partnerships. I had just started to speak on the proposed rebate for superannuation contributions made on behalf of a low income or non‐working spouse. It is on that matter that I wish to conclude my remarks this afternoon.

BREAK.PARA: This measure proposes a tax rebate of up to 18 per cent for the first $3,000 of contributions made on behalf of a non-working spouse or low income couples. Low income is defined as `having an income of less than $13,800, phasing out between $10,800 and $13,800'. The superannuation committee requested modelling from the government on how this measure would raise national savings. That has been the theme of the government's approach: `We must do this because it raises national savings'.

This modelling has not been provided, and I do not think that we know or the government knows for certain that this measure will increase national savings. It will increase national savings only if the increase in retirement savings is more than the $38 million a year cost to revenue for this measure.

Of course, that depends on an assessment of who the people are who are most likely to benefit. We think they are likely to be taxpayers who, on top of the $3,000 a year contributions that the government will provide a tax rebate on in the savings rebate already announced in the budget, can afford to make even more savings contributions on behalf of a low income spouse.

Who are they likely to be? I think they are much more likely to be high income earners than anybody else, because which ordinary Australian battling family with a dependent spouse will be able to afford to make payments of $3,000 a year into their own superannuation? That is $58 a week. What families will be able to do that and then have money left over to contribute on behalf of their spouse?

Every analysis of the savings patterns on high income earners shows that they will arrange their savings allocations to maximise after‐tax rates of return. Providing additional incentives will not cause them to save more. As we have been told so often—by Mr FitzGerald as well—what we are likely to see is a switch from one form of savings to another.

The Democrats do not want to discourage low and middle income families from increasing their contributions to superannuation if they can afford to do it. But we do not want to provide yet another tax break to high income families for their tax planning accountants to reduce their contribution of tax burden even further.

Senator Sherry has foreshadowed amendments to the rebate to subject this rebate to the same means test as the family tax payments and the same assets test as is used in determining social security benefits. We think this is an entirely defensible position. If the government feels that these families are sufficiently wealthy to not need tax relief on tax, then why should we put in place inconsistent tax treatment here?

It was not very long ago that the government wanted us to pass a superannuation surcharge tax for high income earners, arguing that their tax breaks were too high. With this bill, they get much of that tax break back again by simply transferring the contribution to their spouse's name. I think we should prevent that.

The use of the social security assets test is also consistent with the government's treatment of access to social security. If the government believes that people with assets above $376,000 should be self‐sufficient for social security payments, then why provide them with additional benefits of up to $540 a year from the taxpayer?

We have had a lot of lectures from the government on the need for means testing of social security benefits and other tax benefits. What we are saying in support of Labor's amendments is: `Let's just have some consistency.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another omnibus tax bill. The major issue most people will be focusing on will probably be the capital gains tax measures for small business, but there are other issues too. Capital gains tax—or CGT—is a tax on the increased value of assets. It is a tax on the increased value of investments or the increased value of a business.

SPEECH.PARA: The poor do not pay CGT. Most people would generally pay CGT only on the sale of a house and maybe occasionally on some stock. Business people have to pay CGT on a few other investments or on some business assets. This includes assets in a small business or the small business itself.

Capital gains are for assets that appreciate. They are not for cars, unless they are collector cars. They are not for commercial vehicles; they are not for business assets that depreciate, which are most business assets in either productive, resale or wholesale enterprises.

Manufacturing and office equipment depreciates. Most stock bought for sale depreciates. There is no capital gains on these. Capital gains taxes do not apply where money has been invested in depreciable assets. Standard business taxes take account of those, and they are usually deductions in the calculation of annual taxable income.

A small business typically invests in a shopfront or workshop and equipment, and in their stock‐in‐trade, or inputs. For both productive and resale businesses there is stock bought wholesale, or the costs of materials, plus labour, plus the cost of overheads which is balanced against business profits. Tax is paid on the profits each year as company tax. Capital inputs have capital balanced against assets. The increase in assets is due to capital input, so they are not capital gains. Most assets generally then begin to depreciate.

BREAK.PARA: When a business is sold the sale price is either more or less than the audit value of the company. If it goes for more, then it is subject to capital gains. If it is sold for the same or less than the audited value, then there is no capital gain. There may be a capital loss. This is fairly typical of a small family business.

Where there is a gain in the businesses we normally think of as family businesses of ordinary people, that gain is generally based on a value put into the company as an identity—the goodwill or the name and profile of the company. The reputation of business has a value not reflected in monetary inputs but which may be reflected in the value of the company.

Another place where an increase in capital value may be generated is an incidental gain, such as when a business operates out of premises they own. If the business is sold, appreciation on the value of the land, irrespective of the business, may make it more valuable. Many small family businesses lease premises but some, especially older ones, may own the land they operate from. This is, however, a value which may require the business to be relocated or dissolved in order to be realised as something other than an appreciated asset. That is where capital gains are likely to affect the ordinary small businesses.

There is another class of small business, however. These are the family businesses of the well‐off whose prime purpose may be to provide more advantageous tax treatment of investment. As investment vehicles they generally do not own material stock bought wholesale for resale; they generally do not own materials or productive equipment. That is not the sort of business they do. They are vehicles for investing in assets that appreciate and so develop capital gains. These are the businesses most likely to be affected by the government's changes.

The assets we are talking about are land, rental property, corporate stocks, bonds and other investment assets like paintings. Are these sorts of businesses the intended beneficiaries? What class of people are we seeking to benefit? In many regards this particular measure is equivalent to, and in line with, the Costello savings scheme which primarily benefits anyone wealthy enough to have reasonably large amounts of surplus capital—in other words, it would largely exclude the great majority of Australians, including small business people.

Trusts and such may operate businesses and, according to the Australian Taxation Office, for tax minimisation purposes people put assets like stock and paintings into such businesses. The tax office made that point and tried to convince me that the personal tax measures in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) and in this other bill would not apply to such things.

There may be benefits for ordinary small businesses, but we seem to be talking primarily about giving CGT relief and roll‐over relief to what are effectively family businesses in the Dallhold model, shells for the rich in complex webs of business structures. We are told that the whole of business assets are considered in the assets test but we know—and we are often told by the tax office when it wants to claim more tax—that the rich get away with at least hundreds of millions of dollars worth of tax dodges by using the law to claim things that are not assets, or not theirs, or not assessable or whatever.

Now we are told that under self‐assessment they will of course report the whole of their wealth. This measure is not likely to benefit small business. It will benefit structurally small companies involved in investment. Companies primarily holding investment assets of land, stock or whatever will be the big winners. This will mainly serve the better‐off sector of the community. Given the record of this government so far, this is not any surprise.

For the Greens, a fundamental issue is to assure that those who get the scheme are not the very rich. We would like to reduce the opportunity to rort the scheme as much as possible. In light of that, we will support the ALP amendments to replicate the ceiling of $5 million in assets and the measure to include personal use assets with resale value over $5,000 and those which increase in value. The latter are investments or can act as investments, even if they give us use value in the meantime. We should not be creating tax shelter for investments in holiday chateaux or yachts.

We also seek limits to the amounts of capital gains that can be rolled over into retirement products. We do not think that the rich should be allowed to roll over massive amounts into retirement trusts, particularly where they have discretion on the investments as they do in some of these schemes. They can, of course, put money into such schemes without any real loss to current disposable income. This is not the case for working people. Workers are unlikely to be able to roll anything like half a million dollars into a retirement vehicle.

In fact, this measure will give an avenue to the rich to negate the effect of the so‐called superannuation surcharge tax which was supposed to do something about the way the well‐off could use tax breaks for superannuation to minimise tax. This provides them with another way of minimising tax by putting it into retirement funds. As a result, we will support the ALP amendments regarding the change from $500,000 to $250,000.

Another extremely contentious issue in terms of distributive justice is the superannuation contributions made on behalf of a spouse. This is what ordinarily the tax office would identify as income splitting and be doing all in its power to stop. Under this scheme a rich person should be able to get a rebate to put superannuation into their spouse's account when many people have trouble even supporting a spouse. It also runs entirely counter to the whole thrust of the superannuation surcharge tax.

I do not always agree with the Australian Taxation Office on the income splitting issue. In some cases, it serves valid social objectives to allow people, wealthy or not, to provide for others in a way that gives them some independence. It means that ultimately such beneficiaries will neither become dependants of those providing for them nor dependants of the state.

The issue I look at in this regard is whether the person being provided for is already functionally of independent means. In such a case, it is not actual provision for their well being; it is simply rearrangement of family assets for tax minimisation. In most cases, where the spouse is a married spouse and the taxpayer is able to contribute $3,000 per year to their credit as a tax measure, one would conclude that they are likely to have either a substantial income or substantial assets. As a family, they will still have substantial assets and income relative to the vast majority of the population. In short, they will probably have incomes of upper‐level management workers, even if they are not flat‐out rich. Most people who get the superannuation contribution do not need it to maintain an adequate income.

My assessment of this is that it is part of the general benefits this government is providing for the rich. It is an avenue for tax deduction that most people cannot use. It is an avenue that requires significant surplus capital for someone to make use of. It fits in nicely with the capital gains tax deals for the family investment‐oriented companies of the rich. It fits in well with the savings scheme, which benefits anyone making virtually any significant investment, but does almost nothing for investments of the size most people can afford.

This is also part of the coalition agenda for women and families. It is a perk specifically designed to benefit families with one working partner. It does nothing for families where both people work. It does nothing for single parent families. My understanding of this is that it cannot be used to provide superannuation for a partner who no longer lives with the taxpayer, who is separated or divorced. I am surprised that, in the requirements for eligibility, the government did not include possession of a labrador and a white picket fence in the front yard. I suppose that is because the rich are more likely to have guarded security walls and an alsatian. What is the argument, that the spouse of someone who can afford to put $3,000 into the superannuation fund of their partner needs special incentives for their support? As a family they are likely to own at least one house and have substantial savings and investments.

At retirement age, the spouse and the taxpayer will probably be able to support themselves quite well. I have heard an argu ment that not all women who are partners of the rich are well off, but if they were to leave their partner or if their partner was to die, they would receive substantial assets. A married spouse is likely to inherit. A married spouse, in the event of separation, generally gets alimony, half the joint assets and a part of the superannuation of their husband or wife.

For these reasons, I will oppose schedule 10 of this bill. There is no excuse for allowing income splitting by the well‐heeled to provide for those who will be provided for anyway in almost any case. There is nothing whatsoever to stop any well‐off person from putting money for a spouse into any investment they wish. There is no punitive taxation such as that applied to money invested in the name of a child. There is nothing to stop the well‐heeled from putting money for a spouse into superannuation, a house, stock, a trust or a savings account. We are not removing barriers; we are creating incentives through giving tax breaks of which the rich will primarily be able to avail themselves. This is a perk for the rich in so‐called traditional families and very few others will ever see any benefit from this. I oppose it strongly when basic social infrastructure and social services for all levels of society are being cut off due to lack of funds.

However, I do recognise that this measure is likely to pass with the support of the Labor Party. I understand the ALP will put amendments to make the tax break conditional on the taxpayer's income and assets and to exclude the richest. We will support that. I believe, if this goes ahead, to the greatest extent possible it should at least be limited to those who actually need it,

In that light, the definition of `spouse' in the Income Tax Assessment Act is fairly broad and includes virtually anyone living together in a marriage‐like relationship. It explicitly includes people who are not legally married. While I have argued that those married to the rich are liable to be provided for whether or not they explicitly have a superannuation account, there may be an argument in relation to those who are not married. It is more difficult for a non‐working or minimally‐working de facto partner to claim assets or support in the case of death or separation.

Since those who are married will probably be looked after, I will put an amendment to make it a requirement that, to get a tax break on such a contribution, the spouse should be unmarried—or de facto in the case of people in a more problematic situation. There is another class of spouses who are in an even more problematic situation, where they are even less likely to be awarded alimony or part of family assets in the event of separation, whether or not they have children. This group of people is currently also excluded from marriage. I am talking about same‐sex spouses. In line with our general recognition of familial diversity, I will also seek to broaden the definition of `spouse' in the Income Tax Assessment Act to include de facto same‐sex couples on the same basis as de facto opposite‐sex couples.

I have some major problems with the research and development section of this bill, which is designed to assure that syndicate‐like partnerships are not allowed. In previous bills, I supported research syndicates as good mechanisms to provide corporate funding for research and said at that time, if there were problems with claims for false or invalid research projects, that should be addressed directly, rather than gutting the scheme. In fact, it was the Senate amendments which preserved some measure of these schemes against the attack of government. So arguments about assuring that the intention of the Senate is carried out hold little weight. I still believe R&D is important and partnerships, including those that are syndicate‐like, should be allowed with whatever is needed to make sure the research projects themselves have value.

I also believe there are questionable aspects in allowing the beneficiary or trustee who acquires a dwelling as a result of death to be deemed to have acquired the dwelling at its market value on the date of death. I think the capital gain should be over a greater period, either from the date of acquisition or from the value in 1985 when capital gains tax became payable on houses. I am not in favour of supporting high levels of inherited wealth. If a person owes a fair bit of tax on getting a house, I cannot imagine that, with a house as collateral, they cannot get a long‐term loan. Capital gains tax is a minimal form of wealth tax.

I will ask questions in the committee stage about the sales tax on telecommunications and audio‐visual equipment. I have a problem with the way the tax office will consider the components in something like a solar water heater, exclude the specially designed tanks that are there on the basis that they can be used for other purposes and then try to push the reverse principles for items like transformers that plug into equipment, even though those transformers are able to be purchased separately as exempt electrical goods.

I would also like to note that although I will support the measures to ensure that superannuation contributions are made in respect of workers over 65, I fear in terms of this and other measures of government that this tends to be the first stage of a push to extend the retirement age to 70. I do oppose this. I think it is one of those things where something dressed up as a reasonable measure is actually part of a wider covert agenda.

There are other minor issues in this bill, but I remind senators that we are putting all these issues into law. After assent, they will affect real people and will change the structure of our society in small or large ways. It is not enough to claim that we are in a hurry, that we do not have time to properly consider the issues in this bill. `We were in a hurry,' does not really cut it, especially at the beginning of a session. We owe it to the people of Australia to properly debate and amend legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 and the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . We have debated them before. We are continuing our debate. My colleague, Senator Sherry, has argued persuasively and cogently about the inefficiencies in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 and Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 and foreshadowed, on behalf of the opposition, changes that are appropriate to make these bills just and fair for taxation payers in Australia. I support his remarks and hope that the Senate can be persuaded to the course of rationality that he has presented.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to concentrate my remarks, however, on one aspect of these omnibus bills, that is, section (pa) of the tax act—that section of the tax act that deals with the rights of prospectors in a range of industries, but including the goldmining industry, when they sell prospects that they have discovered for mining for future development, that is, mining by a mining company of some sort or other.

In the 1996‐97 budget, the government announced that it was going to close down what it called a loophole for what it alleged was tax avoidance by who it said was prospectors for minerals in Australia. When the opposition looked at the proposal that the government had actually brought forward as opposed to what it claimed it was going to do, the opposition said it would support the principle of the change because it did, in fact, render a service to the tax act and provide tax fairness across the board, but that what it would not support was retrospective application of that proposal. This debate is really about that issue: whether or not the government is proceeding to retrospectively claw back from taxpayers rights that they are reasonably, justifiably and fairly entitled to.

I might add that a Senate committee, the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, examined this and came down with a recommendation—I recall unanimously—that retrospectivity here on tax law should be avoided. It proposed certain things, none of which the government has followed. The government, in bringing forward the changes that it has brought forward today, knows that it is directly opposing a finding of the Senate economics committee with respect to this provision. I say these things to make the record clear.

There is probably one other explanation that is necessary to make the record clear. Last year, before the parliament rose, this provision came before the parliament as part of a series of provisions. At that time, I moved an amendment on behalf of the opposition which would have clarified the situation and put it beyond reasonable doubt. That amendment was not carried by the Senate. An amendment which constricted and, I believe, in the minds of the people who moved it and in the minds of the senators who voted for it, would have prevented retrospectivity, but prevented it in a more intelligent way, perhaps they would argue, than mine did—I think mine was very intelligent, but they would argue that theirs was better, and I respect their difference—would have restricted it and nonetheless prevented retrospectivity.

The facts are now—I think I state this fairly and without challenge—that, firstly, the change made last year is a change that is very difficult for the tax office to implement. Secondly, it is a change which does not protect the industry from retrospectivity. It is at this point that the further amendment that the government proposes comes forward. That further amendment, and the one that we now have in front of us for debate, does these things. It certainly makes the provision workable by the tax office, and that is, I guess, half a blessing, but what it does not do is address the issue of retrospectivity. In fact, it maintains a situation in which there would be retrospective application of the tax law unfairly and unjustly to this sector by the government if the amendment before the chamber is carried.

It is my intention, and I now hereby formally foreshadow it, to move in the committee stage an amendment which is, in the first instance, the amendment that I moved last year and which was defeated—a broad amendment to prevent retrospectivity. In the event of that amendment being defeated, I will move a more targeted amendment which I think collects the points that were made by those of the senators who supported the current amendment last year and delivers on their intent. There will be a third amendment in the case of the second one not succeeding. I formally give notice that, in the committee stage, I will move those amendments, clean up this issue once and for all and provide tax justice and fairness for an important sector of the Australian community. In terms of strategic importance, this is fundamental to the health and wellbeing of the Australian mining sector as a whole.

BREAK.PARA: What is true—and I will not elaborate this point at great length, although it ought to be emphasised and well understood in this chamber—is that Australia's major industry, particularly its major export industry, is mining. The existence and continued wellbeing of that industry sector depends on a healthy level of prospecting going on in this country.

If we do not prospect, we do not find future mining sites, and therefore we do not realise our ability as a nation to harness our mineral wealth for the national good. If we stop prospecting or we put hurdles in front of it to make it more difficult, or if we push people out of the prospecting sector, in the longer term we will choke off the ability of the mining sector as a whole to perform for the Australian economy the important role it has historically had.

It is a fundamental contention of mine that the government amendments would impose considerable constraint on the prospecting sector. Certainly, they would drive the small prospectors out of the sector, and they are the ones who have a better record, I would argue, of finding mineral associations worth mining. Prospecting would be left to the corporate giants who follow the conservative plays and who have a less impressive record, in my view, than the wildcatters—the small prospectors, who are the ones prepared to take the risks and make the chances of finding something more effective.

Let me now go to the government's proposal. As I said, we supported the closing off of this so‐called loophole, but we did not support it being done retrospectively. The amendment that we moved would have succeeded in achieving that. It was defeated. It was believed that the amendment that was carried closed off the loophole but did not provide retrospectivity. It is now found that it does not do so and that the clause is unworkable. Thus, the government is amending it again. The problem with the government amendment is that it makes the act workable but it does not answer the issue of retrospectivity.
I want to refer to three issues directly. The first, and the easiest to scotch, is the question of attacks upon me and self‐interest. I am a senator representing the state of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—And a good one, too.

—Thank you, indeed, colleagues! Some people say that this is a Western Australian issue, that the national good is being put aside in the interests of one state and that I, as a Western Australian, do not care about the national interest. To those attacks I say that the national interest is best served in these circumstances by not imposing retrospectivity in taxation law on the whole of this industry, wherever it is practised in Australia. The fact that there are probably more gold prospectors per head in Western Australia than in any other state is not the point, because gold is not the only metal or mineral that is subject to these provisions.

BREAK.PARA: Indeed, my colleague in the other place, Mr Stephen Smith, the shadow minister for resources, when attacked by a Tasmanian House of Representatives member, Mr Chris Miles, made the point that there is a vibrant minerals industry in Tasmania and that many of the other mineral commodities affected by this provision, other than gold, are found in that state. The list of those other minerals reads:
Antimony, chromite, cobalt, copper, gold, ilmenite, manganese, mercury, molybdenum, monazite, nickel, osmiridium, pyrite, rutile, tin, tungsten, zircon and graphite.
Prospecting for any one of those minerals is covered by the provision that is now before us, and it is in the national interest to protect the rights of prospectors wherever they are in Australia.

This is not the time to have a debate about gold, but I intend at some point to raise the issue of the decision of the Reserve Bank to sell Australia's bullion reserves, at the value of $2.4 billion, while at the same time wiping something like $2 billion off the value of shareholders' gold—in other words, having it transferred directly from the pockets of Australian shareholders to the Commonwealth Treasury. That has quite dramatically affected the price of gold and the value of one of Australia's leading export metals and has made marginal a number of functioning mines in this nation. That is an aside to the issue we are debating, but it is a debate I intend to have when the opportunity better presents itself later in the week.
With respect to this amendment, two specific issues are worth going to. Referring to the prospector, last year's amendment specified—and I refer to clause 23(pa)(ic)—that:
the person, on or prior to 20 August 1996 and at the time the income was derived . . .

This clause is saying that the remuneration from the sale of a mineral lease is taxable not at the time at which it is sold but at the time at which the income is derived from the sale. That is an important point.

The government is saying that it is requiring the taxpayer to be a bona fide prospector at the time the income is derived. The government contends, firstly, that this provision reflects the policy behind section 23(pa) since its introduction. Secondly, the government contends that it is a fundamental requirement that the exemption is only available to the person who has undertaken the majority of the fieldwork in that area. Thirdly, the government contends that it ensures that the tax treatment of income derived in an income year applies to the circumstances in that year. Finally, the government contends that to remove this requirement would amount to a change of policy during the phasing‐out period.

They are the explanations I have been given. Let me deal with each of those contentions. Firstly, the policy behind section 23(pa): the first point to be made is this is an attack on the small prospector who returns income on a cash basis to comply with tax law; that is, when the cash is received is when they are required to disclose the income. Larger prospectors who are required to account for income on an accruals basis can disclose the income when they sell the prospect.

If there is any delay in settling the sale of tenements due to, for example, native title claims or ministerial approval for transfer of tenements, then the bona fide prospector is at risk of losing their exempt status. These delays which are outside the control of the prospector could take months or years to resolve. Loss of exempt status could arise where the purchaser moves onto the area and carries out extensive work such that the fieldwork of the prospector is subsequently swamped by the purchaser's fieldwork.

There is no evidence that the exemption was previously only allowed where the taxpayer could prove that they were a bona fide prospector at the time the income was derived. As an example, I cite the Biggs case. The Biggs case involved a number of transactions with delayed settlements. The court made no inquiry in that case as to the work carried out by the purchaser after the prospector had sold the tenements and neither was this raised by the commissioner at that time. Whilst that was dealing with the old section 23(p), there is no material difference in its wording on that point.

The ATO in its tax ruling on bona fide prospectors makes it clear that the status of the bona fide prospector is determined at the time of disposal, not when the proceeds are received. The following sections of TR 92/19 issued by the Australian Taxation Office in 1992 prove that the government is wrong in its assertion that this represents a change of policy, because the policy has always been to determine eligibility for the section 23(pa) exemption at the time the rights to mine are disposed of, not at the time that the income is derived. The two relevant sections of the tax ruling are sections 7 and 48. I will not read them in full now in the face of time but I reference them for the officers advising the minister.

The second proposition in the government's argument is that the exemption is only available to the person who carries out the majority of the fieldwork. I guess that has to be accepted because that is what section 23(pa) says. But the issue is at what point does that test have to be satisfied: at the time income is derived or at the time of disposal of the rights to mine? The second proposition I think adds nothing to the government's argument and does not detract from the argument that I have put.

The third contention of the government that I have cited is a meaningless statement and does not provide any support for the argument. There is no fundamental provision in tax law that states the income tax treatment of a transaction must always be determined by the circumstances which apply in the year income is derived. As an example of that, take the sale of the family home: whether it is exempt from capital gains tax is dependent on a number of issues, many of which have nothing to do with the circumstances in the year the home is sold. Its use for income producing purposes 10 years ago will affect the tax liability on sale. It also raises the question of what circumstances are being referred to by the government in this particular case.

The final of the four reasons I gave, and which the government holds to, also falls away as the analysis in my first point shows that it has always been policy to consider the fieldwork test at the time of disposal, not at the time of income derivation. So there is no change in policy. I think the point about becoming eligible at the time the return is received by the individual should be registered. As I understand it, that is also a position supported strongly by the Minerals Council of Australia.

The other point in this amendment concerns market value and how you arrive at a market value. I will make two quick points in the time that I have left. In June 1995, the Australian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy issued a Code and guidelines for assessment and valuation of mineral assets and mineral securities for independent expert reports, which is called the Valmin code. The Valmin code makes it clear that, in making market value assessments, you ought not give one figure. There is a range of figures because you are looking at a number of factors that could change. I cite the Valmin code as the industry code for guidance in setting market value valuations. This amendment, if carried, would require there to be a one‐figure valuation; whereas the industry code, which is supported by the Australian Stock Exchange as the reasonable code and endorsed by the Minerals Council of Australia as the appropriate code, makes it clear that you cannot report the values in that manner.

To continue that point, the Australian Securities Commission, in its Practice note 43 on valuation reports and profit forecasts released in December 1993, specifically makes that point in paragraph 38 as well. So when you are calling for a valuation in the tax act, you ought to know that the valuation codes of the regulatory authorities—the Securities Commission, the Australian Stock Exchange and the Minerals Council—do not require and argue specifically against the possibility of coming up with a single figure valuation. Therefore, the provision in this bill would fly against the basic means of regulating forecasts or assessments of valuation of properties held in that time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Since the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 is an omnibus bill and there are detailed arguments in relation to a number of contentious clauses of it, I thought that I would handle the detail in the committee stage rather than debate the detail as it has been raised by honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I do thank the senators who have made a contribution to this debate. I would like to make a number of broad statements to conclude this second reading debate, and to commend the second reading to the Senate.

Firstly, Senator Cook has just spent a long time giving a detailed analysis of the proposals and the effects of clause 23(pa). What the government is seeking to do is to put into effect—and Senator Cook appreciates this to the extent that he says it makes it more administrable by the tax office and that that is half like a good idea—the amendment that was moved successfully by Senator Murray in the committee stage consideration of a previous tax laws amendment bill in relation to making sure that the effect of this provision was entirely prospective—please excuse the pun on the word `prospector'.

There is absolutely nothing—and these amendments will ensure that that is the case—which makes the proposal retrospective. In fact, the effect of one of the Labor amendments would be to ensure that the proposals and, specifically, the effect of the grandfathering proposal are lost because it fails to restrict it to a bona fide prospector. But I will get into the details on that debate when we move to the committee stage shortly. It is also worth pointing out, even though I will go into more detail in the committee stage, that the effect of the Labor amendments on the revenue, combined with the effects of the previous amendment, would be in the order of $100 million. But that may not be of concern to those opposite.

In relation to the other matter which will be of importance to many tens of thousands of small business people across Australia, the amendment to be moved by Labor and the Greens—and there have been indications of support from the Democrats—seeks to reduce the capital gains tax exemption relief provided to small business people from $500,000 to $250,000. We hear from the Labor Party and the Democrats, but not so much the Greens, that they are in favour of helping small businesses.

What has the coalition done to help small businesses? We hear that very often in this place. We see it in the newspapers and hear it on television, and we hear it from small business people. The coalition is delivering a fundamental commitment to provide capital gains tax relief for small business people. But when we bring it before the Australian Senate they say, `Sorry, the small businessmen are all these wealthy people. They don't need this sort of relief—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.

—Not you, Senator Sherry, just generally. That mob out there say that that is too generous. I think it is fair to say to the small business people of Australia that next time they see a Democrat or Labor senator they should ask them, `Why did you chop down my capital gains tax exemption from $500,000 to $250,000?' The Labor Party brought in—just to make the argument—the reasonable benefits limit under its superannuation policy which, at the moment, subject to indexation, is up to around $909,000. So if you are a superannuant, you get relief up to $909,000.

BREAK.PARA: I will put it into context. What we are putting in place is relief for a small business person who has built up a small business—

TALK.START.PARA: —Relief? Optional taxation?

—Senator Conroy is saying `make it optional'. Senator Conroy wants to destroy small business; he wants to tax them to death; he does not want to give them relief. He does not want to give them support and assistance. He does not want to give them tax reform. I wonder if he supports Senator Gareth Evans's proposals for inheritance taxes. You had better tell us where you stand on that, Senator Conroy. Maybe he will bring in inheritance taxes.
—He said the states could levy it.

—Yes, he will tell the states to do it. That is a good question to ask of the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria. Does he support Gareth Evans's proposal for inheritance taxes? Does Mr Brumby want to bring in inheritance taxes, or are you going to bring Joan Kirner back and ask her to bring in inheritance taxes? This is what Senator Conroy and the others opposite will bring in.

BREAK.PARA: So, if you are a small business person and you put your life savings at risk and you invest in a small business and you seek to employ people, we are saying that we will give you capital gains tax relief of up to $500,000 if you have a business that is worth less than $5 million. Then Labor says, `No, that is too generous.'

If you put it in context, we are saying, `Right, at the end of a lifetime's commitment to this small business'—and it is over the entire lifetime—`you are exempt from the capital gains tax provisions up to a maximum of $500,000.' If that small business person has been successful enough to put away a capital gain of $500,000, they can go and invest that in a bank or in some other managed investment and expect a return. I do not know what the banks are paying at the moment, because I do not have any savings in a bank at the moment, but you could expect a return of something like $25,000 if you invested $500,000 at five per cent.

What the Greens and the Democrats and the Labor Party are saying is that a small business person cannot receive that sort of retirement income. What we are saying is that this is a matter of choice for small business people. The people opposite say, `Oh, we have to encourage the small business sector, get them out there investing and creating jobs,' and we agree with that. What we are saying is, `Let's give them some incentive.' A lot of small business people do not have the money to put into superannuation or other savings. They pump their money into their small businesses. They put the money into the small business to try to create an income for themselves and their families—obviously to look after themselves in retirement.

We are saying that it is very good to invest in your own small business. We are saying that, if you do that—if you make that commitment and you invest and you employ people, especially young people—there should be an incentive at the end of it. We are saying that, if you can put together $500,000 under all of the constraints within this legislation, under current interest rate regimes and returns on investments, you might get $25,000 or $26,000 or $27,000 in retirement income because of this measure of tax relief for small business people.

The Democrats, the Labor Party and the Greens have said, `No, that is too generous. You can't have $500,000. You can't have $25,000 a year. We are going to chop that in half to $250,000.' So for a lifetime's work and a lifetime's commitment to small business, to helping Australia, to employing people and to providing for yourself, you can have $12,500 income to live off for the rest of your life.

Thank you very much, Labor Party, and thank you very much, the Australian Democrats. We think the small business people of Australia deserve this relief. We think it is a way to encourage small businesses to invest in Australia and to go out and employ people. You are saying, `Don't have any of that. Make sure they go on the pension when they retire.' That is the message for small business people. We will watch how you vote on this amendment.

In relation to that amendment, the other proposals for change to throw 23(pa) open and the other matters, the government regards these as important measures. They are measures that implement our commitments to the Australian people, particularly to the small business sector, in relation to FBT, to remote area housing and to the other matters in this bill. If those amendments are carried—and we refer specifically to the CGT exemption and to the changes in relation to 23(pa)—then the government will have to present the bill back to the Senate to insist on the important measures that are within it.
I will go into more detail on the specific amendment proposals in the committee stage. At this stage, I close the second reading debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 5 (line 15), omit "$500,000", substitute "$250,000".
(2) Schedule 1, item 3, page 5 (after line 26), after section 160ZZPZB, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 160ZZPZBA Threshold criteria in respect of maximum net value of assets of taxpayer and related persons

PARA.TAB: (1) This section sets out the threshold criteria all of which must be satisfied before this Division applies in relation to the disposal by a taxpayer of an asset.

TAB.TAB: Note: The criteria must be satisfied at the disposal time.

PARA.TAB: (2) In this section, asset has the meaning given by subsection 160ZZPL(1) except that an asset referred to in paragraph 160ZZPL(1)(a) does not include an asset which may:

TAB.TAB: (a) appreciate in value; or
(b) have a resale value of more than $5,000.

PARA.TAB: (3) The net value of the taxpayer's assets must not exceed $5,000,000.

(4) If the taxpayer or an associate of the taxpayer is a partner in a partnership and the asset disposed of is an asset of the partnership, the net value of the partnership's assets must not exceed $5,000,000.
(5) The sum of:

TAB.TAB: (a) the total of the net values of the assets of the taxpayer; and
(b) the net values of the assets of any entities that are connected with the taxpayer; and
(c) if the taxpayer is a partner in a partnership (other than a partnership that is connected with the taxpayer)—the share of the taxpayer in the net value of the assets of the partnership; and

(d) if an associate of the taxpayer is a partner in a partnership (other than a partnership that is connected with the taxpayer)—the share of the associate in the net value of the assets of the partnership;
must not exceed $5,000,000.

PARA.TAB: (6) The net value of the assets of an entity at a particular time for the purposes of this Subdivision is the amount (if any) by which at that time the sum of the market values of the assets of the entity exceeded the sum of the liabilities of the entity that related to those assets (other than a liability that related to an asset that is not an asset for the purposes of this Part because of paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d) of the definition of asset in subsection 160ZZPL(1)).

BREAK.PARA: (3) Schedule 1, item 3, page 12 (line 20), omit, "$500,000", substitute "$250,000".
(4) Schedule 1, item 3, page 12 (line 23), omit, "$500,000", substitute "$250,000".
(5) Schedule 1, item 3, page 16 (line 25), omit "$500,000", substitute "$250,000".

These amendments flow on from the points that Senator Campbell was making incorrectly about Labor's approach to the capital gains tax rollover amount that will be exempt from tax under this proposed legislation. We propose to reduce the capital gains tax rollover amount that will be exempted from tax if rolled over into a retirement product from half a million dollars to $250,000.

We regard our approach as an equity measure. Currently, a worker who receives a bona fide redundancy payment receives a tax-free amount of $4,348 plus $2,174 for each year of service. For a worker to qualify for up to $250,000 of tax relief under a bona fide redundancy, they would have to work for 113 years, according to the figures I have got, and that is clearly an impossibility for any Australian worker to do. So even Labor's proposed amendments making the rollover of the retirement product $250,000 at the exemption level rather than half a million dollars, as the government is proposing, are still extremely generous when seen in the context of what is available to other people in the Australian work force.

But there are a number of other aspects to Labor's approach to this that should be taken into account. For example, many small business operators do currently have operating superannuation schemes as well as their small business. Senator Campbell might like to provide us with the figures of the number of small business operators who have superannuation.

Those small business people who are going to benefit from this measure and also have superannuation schemes enjoy a very generous—we believe, correctly generous—approach for the tax treatment of superannuation. So they have got that benefit as well. We do not believe it is appropriate that the taxpayer should subsidise the retirement of a number of people by giving tax relief up to $500,000 in capital gains given these circumstances. We think $250,000 is reasonable enough.

Senator Campbell should also address Labor's amendments in the context of some of the other changes his own government has made. For example, we had a very lengthy debate in the context of the deeming of superannuation at age 55. It is a measure which your government has introduced. Labor has taken a consistent approach on these types of benefits to people in the broader community. The consistent approach is: we have taken the view that a quarter of a million dollars is a reasonable level at which to strike these exemptions.

In the context of deeming superannuation, in respect of which, I have to say, your government has passed legislation, you have deemed people's superannuation assets when they turn 55 starting, effectively, at $30,000. The people who are affected by this measure are people who, in many cases, have struggled long and hard to put money aside into superannuation in exactly the same way that the small business entrepreneurs in this country have struggled over many years to build up a business. There is no difference of principle.

The other aspect to these amendments is that there is a change of the test from a net business asset test to a net total asset test by including all personal use assets, except for those personal use assets that have a value of less than $5,000, which will be excluded. We do not accept your exemption figure of half a million dollars, but let us assume that is passed. Is it reasonable for a small business operator to be able to benefit not just with respect to their business assets but also with respect to the personal wealth assets that they have got? We do not believe that that is reasonable.

It may well be that there are some small business operators who have art collections or boats or other assets that they have accumulated. I do not criticise them for that accumulation of those personal assets. What small business operators choose to do with their money is up to them. But to not exclude those types of assets when establishing the effective cut‐off point for the exemption from capital gains tax is totally wrong in principle and totally wrong in terms of fairness and equity.

In recent times we have heard a lot about fairness and equity in relation to the government's approach on superannuation. I ask Senator Campbell: where does the issue of the new tax on superannuation fit into small business? I know a lot of small business operators who are very angered by the introduction of the new 15 per cent superannuation tax, for example. It seems to Labor, Senator Campbell, that on a range of superannuation issues—treatment of capital gains tax, the new tax on superannuation, the deeming provisions—your policy approaches are totally inconsistent. You introduce a new tax in one area, you deem superannuation in another area, then you attempt to give a substantial benefit. Labor believes that there should be a benefit given to small business. But you have taken a totally contradictory approach in a range of your policy initiatives and legislation to date.

We think that small business operators should be rewarded. Taking into account their background, their dedication and commitment over many years, and taking into account the other issues that I have outlined, this figure of $250,000 is a reasonable figure to allow to be rolled over from the assets of a small business into a retirement product and to exempt from capital gains tax.

Labor's approach in these amendments is not philosophically to disagree with your approach, Senator Campbell, that small business should be rewarded. We endorse that approach. But we are here arguing about the justice, the fairness and the equity across the general community. Even if Labor's amendment is carried, and this figure is reduced to $250,000, in comparison with the rest of the community small business is being generously treated. We do not decry their being generously treated, but we think that some level of relative fairness and equity across the general community has to be taken into consideration, as matched against ordinary workers, as matched against everyone else in the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were to listen to Senator Campbell, you would think that the parliament had done nothing at all for small business since this government came into office, and that is not true. I think we need to get the issue of the capital gains tax rollover into perspective. We are not saying, Labor is not saying, that we do not want to see the retirement savings of small businesses fairly treated. We are differing over what we think is fair and equitable. We are saying that we want to make sure that large businesses cannot use this to wangle a benefit meant for small businesses, and I think the threshold the government is setting makes that possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should put on the record the tax breaks we have already provided for small businesses. The parliament agreed quite enthusiastically, as I recall it, to a rollover of the proceeds of the sale of a business each time it is used to buy a new business. So that gives those small businesses a deferral benefit. That is a real benefit, because that is a tax that they do not have to pay until many, many years later.

We have heard a lot about small business people having the opportunity to save through their businesses. Senator Sherry has pointed out how long it would take people to save the equivalent of this tax break. At another level, the fact is that a normal PAYE taxpayer has to save out of their after tax profits, but a business which saves through the business can frequently save money without having paid any tax on it. That is especially true if the business is incorporated and the earnings are retained within the company. Some people might say that that is, in some respects, a form of tax avoidance, but it is a tax advantage.

Then we have to ask: what is the advantage of rolling over from the business to super anyway? When would a person want to do that? They would probably want to roll over close to retirement age. That is a lot different from asking people to put money away much earlier in their working lives.

I think that if this measure is not properly targeted it will not end up encouraging retire ment savings and will provide a new tax planning opportunity pre‐retirement for a lot of people for whom it was not intended to. We have all said time and time again that we approve of doing something for genuine small business people—people who might not otherwise have sufficient funds to retire on—to help them save for retirement, but we do not think that extending the measure to bigger business, the owners of which would already have sufficient retirement savings anyway, is a good idea. We think that is throwing money away.

That is why we think the $250,000 cap is very reasonable. It will catch, in an advantageous way, those business people who might have ended up on a part pension. We cannot see any merit at all in providing a new tax concession for people who would already be sufficiently wealthy not to end up on the part pension. The effect of this Labor amendment is simply to say: this is a reasonable cap, it gives genuine small businesses on average incomes a good incentive and does not allow slightly bigger ones to wangle a tax advantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We have mentioned that the Greens (WA) have basic problems with the capital gains tax breaks measures that have been provided for in both this bill and tax laws bill No. 1 last session. We believe they will primarily benefit the rich and will be just another loophole and another legal means to reduce their tax. These measures will do almost nothing for ordinary small and medium sized businesses. They are not going to help the battlers and the Ma and Pa businesses, stores and so on. They are not going to help the person who makes clothes, runs a welding or fabricating shop, makes wind generators or makes modems for computers. They are not likely to benefit from this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: The kinds of businesses that employ the majority of workers in this country are not going to be helped by this bill because the money they make is, for the most part, not capital gains money. The money they make is business profit and that is something else. We believe that the $250,000 cap is reasonable. Above that, we would basically give a benefit for the rich and the super rich in our society and it is not acceptable in the current times of stringent cuts—unacceptable cuts in my opinion—in other areas to simply reduce long-term business tax in other areas instead of looking at a sensible tax regime in Australia. The Greens (WA) certainly will be supporting the ALP amendment Nos 1 to 5 on sheet 594.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears from the opposition's amendments that the opposition does not have an argument with the government in principle. In other words, the opposition appears not to oppose the measures that are being proposed in this legislation to enable rollovers to be exempt from CGT. What size is the cap? Personally, I am not convinced that the arguments that have been advanced by the government for their particular sized cap should be cut in half. If they want to be generous, I think the government ought to be generous. They have asked us to look at small businesses. Certain suggestions have been made as to how best to help small businesses. I do not think that they have got that on their own because I think all of us around the chamber had that objective in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some concerns that the government is not placing the priorities where they should be and is not placing a priority on issues of fair trading for small businesses, to be quite frank. They are fiddling around with things such as exempting small businesses from the unfair dismissal proposals. That is an argument for another day. I will refer to what the Reserve Bank said in respect of that matter as it might relate to employment. Quite clearly, the indication from that source was that the government's proposal would have very little effect on employment at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which we have been saying for quite some time, all of us.

—As Senator Kernot has indicated, we have all been saying that for some considerable time, but it is interesting to hear the Reserve Bank statement on the matter. However, I want to take this opportunity to say that, if the government wishes to have the cap at $500,000 and there is no objection in principle to super rollovers for small businesses being exempt from CGT, then I will be opposing the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of comments in the context of some of the issues that Senator Harradine and Senator Campbell touched on. Senator Harradine, we, in a sense, debated this approach with respect to the exemption during the last sitting of the Senate. I would ask you to take into account your position on that occasion with respect to your consideration of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you have it all there, Senator Harradine. I would also ask you, Senator Harradine, to consider the fact that, if no-one is disagreeing in principle with the government's approach, it is still important that we consider, as we have done on previous occasions, issues of fairness and equity in our approach to what is the relevant cut‐off point for the rollover to take effect.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said in my previous comments, the superannuation tax concessions that are already available should be taken into account in the context of small business. Many small business people do have money in superannuation more broadly and obtain a significant tax benefit that way, albeit some of them are very upset at the government's new superannuation tax. Isn't it reasonable, Senator Harradine, to take into account other personal use assets such as those I touched on—art collections, boats or other forms of personal use assets worth more than $5,000—if that is where some small business people have chosen to acquire assets and wealth?

Senator Campbell referred to small businesses building up assets over many decades in some cases. I would like to point out, Senator Campbell, that capital gains tax only applies to assets built up since 1985, not to assets prior to 1985. We are not dealing with, as you wrongly and very generally and emotively asserted, assets built up over decades. That is just not correct.

I will conclude my point in respect of small business more generally. I, like many of my colleagues such as Stephen Martin, our small business spokesperson, and a number of our other shadow ministers, spent a lot of time with small business. I would have to say that, in the last couple of months during the recess, there are two issues that small business raised consistently with Labor. I suspect they have raised them consistently with you too if you are honest about what small business has been saying to you.

The first issue they raised with us is that they want consumer confidence restored. They want customers coming through their business door and spending money. There is a significant lack of confidence within the broader community and small business is suffering as a consequence of that lack of confidence which, to a significant part, I would argue, Senator Campbell, your government has created. There is a significant lack of confidence within the community. I am not just basing my remarks on small business in Tasmania. If you want a small business desert at the moment, come to Tasmania. They are very concerned about trading conditions. That concern is more generally held by small business right around the country at the moment.

The second issue they raise consistently is the issue Senator Harradine touched on—fair trading. They seem to me to be the two issues that are most consistently raised by small business. Frankly, I do not think I have had one small business operator raise this CGT rollover exemption for retirement products, as important as it is. They have certainly raised the new superannuation tax with me. Quite a number have raised that with me. They have certainly raised the deeming provisions at 55 as well, but not one has raised this measure you are proposing here.

In relation to the other point Senator Harradine made, I would have to say that a number of small businesses have raised the issue of exemption from unfair dismissal provisions, but overwhelmingly the issues are customers' demand and consumer confidence. They want money through their till. They want demand in the community and they want fair trading. I think they are the priorities that small business is currently concerned with and will be concerned with for some time.

BREAK.PARA: I am disappointed in Senator Harradine's approach. I hope he will reconsider, but I do not want to unnecessarily occupy the time of the committee if Senator Harradine is not going to give consideration to his stated position on these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to one point Senator Sherry made about the prospective application of this legislation post the date of the introduction of the capital gains tax by the Hawke Labor government. That is, of course, a statement of fact. However, when I speak about the atypical or hypothetical small business person working for a lifetime and working for decades and giving them incentives to save by investing in their own small businesses and, hopefully, at the same time, creating jobs which are much needed, we certainly think this measure will encourage people to do that. This measure is only one of many measures this government is bringing in to help small business.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Sherry that all small business people would like to see more cash through the till. They would like to see more consumer confidence and more people spending money. We hope that that will happen. I might also say to Senator Sherry that when I used to go around talking to small business people during the recession we had to have I got fairly harsh statements about his government. If he ever wants to see what consumer confidence can look like under a Labor government, my memory is not that short that I cannot remember conditions then.

Small business people do like the fact that interest rates have plummeted under this government. They did not enjoy 30 per cent interest rates under Paul Keating when they had to go to AGC and pay 30 per cent on business loans. We do believe that $500,000 is fair. This has become the key issue of the debate. We do believe in a small business person who has worked for a long time, even up to decades, committing themselves to investing in their business.

Senator Kernot, they have paid taxes all on their profits all the way through too. Small businesses pay tax on all of their profits, but they also have to live on the money they make out of their small businesses. They have to pay to put shoes on their kids feet, for their clothes and to put food on the table from their small businesses.

We are saying that, if you have spent a lifetime working in a small business, and you sell the business and make a capital gain of $500,000, that will return you about $25,000 a year. Now Labor and the Democrats are saying that is too generous, that a small business person should only be able to make $250,000 at the end of their lives. They may not have superannuation. They might have put all of their savings into their small business and you are saying that $12½ thousand a year as a retirement income after a life of hard work and toil in small business is good enough for them. We are saying it is not good enough.

We think that small businesses should benefit from this measure. We hope that, as a result, small business people will invest in their own businesses, will create employment and will retire on a living wage at the end of that lifetime's work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there has been an agreement to put amendment No. 2 separately. So I put the question that amendments Nos 1, 3, 4 and 5 be agreed to.
—I now put that amendment No. 2 be agreed to.

—With respect to amendment No. 2, I understand that the government has indicated that subparagraph (6) is not necessary. Could I have some elaboration from the government in respect of that particular part of amendment No. 2?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 2 proposes to insert threshold criteria in respect of the maximum net value of assets of a taxpayer and related persons. The criteria are identical to the criteria of section 160ZZPP that must be met to qualify for the small business CGT rollover relief. The criteria are already in the law in relation to the CGT rollover relief and the bill picks up the existing criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the revised amendment also seeks to include personal assets of the small business person such as the person's family home. This additional criterion will add a compliance cost to the measure. It is not consistent with our election commitment. The Labor Party attempted the same amendment in relation to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1), I think, and that was for the capital gains tax rollover relief for small business. On the last occasion, with the support of the Democrats voting against the measure and, I think, Senator Harradine, the amendment was voted down for the reasons that the government stands by.

In other words, in summary, the bill picks up the measures that already apply to the rollover relief. So the same measures apply, and the government is again saying that the exemptions that Labor is trying to put in this amendment are for the same reasons that the Senate, in its great wisdom, supported the coalition's position under Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1). We would again ask senators in their continuing wisdom to support us and oppose the Labor exemptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned in my second reading speech, the Greens (WA) will be supporting this amendment because we do not believe that a $5 million ceiling is unreasonable in these issues. If we do not put these kinds of delineations, the message going out to the community is: `If you are a non-government organisation, you can have your funds cut because there is an "enormously big back hole"; if you are involved with community based education or child care, you can have your funds cut because there is an "enormously big black hole", but, if you are very rich, we will give you taxpayers money.' That is not a good signal. Therefore, as signalled, we will be supporting this amendment.

—Senator Margetts, you may not have understood what I said. I only just understood it myself. The bill does not need to pick up this amendment. We are saying it is redundant because the existing law puts in place the $5 million cap. It is already there. You do not need to do this. That is what I am saying. We agree with you. You do not need to support the amendment to support your principle because it is already in the law.
—I thank the minister. In that case, there is no reasonable reason why this amendment cannot be supported to make that principle quite clear in relation to this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell has made a number of assertions and I think it would be worth while to reflect on those assertions because they are wrong, according to my information. Firstly, the voting record on the last occasion of Senator Harradine and the Democrats has been asserted. I do not know which particular vote you were referring to, Senator Campbell. Could you let us know which vote were you referring to in that comment, first of all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, if I have made any reflection on the voting record of either the Democrats or Senator Harradine, I will correct it. I will tell you what I will do: I will show you mine if you show me yours, and we will come back to it after question time.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Madam President, I inform the Senate of the resignation of the Hon. Geoff Prosser as Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs and of a number of changes that have followed therefrom.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon. Peter Reith has been appointed as Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Senator the Hon. Christopher Ellison has been appointed as Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General, and we all congratulate Chris on that elevation and are sure he will do very well. The Hon. David Kemp has been appointed as Minister Assist ing the Prime Minister for the Public Service; the Hon. Alan Cadman has been appointed Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business; and the Hon. Trish Worth has been appointed as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services.

In relation to representational responsibilities in this place, Senator Ellison will represent the Hon. John Moore as Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, the Minister for Science and Technology, the Attorney‐General and the Minister for Family Services. Senator Herron will now represent the Minister for Health and Family Services, Mr Michael Wooldridge.

On another matter, I inform the Senate that Senator Warwick Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy, will be absent from question time today until Thursday, 28 August inclusive, and on Monday, 1 September. Senator Parer will be in Canada attending the APEC Energy Ministers Conference. During Senator Parer's absence, I will take questions relating to the portfolio of primary industries and energy. I will seek to represent him as well as he represented me during the last sitting week. For the information of honourable senators I table an updated document showing all members of the ministry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, are the state and territory ministers for vocational education and training justified in roundly condemning the Commonwealth government, and your junior minister, Dr Kemp, as they did at their meeting in Adelaide last Friday, for failing to maintain adequate Commonwealth funding for vocational education and training? Do you understand the ministers' concern that your government—and I quote—`is not providing sufficient funding to support the new apprenticeships and the youth allowance initiative, and that young people are having their expectations raised unrealistically.'? How does the government propose to respond to these concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Other senators may not know what I assume Senator Carr does know, and that is that the Commonwealth is in the position of negotiating with the states at the moment vis a vis the new Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: Frankly, Senator, I would have thought that to ask this question in the light of those negotiations indicates that your training shadow minister or yourself—whoever has put you up to the question or is responsible for the question—has perhaps come down in the last shower. Because what you are seeing at the moment is what you frequently see, not just in the training area or in the education area, but in the health area and all areas where there are Commonwealth and state responsibilities together and where there has to be some re‐negotiation vis a vis financing. What you see then of course is standard positioning and re‐positioning tactics undertaken by the states.

The Commonwealth's overriding objective in this matter is very clear, and that is that opportunities for young people to improve their skills and qualifications must continue to grow. That is part of our vision of building competitiveness and job opportunities for the 21st century.

The Commonwealth has made it abundantly clear to the states that it is prepared to commit to maintaining real funding for five years, and that in return it expects the states to continue to improve the efficiency of their TAFE systems and to provide more places from those efficiencies. That is abundantly clear to the states—in effect, an offer of maintaining real funding for five years with an expectation that in return there will be an improvement in efficiencies within the TAFE systems, and that those efficiencies will be allocated to more places for growth in the VET sector.

It is clear from assessments by the National Training Authority that substantially more effective use could be made of the resources in TAFE. Senator, if you disagree we will be very happy to hear an explanation from you as to why you make the assumption that the VET sector is working at 100 per cent effi ciency. We believe from ANTA assessments that there are efficiencies that can be made. Clearly we believe that; that is the basis of the offer.

The Commonwealth welcomes the commitments made by the state ministers last Friday in Adelaide to the national training framework for vocational education and training, with a much strengthened role for industry. The states and territories have also, in case you were not aware, agreed to give a very high priority to the funding of new apprenticeships within their TAFE systems.

All in all, I think the states and the Commonwealth are heading in the same direction. We all recognise the need for more vocational training. I think there is a recognition that there are efficiencies that can be found, and what you are catching on the coat tails of is some pre‐ANTA agreement negotiations and positioning on behalf of the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it not true, as the state and territory VET ministers claim, that the Commonwealth `demanded that states and territories agree to the arbitrary creation of an additional 500,000 student places', and then required these new places to be funded by states and territories without additional Commonwealth funds, and in the context of earlier federal funding cuts? Haven't the states got every reason to be upset? Further, Minister, are you not concerned about the public criticisms by state and territory ministers that Dr Kemp continually makes media announcements about the state governments' efficiencies that he was unprepared to actually put to those ministers at formal meetings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am not sure whether you were not listening to the answer or simply chose not to acknowledge the content of it, and whether you did so because you do not want to front up and answer the question on behalf of the Labor Party. That question is: do you believe that the VET sector is working at 100 per cent efficiency?
