It would be a very simple answer for you: either yes—in which case you would be the laughing stock of the nation—or no. And if your answer is no, then you do agree that there are efficiencies that can be found.

ANSWER.PARA: I have outlined in my answer to you the offer made by the Commonwealth through Dr Kemp for a maintenance of real funding to the VET sector for five years—

TALK.START.PARA: —Half a million extra places!

—Senator, if you know the answer you should not have bothered asking the question. The offer is for five years on the proviso that efficiencies are found and that those efficiencies go into new places. I would have thought that the kids who are looking for places in VET would have been very supportive of that move—and so should you be. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to Senator Hill. Over the last couple of months there has been further positive news for the Australian economy in the form of lower interest rates and lower inflation. How is the Howard government going to further assist families and small business? What are the implications of the recent annoucements, such as those in relation to the car industry and the Alice Springs to Darwin raliway line?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there certainly has been further good news on the economic front during the last couple of months. The last two you mentioned, Senator Boswell, I would particularly like to note. Firstly, if I can put it in its broader context, the economic picture remains very promising.
—Promising? What about consumer spending?

—Let us look at inflation, for example, since Senator Sherry wants to interrupt. We have the lowest inflation now since 1963—1.7 per cent. We have had five reductions of interest rates since this government came to power—10.5 per cent down to 6.7 per cent, a fall of 3.8 per cent. All Australians will remember the days of Labor when the housing loan interest rate went up to 17 per cent. That was Labor's record on housing—17 per cent interest rates. Under the coalition government, savings have been achieved of some $317 a month on a standard variable home loan—a real achievement.

ANSWER.PARA: For small businesses it has been good news as well, with interest rates falling to 8.75 per cent. Do you remember Labor, Madam President, with small business interest rates over 20 per cent? That was Labor's record—and it has fallen substantially under the coalition government. We have a picture of improving business confidence. The NAB July survey of business confidence for August showed the highest monthly level since the beginning of the series in March—good sign! The Westpac Melbourne Institute index of economic activity in June rose for the third consecutive time. The ACCI survey of business expectations shows that business confidence is high. I quote:
An upbeat assessment is shown for general business conditions, sales, employment, profitability and investment.

The picture for economic growth is also very positive. The OECD expects Australia will experience the fastest economic and employment growth among the G7 countries over 1997‐98. The Economist predicts that Australia will be the fastest growing industrial economy among the 15 countries that it reviewed over the year 1997‐98.Of course, the Reserve Bank governor has now stated that the economy can grow at four or 4½ per cent over the next couple of years without any adverse effect on inflation. This is really good news for all Australians.

Business investment is currently running at about 13 per cent of GDP—a record high business investment, a record high in real terms and expected to strengthen even further in the year 1997 to 1998. We are continuing to reduce the deficit legacy of Labor. We inherited a deficit of over $10 billion. Within three years we will be achieving a surplus of $1.6 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have taken the guts out of the economy.
—It is an excellent economic outcome, Senator Bolkus—
—Try and tell those behind you—they don't believe you!

—We have the decision at the weekend to finally meet Commonwealth undertakings of the last 80 years and build the Alice Springs to Darwin railway—a promise that so many governments had made but none had been prepared to deliver.

ANSWER.PARA: Add to that the consequences that are already flowing from our decision on tariffs in the car industry, the great news from Toyota that it will now double Australian exports over the next four years. There is a really good picture out there on the economy, and all Australians recognise it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —That certainly is good news for small business. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. At the risk of embarrassing the Labor Party, could the Minister give us some further initiatives that the government has undertaken to assist families and small business.

—Not only are we getting the deficit from $10 billion deficit to $1.6 billion surplus in just three years by taking hold of expenditure, but we were able to deliver the family tax promises to Australian families in full and on time. This is a government that delivers its promises. What is the contrast? What would families expect from Labor? You have already heard it from former Senator Evans, Mr Gareth Evans, the deputy leader, this weekend. He sees the prospect of death duties on families as the answer to Australians' dilemma. He sees the need to increase income taxes. He sees the need to increase payroll taxes—put more pressure on small businesses. So there is the contrast: a government that gets control of expenditure, cuts expenditure, enables us to take pressure off taxes, off inflation, off interest rates and delivers outcomes in terms of benefits to families—in contrast, Labor: high tax, high expenditure, more borrowings and taxes on death. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Vanstone, Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. My question relates to recent comments on the Commonwealth's new appren ticeship scheme by the Victorian Minister for Tertiary Education and Training, Mr Phil Honeywood. Are you aware, Minister, that Mr Honeywood has stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The coalition's recent announcement of 220,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships is so poorly designed it might force the government into setting up a higher education contribution scheme for TAFE.
And that:
The scheme is unlikely to have a significant impact in Victoria because there are no funds to create TAFE places.

Given these strong statements by your Liberal colleague in Victoria, what actions will you take to protect the quality of TAFE services and to ensure adequate funding for the much heralded new apprenticeship scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for the question. Senator Crowley, your question relates very closely to the question that Senator Carr has asked—
—What a surprise!

—Yes, what a surprise; you often do not manage to have a coordinated approach. I think that the answers that I have given to him are very applicable to this. You see, we are in the middle of renegotiating the Australian National Training Authority agreement. That very much relates to VET funding for the states.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a lot of positioning going on by the states at the moment—and I probably would be doing the same if I were a state minister—obviously seeking to maximise the opportunities for funding from the Commonwealth. What the Commonwealth has said to the states—and we have made this offer—is that we will maintain funding in real terms for five years, but they have got to find efficiencies. We have indicated that those efficiencies should be put into extra places.

All you are seeing, Senator Crowley, is the same as I told Senator Carr that he was seeing: negotiating and repositioning by the states—in this case Minister Honeywood, an excellent minister who is very keen on more vocational training in schools, who has put more vocational—

TALK.START.PARA: —He speaks highly of you as well!

—That is pleasing to know, Senator. Thank you very much. He is keen to put more vocational training back into schools and to ensure that that vocational training is not a lock‐off—that is, that people are not locked off from a higher education and can move on, for example, to university. He is doing an excellent job. But, as any state minister would be doing, he is trying to renegotiate and get more money from the Commonwealth. It is as simple as that. We are in negotiations with the states and, when they are resolved, everybody will know about it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sure that Mr Honeywood will be pleased to know that what he is doing is merely positioning. Are you aware, Minister, that Mr Honeywood has also said that Dr Kemp is more interested in his profile than in solving youth unemployment, and that:

QUESTION.PARA: At the end of the day unfortunately David is so hooked on his national profile and gaining the kudos for the federal government for its training reforms that he completely ignores his responsibilities.

Given this breakdown in trust—which is more than positioning, Minister—between the states and Dr Kemp, will you discipline your junior minister to ensure that he keeps his eye on the ball and not on his personal promotion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am not aware of those remarks by Mr Honeywood. I must say they seem most out of character to me.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr, cease interjecting.

—Phil Honeywood is not the sort of person or minister to play the person rather than the ball, and those remarks therefore come as a surprise to me. I do not see a need to discipline Dr Kemp. He is focused very much on the job. I would never have described Dr Kemp as someone who was seeking to promote his personal profile in any way whatsoever. He is very much a minister who focuses on getting the job done.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, in this repositioning between the states, every now and then there is a little bit of hot air one way or another, but I would not put too much on it, if I were you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which of your comments is hot air, Minister?

—Senator, if you wanted to answer the question yourself you should have stayed in government and been on this side. I am simply indicating to you that, in the renegotiations, often things are said, and you do not want to get too carried away with it. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to Senator Alston. I ask, in relation to the upcoming one‐third float of Telstra, whether the government has kept its election promise to give Telstra employees not only one free share for every four shares they purchase in the public share offer, but also a loyalty bonus for holding onto those shares for 12 months or longer? Is it a fact that this generous employee share offer is not only strongly supported by Telstra staff themselves, but is now also supported by the trade unions which so vehemently opposed the one‐third float?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Abetz is quite right. This is a very significant breakthrough because it means that the trade union movement is simply not taking the advice of its political puppets.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that prior to the last election we promised that there would be very generous arrangements for Telstra employees, and we said that they would be able to take up to 500 free shares. Indeed, we set aside notionally two per cent of the float. The reality is that we are now giving them 3.8 per cent—almost double that level of allocation—and, in addition to the 500 maximum free shares that they will get, there will be an additional maximum of 200 free shares by way of loyalty entitlements for holding on to those shares for more than 12 months. So it is a very good outcome for Telstra employees, and it is not surprising, therefore, that the trade unions have changed their tune, obviously voting with their pockets.

The CPSU's latest newsletter says that the union has announced that it will put in a claim for Telstra shares for its members as part of negotiations on a new enterprise agreement. The secretary said that there is a lot of support among members for a special allocation of Telstra shares for staff. So, quite clearly, the union knows all about having your cake and eating it. The tragedy is that Labor wants to have its cake by opposing it, and now it wants to spit the cake out.

They have not said `Boo' on this subject. I looked in vain for anything from the shadow minister on this subject. He has been as silent as the grave in recent months—quite clearly asleep at the wheel. We know that Senator Bob Collins is not able to be with us today. There is a glaring vacancy on the front bench but, of course, Mr Beazley cannot find anyone to make up the numbers so Senator Schacht presumably is safe for the time being.

If you really want to make a contribution, what you ought to do is get out there, put out a press release on the subject, tell the unions that they are right and tell them that this is actually a cooperative arrangement designed to recognise that it is a win‐win outcome for Telstra employees and for the company—and ultimately for shareholders—rather than pursuing the mindless negative opposition that we have seen over recent years.

I think the unions know that Kim Beazley has always been secretly in favour of the float. The tragedy is, of course, that he has been too scared to say so publicly. That is not the sort of leadership that they have been interested in and that is why they have refused to take your advice any further on this matter. It is important that the unions have been converted to the view that we have been consistently espousing—that is, that employee share ownership is a very good thing for all concerned. It offers attractive financial benefits to employees. It is good for Telstra because it gives the employees a financial incentive to improve their own performance and the company's performance.

That is a very welcome change of heart from the position that was put in a joint union submission to the Senate inquiry last year when there were concerns expressed about the possible effect of the float on employment levels and wages, and on conditions of employees—in other words, all of the negative connotations which they could find. They have changed their tune and it is about time the ALP changed its tune and recognised that this is, indeed, the way the rest of the world has gone. If you want to be forward looking and taken seriously, then it is not back to the future on this issue, as with all the others. You ought to get up with the times, put out that press release, say what a good thing it is, congratulate the unions on taking a constructive approach and acknowledge, at long last, that this is the way to go for employees at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, you claimed recently that privately educated students are more likely to be employable. Are you asserting that there would be less youth unemployment if state schools provided, in your view, a better education? Is the problem really the standard of public education or is it the fact that you are doing nothing to create jobs for our young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chris Evans for the question. I refer him to the speech I made, on which he is obviously choosing to ask a question. On the basis of the way in which he has phrased his question, I can only assume that he has not read my speech. This government—myself, Dr Kemp, the Prime Minister, everyone in the government—is very supportive of choice in schooling, of there being a strong and effective government school system, which we have, and a strong and effective non‐government school system. That is obviously vital.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also recognised that not everybody will have that choice, either because of funding limitations on a family which may limit the available choice or there might be a geographic situation limiting a family's access to choice, that is, there may be only one particular school in their reasonable vicinity. The comments were certainly not indicating that there would not be any unemployment if schools performed in a different way.

The speech was made in the context of indicating that the environment into which young Australians are now going, if they choose to leave school early, is a much more difficult environment than it was, say, 10 years ago. I do not have the figures in front of me but I can certainly get them for you. The size of the youth labour force has drastically reduced. I think it has halved in something like a decade, so that if you now choose to leave school early—as soon as you are able—you are looking for a job in an ever diminishing number of unskilled jobs. That is why the common youth allowance, to be introduced by us next year, is so vital to young Australians. It may have been okay 20 years ago when there were a lot of unskilled entry‐level jobs, or maybe 15 years ago, but it is not okay now for a government to keep saying to young Australians, `Yes, you can leave school as early as you like. We know, if you do, you are going to make up a proportion of the long‐term unemployed. We know it is going to be harder for you to get a job, but we'll let you do it. Furthermore, we'll pay you to do it.' It is not acceptable for a government to keep doing that. That is why we have introduced the common youth allowance where we will be saying to people under 18, `If you haven't completed year 12, we aren't going to pay you an allowance or the dole to look for one of these every‐diminishing numbers of jobs.

The speech highlighted the different destinations of students leaving from government schools and from non‐government schools. Government schools do have a higher proportion of students who want to look for work, and that makes vocational training even more important. It is fair to say that the whole speech, in being reduced down to a couple of paragraphs to suit the editors, has sadly been misrepresented and has not given the impression of the whole speech. That is often the case. If you want to reduce a painting down to a small aspect and look at it under a microscope, you only see one part of it. The fundamental point of the speech was that schools which provide relevant workplace skills serve their students well.

Without being parochial, I took the opportunity to highlight Salisbury High in my state, and there are other schools that have an excellent record, a record which you could not beat, in providing students with what they need for the pathway that they choose.

Just in case you are in any doubt, if my speech or the reporting of it has, in any way, left any teacher in a government school in any doubt that their efforts are appreciated, then I very much regret that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you did—and I have read the speech—make the claim that private schools have virtually solved the unemployment problem. You did not attribute that to the wealth and social status that so many of your colleagues enjoyed in attending private education. Somehow you seem to put the blame onto public education for the lack of jobs available to young people in the country. Is not the problem the failure to create jobs for young people, not the education they receive at public schools? You seem to want to duck that issue.

—I am sorry this has been asked as a supplementary question because it does not give me much time. I cannot believe that someone on that side of the chamber has the nerve to raise the question about jobs for young Australians with their record in government.
—Oh, get out of it!

—I do not suppose you do like to hear it. What was youth unemployment under Labor? A record high, 34 per cent. You took it to a record high. As I indicated, you had better read the speech again. We have an excellent government school system, we have excellent non‐government schools and each of them has to cater for the needs of the students that they have. If one cohort of schools has more kids going into it who want to come out and go straight into entry‐level training, then of course vocational training is going to be more im portant for that sector. That is obviously the case.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer the minister to proposals to dam the Fitzroy River in my home state of Western Australia. I ask: will you, on behalf of the federal government, refuse to provide any permission, subsidy or support towards this poorly planned and ill‐advised scheme?

—I am not sure what permission would be sought. I am not sure what subsidy would be sought. I certainly am aware of the proposal. In fact, I wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry and Fisheries in Western Australia late last year to seek certain assurances that, in relation to the proposal, there would be full and proper environmental impact assessments and safeguards. I received a response from him to that effect. But, as far as I can see, there is no immediate basis for Commonwealth jurisdiction within the issue. The Western Australian government has stressed that this is at a very preliminary stage; that all assessments would be pursuant to its legislation, which gives public confidence and assurance; and that they understand the sensitivity of the issue and the right of the public to be satisfied not only of economic viability but also of ecological sustainability.

—As you are the Minister for the Environment for the whole of Australia, I ask you: have you received advice from your department on possible triggers for federal involvement and, if so, could you describe those triggers to the Senate? If those triggers exist, could you table the advice?

—I cannot recall any such advice. I do not immediately see the basis for a trigger. That is what I thought I said, in part, in my answer to your question. But I will go back and search the records to see if there is anything. What I have said to you—which I would have thought you would be pleased to hear—is that the Commonwealth is seeking assurances from the Western Australian government that there will be a full and proper assessment of all environmental consequences before any decision is made, and that I am pleased to inform the Senate that such assurances have been given.

—I address my question to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer to the social impact study undertaken in relation to the proposed Jabiluka Uranium Mine and released by Senator Hill on 20 August. Have you been provided with a copy of that study? Have you read it? If not, why not? If so, what conclusions do you draw from the study's findings in relation to the potential impact of uranium mining on Aboriginal people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reynolds for the question. As I understand it, the study has gone from Senator Hill to Senator Parer, and it is awaiting his decision. I have not seen it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator, given that it is a social impact study, has your office not contacted Senator Hill and Senator Parer to ensure that you are involved in the assessment and the process before any decision is taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I will check for you, Senator Reynolds, and find out if the office has done that. I would have expected that ATSIC would, but I will check for you and let you know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. It relates to honesty in government. I quote from a statement prepared by the Attorney‐General, which said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal Government has decided to ban x‐Rated videos and create a new category for non‐violent sexually explicit videos which will contain tighter guidelines in order to exclude demeaning material.

Is the minister aware that such material should already be excluded by law under the national classification code? Does this not mean that the responsible minister, namely the first law officer of the Crown, has failed to ensure that current X‐rated material conforms to the demeaning provisions of the national classification code and that, by this statement, he has misled the public since the establishment of a NVE category is clearly not necessary, as he says, `in order to exclude demeaning material'? The fact is that political will and honesty is. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the substance of the question really relates to the responsibility of the Attorney‐General. I think it would have been a very good first question for Senator Ellison. I am sure that, even though it was not asked of Senator Ellison, we will take back the substance of it to Mr Williams and get his response to it.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the cover for the question, the umbrella for the question, which really was honesty in government, yes, this was a decision that was made and announced many years ago on a difficult issue—a subject area that has upset many Australians in the past. We believe that the response that was reached was a proper and sensible response that would address the distress that this issue has caused many Australians in the past. I regret if the decision has not gone as far as to satisfy Senator Harradine, but I can say that it was reached after a lot of careful consideration and recognition of that concern that many Australians had expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I am sorry that I have to ask a supplementary question but I deliberately asked the question of the Minister representing the Prime Minister, that is to say, the leader of the government in the parliament. I am not going to the issue itself; I am going to the fundamental question as to whether the first law officer of the Crown should issue a statement which is demonstrably false. And under those circumstances I repeat the question: will the minister, if he cannot give the answer, take the matter to the Prime Minister and, if necessary, refer to the Prime Minister the discussion that took place in the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee supplementary estimates hearing last week.

—I have said that I would take it back to the Attorney-General but I will also take it back to the Prime Minister and ask that this matter be looked at. What I can assure Senator Harradine is that the first law officer in this instance would be one of the most honest and honourable people that I know. Therefore if there was any error, I can assure Senator Harradine it would have inadvertent.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given that the Prime Minister's code of conduct requires that `Ministers must not engage in any professional practice', how is it that, according to an answer I have just received to my question on notice No. 678, the Prime Minister has approved arrangements which allow the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to continue practising surgery? Minister, will you table for the benefit of the Senate a copy of those arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not think there was anything secret about this. This was an arrangement that was entered into early in the term of this government when it was recognised that Senator Herron, if he did not engage in a minimum surgical practice, would simply lose his capacity to perform that role in the future. And that would be an unjust situation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought, Senator, you would recognise that to be totally unjust. That was the arrangement which was reached at that time. As I understand it, it is no more than is necessary to enable Senator Herron to maintain these skills that are necessary for that task. I did not think there was any secret about it. But if there was a statement made at the time, I will search the records and bring it to the attention of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I referred the minister to an apparent discrepancy between the Prime Minister's code of conduct and the answer I received. I did ask you, Minister—and I will ask you again—if you will table a copy of those arrangements. I would also refer you to the fact that, in his answer to my question on notice, Senator Herron states, `I have incurred an operating loss during this period because of the cost of retaining rooms for such a limited practice.' Minister, I would also like you to assure the Senate that Senator Herron has not written off this loss against his personal income for taxation purposes.

—I used to be a tax lawyer and I could attempt to answer that, but I think Senator Herron's taxation arrangements are his own business. I really do not want to engage in that debate. If Senator Faulkner is seeking the arrangements that were entered into between the Prime Minister and Senator Herron, then I will seek a copy of those and provide him with a copy. But what he said is consistent with what I said. This was an arrangement to enable Senator Herron to maintain the basic skills of his profession, which is a reasonable application and interpretation of the code, the details of which I recall having in this Senate about 12 months ago when I thought the matter was topical. If Senator Faulkner has taken 12 months to catch up with the matter, I am sorry about that, but I have failed to continue to bring the brief. However, I will inquire further and see if I can help further.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Since the election the government has taken a number of steps to improve the lives of young Australians. In the same way that the government has acted to repair the natural environment for the benefit of all young Australians, can the minister outline how the government has acted to repair the budget to ensure that our young people do not face a future of high debt, high tax and high interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Payne for the very astute question. In the same way that we have acted to repair and protect the environment for young Australians, as Senator Hill knows, this government is committed to reducing government debt. We know and the Australian public knows that in recent times—Labor times—government debt simply got out of hand. Being in debt is always regrettable and was, in the case of Labor, simply indefensible in the extreme. It may have been different if there was a point to the debt that Labor created, but there does not seem to have been any point.

ANSWER.PARA: We need to remember Labor's history in this respect. Between 1991 and 1995, Commonwealth debt trebled from $32.6 billion to $97.3 billion. General net government debt reached $93 billion when we came into government, which was just over 19 per cent of GDP. Our government will reduce this to around 10 per cent of GDP by the turn of the century. The underlying budget deficit when we came to government was $10.3 billion and we will be in surplus by 1998-99.

In 1995-96, Labor spent $9 billion on the interest to pay their debts. In the year 2001, we will only have to spend just over $7 billion. That means a reduction of $2 billion per year in wasted expenditure paying interest on debt. To get an idea of how much we are talking about with the $2 billion that will no longer have to go on paying off debts: it is the amount we spend on both child care and VET each year; it is double the amount we spend on road grants each year; and it is about 40 per cent more than we spend on public hospitals each year—that is how much Labor was wasting compared with what we have been able to achieve by bringing the accounts back into order.

Most families spend their lives working and saving to give themselves and their families a strong foundation. They want to own their home. They want to be free from debt. They want to establish something to pass on to their children, and they want to see that their children have things a little easier than they, the parents, did. That is a very Australian attitude: doing something for the next generation, making things better for them. That is a very similar philosophy to the one that we are following in terms of bringing our finances in order.

As a result of our debt reduction strategy, our young people will not be faced with a crippling debt burden. Less debt means less pressure to increase the tax burden on Australia's young people. Less debt means lower interest rates. Lower interest rates mean that housing is more affordable for young people when they want to make that invest ment. Lower interest rates mean more investment and more jobs for today's young people tomorrow.

What we are doing to confront and solve the problem of government debt will mean that our young people will not have to bear the burden of the sort of profligate spending that went on under Labor, which was the hallmark of Mr Keating and Mr Beazley—Homer Simpson, if you like, asleep at the wheel—living for the polls of the day, not for the future.

Under Labor, Australia's young people faced high debt, high tax and a high interest rate future. Since our young people represent the future—and it is in them that our dreams and plans for the future will be realised—they will get the best start in life they can from this government, not the bankruptcy bomb that Mr Beazley would have dropped on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, given that the Office of National Assessments has now belatedly admitted sending their assessment of South Pacific leaders to DFAT on 4 July, I ask: in the light of DFAT's trenchant criticism of what was in the ONA report on South Pacific leaders, why wasn't the report withdrawn in the week before the South Pacific ministers meeting? Why didn't the foreign minister intervene to have the report withdrawn?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought this was done to death at the estimates hearings, but I will repeat what I said to Senator Cook on that occasion. I would think that the whole world listens to estimates but, just in case, it might be useful. This, of course, was intended to be held in a secure way. This document was marked confidential but, furthermore, included material that was marked AUSTEO. The minister received copies of it, and he had every right to anticipate that it would remain secure. Unfortunately, a breach of security occurred, and that is the error that needs to be remedied for the future so that this does not recur.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook told us during the estimates that, in fact, he had seen material like this when he was minister. So it seems that it is not unusual in substance. Therefore, I would have thought that he would be surprised if any of the ministers who received a copy in an overall briefing document thought that they should ask that it be removed. So the answer basically is that it was intended to be a secure document, and Mr Downer had every right to expect that it would be kept secure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I will take you up on your quotes of what I said later, Minister. But why didn't the foreign minister, Mr Alexander Downer, or the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade contact ONA or the Treasury indicating that the biographies supplied were offensive and of potential diplomatic embarrassment and request that they be withdrawn? Why didn't that happen?

—If the document had have been kept secure, as the foreign minister had the right to expect, nobody would have been embarrassed. That is the point. That is the point that Senator Cook misses. The answer therefore is, as I said in answer to the first question, that Mr Downer had every right to expect that this document would embarrass nobody.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I refer you to cabinet's decision last week not to provide the necessary support to allow the ACT heroin trial to go ahead. I ask: having effectively put an end to this trial, will the government now examine any other options to address the problem of heroin addiction? Will the government now proceed, for example, with a national summit on drug abuse and/or will you be directing any additional funds into other drug rehabilitation programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lees for the question, because it is a very serious matter in relation to heroin addiction in this nation and, in fact, the whole of the world. It is a scourge.

ANSWER.PARA: As you know, the minister and the cabinet determined that they would not support the trial in the ACT for various reasons. But there is continuing investigation going on into trials all over the world in relation to heroin addiction. At the ministerial council on drug strategy meeting on 31 July, ministers agreed, in consultation with key stakeholders, to a national drug strategic framework document to the year 2002 and a revised advisory infrastructure to support work under the national drug strategic framework. Ministers emphasised the importance of ensuring that the revised infrastructure allows for an enhanced role for experts, practitioners, the non‐government sector and consumer groups.

In contrast to a one‐off national summit, the revised advisory infrastructure will provide ongoing opportunities for people outside of government to have input into the development of policies and programs to address drug‐related harm. They also agreed to hold an extraordinary conference of health and law enforcement ministers in November to review the national drug strategic framework. States and territories, including New South Wales, agreed to conduct consultations with key stakeholders and individual experts to allow them to provide expert and community input to the November meeting.

The National Drug Strategy Committee executive will be meeting on 28 August to identify appropriate and broad‐ranging consultation processes to be undertaken in the development of a national drug strategic framework. It is anticipated that these consultations will provide opportunities for a wide range of organisations and individuals to have input into the development of future directions under the national drug strategy. This breadth of consultation would not be possible with a national drug summit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I am aware that some of the states are now tackling this issue in a variety of ways, but what specifically is the Commonwealth now going to do in particular to support those people, particularly young people and their families, where heroin addiction is already a problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth has an overriding responsibility. I think the message that we have sent in relation to the restriction on the trial in the ACT is a clear demonstration that the government believes that a trial of that nature will not succeed in developing a clear strategy to solve this problem. What we are doing is facilitating this meeting of the national drug strategy group so that further consultation can occur.

—My question is also to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services and also relates to the proposed heroin trial, subsequently ruled out by the Prime Minister and the cabinet. Minister, is it a fact that Dr Wooldridge spoke directly to the Prime Minister prior to his backing of the heroin trial at the meeting of state and territory health ministers in Cairns on 31 July? Is it also a fact that Dr Wooldridge discussed the heroin trial with Mr Grahame Morris, chief political adviser to the Prime Minister, prior to the health ministers meeting? What view of the trial did the Prime Minister communicate to the Minister for Health and Family Services, either directly or through his chief political adviser, Mr Morris? Given the Prime Minister's stated opposition to the plan, why did Dr Wooldridge so badly mislead the meeting of state and territory health ministers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Forshaw canvassed this matter during a Senate estimates committee hearing. It was made clear to him then—
—We're here now; not there.

—You were not there, Senator Ray. Seeing that you are listening, I thought you might like to know what went on at the Senate estimates. You are the one who is always bringing up Senate estimates committees. Any debate within the cabinet, as you know, is not subject to discussion outside of cabinet. I am certainly not aware, as I said—

—On a point of order, Madam President: Senator Herron is now proceeding to give precisely the same answers that he gave at the Senate estimates in order to avoid the question. At no stage during the question was cabinet mentioned. Rather, the question specifically related to what direction was given by the Prime Minister or his chief adviser, Mr Morris, to Dr Wooldridge. There was absolutely nothing at all in the question about what may have been discussed in cabinet.
—Senator Herron, I draw your attention to the question and invite you to answer it.
—Within that question also was the question as to whether Dr Wooldridge had given in principle support for the trial. Correct?
—He did!

—It was the preface to that part of the question that I was giving the answer to when I was discussing it with you. So, Senator, I suggest you wait until you hear the answer before you jump up with spurious points of order.

ANSWER.PARA: The ministerial council met and agreement was reached that the trial would proceed on the basis only that Australia meets its international treaty obligations under the United Nations Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs 1972 and the 1988 Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, and that it is formally put to the International Narcotics Control Board and the Commission on Narcotic Drugs and is not opposed by the board or by a majority of the members of the commission.

They were the caveats that I mentioned. If you recall, during the estimates committee, they were the caveats that Dr Wooldridge put at that ministerial council meeting. That is the usual way for ministerial councils to operate: ministers give in principle support subject to the resolution of matters, sometimes it is significant detail being sorted out. At no stage did the Minister for Health and Family Services indicate at the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy meeting that the Prime Minister had given his permission for the trial to proceed. That was the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he discuss it with Mr Morris?
—Also in the question of Senator Forshaw was whether Dr Wooldridge discussed it with Mr Morris. I have no idea whether he discussed it with Mr Morris. I will certainly ask that question of him.

BREAK.PARA: I would expect that he would have. Mr Morris is the principal adviser and controller of the Prime Minister's office. One would assume—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Prime Minister!

—If I need to let that office know, I certainly get in touch with him. That is important. We are in the game of politics, Senator Forshaw, and politics demands you let the office know what is going on in the portfolio. I will certainly ask the minister for an answer to your question and forward it to you in due course.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is nice to know that you are in the game of politics, Minister. I would have thought that a majority of health ministers making a decision on this important issue was something a little bit more important than the game of politics. Minister, isn't it the case that the trial would never have proceeded without the cooperation of the Commonwealth and that state and territory health ministers and all those who supported the trial were simply led up the garden path by Dr Wooldridge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a peculiar statement to make. To imply that the state health ministers would be led up a garden path by anyone is a reflection on the ability of the state health ministers. I think you should apologise to them that anybody should have that sway over them.

ANSWER.PARA: I know in the Labor Party that they would get their arms twisted up behind their backs to follow on. At least on our side of politics it is a matter of persuasion and discussion in an attempt to achieve the best outcome.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can hear the laughter on the other side of the chamber because that is not how they operate. It is all kneecapping over there. Certainly there probably was discussion.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. I note that the fifth reduction in interest rates since the coalition government came to office occurred during the parliamentary recess. What are the benefits of this rate cut for Australian families, for businesses and for the economy in general?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm what was stated by my colleague Senator Gibson about further cuts in interest rates. It has to be said that we are a low interest rate government, and that is in striking contrast to the practice of the Labor Party in its 13 years in office. When the Howard government came into office, home mortgage rates were around 10 per cent and rates available to small businesses were over 10 per cent. This government is particularly proud that we have been able to provide sustained interest rate relief. There have been five cuts in official interest rates.
—What about retirees?

—Official interest rates have fallen by 2.5 per cent, or almost a third, Senator Sherry. This will fascinate you, Senator Sherry: home mortgage rates have fallen by almost four per cent and are lower than they have been at any time since the late 1960s. Not surprisingly, this has led to housing affordability being at record levels, which is very good news for the economy and very good news for home buyers. Indeed, the Commonwealth Bank‐HIA housing affordability index shows housing affordability to be higher than it has been at any time since December 1984. Under Labor, the dream of home ownership was getting more and more out of reach of more and more Australians. We can even recall—Senator Sherry can correct me if I am wrong—that, at one stage under the Labor government, home loan interest rates soared to over 15 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The gains from the fall in interest rates are truly dramatic. For example, on a $100,000 loan, a family's interest bill has been cut by as much as $317 a month or, in terms of a year, over $3,800 a year, since this government came to office. These interest rate cuts are flowing through to help businesses—big and small—and the economy more generally. The Labor Party used interest rates to put a brake on the economy. That is why, under the former government, the interest rate levels rose so high. I cannot recall one of the former Keating ministers ever complaining about the very high levels of interest rates which occurred during their time in government. It is no surprise that the Labor Party are regarded by the public as being a high interest rate party; they followed high interest rate policies. By contrast, we are a government that believes in low interest rates. In our first period in office we have been able to deliver comprehensively for families and business in helping to cut the level of interest rates. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the publication of a document concerning South Pacific ministers.

This document is a confidential document. It bears the legend AUSTEO, which means `for Australian eyes only'. It is the highest classification of a security document that we know of in terms of Australian national security. The national disgrace about this document is that it was left on a table in a hotel in Cairns, and all the media got access to it and all the representatives of 13 nations in the South Pacific got access to it and read the very unflattering biographies about them that someone had included in this document. These biographies were not about their policies; these biographies were about their personal habits, tastes and likes and dislikes. Of leaders in the South Pacific, things were said such as, `He likes a drink,' or `He is drinking too much these days,' or `He is an opportunist,' and so on it goes—the sort of gossipy backgrounding that would only occur in the front bar of a hotel somewhere, encoded in an official document for Australian eyes only.

It is a national embarrassment to Australia that this document was compiled in the first place, but it is an even greater national embarrassment that, in a cavalier way, this document found its way into public circulation and into the media. Because it did, many heads of state referred to in this document have launched considerable criticism against Australia. And, because it did, other nations that pride themselves on being secure about national secrets asked the question of Australia, `Why is it that your security is so lax that documents of this character can be freely made available to the media and create an international incident that embarrasses this nation?'

They are the facts that are behind the question I asked Senator Hill today. My question to Senator Hill was: why did the foreign minister of Australia, Alexander Downer, do nothing to curtail or prevent the circulation of this document? Or why did Alexander Downer, the foreign minister of Australia, the minister responsible, do nothing to advise the other ministers or ONA—the agency that compiled this document—that the type of material contained in it was material that should not have found its way into an official briefing and that should not have found its way, as it did, into the public arena on this occasion?

We do know this from the evidence that has been given at estimates committee hearings: the Department of the Treasury requested that this document be compiled. We do know this: officers of the Department of the Treasury have had their salaries reduced, their performance pay cancelled, because of their role in the compilation of this document.

This nation has been internationally embarrassed by injudicious and indiscreet behaviour in a matter of national security and two public servants have taken the fall. The issue is though that the buck stops with the government and the buck actually stops with the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It is his job to advise the government on whether or not material contained in documents like this is fair, whether material contained in documents like this ought to be circulated and whether material contained in documents like this ought to have greater security protection than apparently this one had.

Treasury and not the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade asked for it. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade knew about it. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade sat in on the interdepartmental committee that compiled it. The minister had this document in his private possession at last three days before the conference. What action did he take to protect Australia's international interests? What action did the Minister for Foreign Affairs take to advise other ministers not to pay attention to the indiscreet references in this document? What action did the Minister for Foreign Affairs take to reassure foreign governments in advance that Australia was not prying into their private lives and using their private activities as background to be used against them in negotiations?

The answer to those questions is that he did not take any action at all. He did nothing. He was asleep at the wheel. He did not care or did not bother. He let the thing ride. The answers to the questions given by the minister today to fob this off, to allow the Public Service to take the wrap and for the buck not to stop with the minister, are a disgrace. I think that that ought to be condemned by the Senate. We have never had a security breach that has affected 13 countries at the one time in the way this did. The minister who is absent does not take responsibility. Responsibility should be demanded of him. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have, of course, is a very sad series of events because over the years Mr Tony Street, Mr Andrew Peacock, Mr Bill Hayden and then Senator Gareth Evans put in enormous efforts to build relations through the south-west Pacific. It was always a strange relationship with Australia being a large country and the rest being so small. Those countries looked to Australia for a leadership position on a whole range of economic and environmental issues and indeed in relation to nuclear testing in the south‐west Pacific. Whenever you hold a leadership position there is always some resentment. That resentment will now boil over to a point where repairing the damaged relations with the countries in our region is probably going to take half a decade to properly restore.

SPEECH.PARA: You really do wonder how this series of events could have occurred. After all, the briefing notes were not that important. They were so unimportant that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) did not bother to read them until just before the meeting. For all the committee meetings to develop the briefings, for all the effort put in, this Treasurer of ours barely, according to the evidence in Treasury estimates, glanced at this briefing until the night before or the morning of the meeting.

The question comes up: what happened subsequently? I think it was quite appropriate for the Inspector‐General to investigate the security breach and make recommendations and for discipline to be taken in Treasury. But that is only half the tale.

What happened immediately after the publication in newspapers was a classic example of government departmental positioning as they each tried to slide out. I have to say that Treasury had nowhere to go. It did not take Foreign Affairs long to start their backgrounding machine, pot shotting at Treasury and the Office of National Assessments—none of which was ever directly sourced; it was always, `A spokesman in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said.' The whole foreign affairs department machine got going. It shifted all the blame on to ONA and Treasury and opted out.

After all, the original conception of this meeting did not necessarily include Foreign Affairs officials or even the foreign minister. It was only over some months that they edged themselves into the conference saying that they desperately wanted to be there and it should not be just left to Treasury and Treasurers. Having shoehorned their way in, they should have adopted some sense of responsibility in the process.

BREAK.PARA: The original answer given to us by ONA at the estimates committee—and Senator Hill complained that this was raised again today when it was raised in estimates—was that the biographical details were not sent to Foreign Affairs, not sent to AusAID and not sent to PM&C. Late last week we got a letter, `Oops, sorry, we are wrong about that. They were forwarded to those three agencies on 4 July.' That is some 11 days before the meeting was to take place in Cairns. The significance of that is that those two senior departments—Foreign Affairs and Trade and PM&C—had the content of those briefs 11 days before the meeting and did nothing with them.

Senator Hill said, `Why should they? They are supposed to be held securely.' They were not and therein lies the problem. I would have thought some responsibility exists in those two senior departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Prime Minister and Cabinet to look at the content and understand that there could be a leaking or the material could go astray and what the potential embarrassment would be for this country.

Not only did they not say to Treasury, `Hold on fellas. This material is a bit red hot because it has all sorts of irrelevant scuttlebutt in it,' they did not even contact Treasury to ask, `What sort of security are you applying to these documents?' Surely the most inexperienced Foreign Affairs official should know that if the outer document has `Confidential' on it and pages within the document have `AUSTEO', for Australian eyes only, that particular appellation should have been at the very front of the document.

They picked nothing up. They are too busy positioning themselves, looking to the preening interests of their ministers and how they position them to look at the substance of the background briefing and the potential damage it could do. It is not good enough for Senator Hill to come in here today and say, `It does not really matter what is in a document. If the security is right there will never be a problem.' You always have to assume the worst. You always have to assume, either by accident or some other method, that this material may find itself in the public domain. Senator Hill finally said that this sort of thing hap pened under the Labor government. It did not happen in the briefings I got or any other briefings I saw. You would have drawn attention to this sort of scuttlebutt and disciplined the officers for it. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At the request of Senator Gibson, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Joint Committee of Public Accounts be authorised to hold a public hearing during the sitting of the Senate today from 4.30 p.m. till 6 p.m. to take evidence from Dr Peter Shergold for the committee's inquiry into the Public Service Bill 1997 and a related bill.

In moving this motion on behalf of Senator Gibson, I indicate to the Senate that the committee held public hearings on this inquiry on 6 and 7 August 1997, but the subordinate legislation which is a vital component of the legislative package was not available at that time. The committee has now determined that it needs to hold further public hearings, some of which may need to be held during sitting times, if it is to meet the current reporting deadline of 4 September 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the motion moved by Senator Calvert, the opposition has no difficulty with the motion that is before the chair. I would ask if Senator Calvert would consider, by leave, also including after the words `Dr Peter Shergold' the words `and any other witness'. I did understand the committee might receive a request from other witnesses. I was a little worried about the form of the motion moved by Senator Calvert, that it might in fact limit that occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, I think there is a suggestion—events may have overtaken this; I know not—that Sir Lenox Hewitt again might give evidence to the committee briefly this afternoon. If Senator Calvert would be willing to include those words by leave, I think we can at least cover that eventuality if it arises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend the motion to insert after `Dr Peter Shergold' `and any other witness'. I thank the Leader of the Opposition for giving me the opportunity to insert, by leave, those words.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I also wish to highly commend the efforts and sacrifices of rescuers and support teams in the extremely delicate and difficult operations following the landslide.
