DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rt Hon. Sir Garfield Edward John Barwick AK, GCMG

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Sunday, 13 July 1997 of the Rt Hon. Sir Garfield Edward John Barwick, AK, GCMG, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Parramatta from 1958 to 1964, Attorney-General from 1958 to 1964, Minister for External Affairs from 1961 to 1964 and Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia from 1964 to 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on Sunday, 13 July 1997, of the Rt Hon. Sir Garfield Edward John Barwick, AK, GCMG, Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia from 1964 to 1981; Member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Parramatta, New South Wales, from 1958 to 1964; Minister for External Affairs from 1961 to 1964; and Commonwealth Attorney‐General from 1958 to 1964; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service; and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Garfield Edward John Barwick was born on 22 June 1903 at Stanmore, New South Wales. He was educated at Fort Street Boys High School and Sydney University, where he won the university medal for law and the Dalley Prize. Before entering federal politics, Sir Garfield had already established a distinguished career as a pre‐eminent advocate and an undisputed leader of the New South Wales Bar.

In 1927, he was appointed King's Counsel. In 1941, he practised extensively in all jurisdictions, appearing before the Supreme Court, the High Court and the Privy Council. Through a string of cases before the High Court in the 1940s, most notably the airways case and the bank nationalisation case, Sir Garfield successfully championed the rights of private enterprise against the state. During his career at the bar, Sir Garfield was President of the New South Wales Bar Association from 1950 to 1952 and from 1955 to 1956 and President of the Law Council of Australia from 1952 to 1954.

He was a member of the House of Representatives from 1958. In that year, he won the New South Wales seat of Parramatta for the Liberal Party. In his maiden speech in the House, Sir Garfield spoke of the need for Australia to work for its wealth and to have workplace cooperation between employees and management to `wrest from a very great country a very great future'. He spoke of the need to curb inflation and to attract overseas investment and the importance of maintaining a balance between our imports and our exports. These are, of course, issues which remain pertinent today.

Sir Garfield ably served the Menzies government as Attorney-General and as external affairs minister. It is a testament to his immense ability that he held these two key portfolios concurrently for more than two years. His reformist reputation during these years is perhaps best reflected in his tenure as Attorney-General when he pioneered national legislation in the areas of matrimony and trade practices.

In 1964, Sir Garfield left federal politics to become the longest serving Chief Justice of the High Court. His chief justiceship saw many significant changes: the location of the seat of the High Court in Canberra, the completion of the High Court building, the abolition of appeals to the Privy Council from all Australian courts so far as federal jurisdictions and the decision of the High Court are concerned and the divesting of less important matters from the High Court's jurisdiction to allow it to concentrate on its role as the final court on all Australian constitutional issues and the final court of appeal in Australia.

Sir Garfield's immense contribution to public service knew no boundaries. He was Chancellor of Macquarie University from 1967 to 1968 and was President of the Australian Institute of International Affairs from 1972 to 1973. He maintained a deep attachment to conserving Australia's natural wealth by serving as a trustee of the Kosciuszko State Park for 20 years and as President of the Australian Conservation Foundation for five years. His compassion for his fellow Australians was evidenced by his service as Patron of the Australian National Council for the Blind and President of the Royal New South Wales Institute for Deaf and Blind Children.

In reflecting on the remarkable achievements of this fine Australian, it is difficult to reconcile or comprehend the sustained and vicious attacks that he had to endure for the advice he provided to the late Sir John Kerr in November 1975. It is a matter of regret that Sir Garfield's death has been used by some as an opportunity to renew these attacks. I would hope that today's motion would allow senators from all sides of Australian politics to reflect upon and rightly acknowledge a remarkable lifetime of achievement and service to Australia and its people.

The high regard in which Sir Garfield was held is recognised by the many honours he received throughout his life. He was created a Knight Bachelor in 1953 in recognition of his distinguished services to the knowledge and practice of the law and the administration of justice. In 1965, he was appointed a Knight Grand Cross of the Order of St Michael and St George. In 1981, he was appointed a Knight in the General Division of the Order of Australia for service to Australia in parliament, government and the law.

In his passing, Australia has lost a truly talented and erudite man whose tremendous contribution to our nation was all the more remarkable by its breadth as well as its depth. On behalf of the government, I extend to his wife, Lady Norma Barwick, his son, Ross, and his daughter, Diane, and their families our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I wish to support the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) on the death of Sir Garfield Barwick. Sir Garfield Barwick was a person of substance who had a significant impact on Australian public life for over three decades—first, as an outstanding advocate, then as Attorney-General of Australia and Minister for External Affairs and, finally, as chief justice.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Garfield won a scholarship to Sydney University, studying arts and then law before entering the New South Wales Bar in 1926. He practised extensively in all jurisdictions of the Supreme Court, the High Court and the Privy Council and, in 1941, was made a King's Counsel.

He was elected to the House of Representatives for the seat of Parramatta in the state of New South Wales at a by-election in March 1958 and, of course, held that seat until he retired from the parliament in 1964. During what was a comparatively short parliamentary career, he held two key portfolios. He was the Attorney-General and, in 1961, was given the additional portfolio of external affairs. He held both those positions until 1964. He retired from the parliament in 1964 and was appointed by Prime Minister Menzies as Chief Justice of the High Court on the same day. He served in that position from 1964 to 1981 to become Australia's longest serving chief justice.

Sir Garfield Barwick's name will be found on many of the pages of Australia's political and legal history. His extensive contribution as a senior conservative figure for so long was all the more remarkable because he came from a less than privileged background. But, whatever the achievements of Sir Garfield Barwick in these fields, within the Australian Labor Party his memory will always be associated with his role as chief justice in confirming Governor-General Kerr's decision to dismiss the Whitlam government in 1975.
On his death, as acting Leader of the Opposition, I recalled in a public statement that his biographer, David Marr, has written of Sir Garfield's role in proffering advice to Sir John Kerr that:
At the moment that called for the wisdom and restraint of a great judge, Barwick acted as an advocate.

With Sir Garfield Barwick's passing the opposition notes his contribution to national affairs—as I have said, a very significant contribution—and we do express our condolences to his family and his friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the leader of the government, Senator Hill. We were all saddened to learn of Sir Garfield Barwick's passing at the age of 94 during the winter recess, on 13 July.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Garfield Barwick was one of the most eminent political and judicial figures in Australia in the last half century. His contribution to Australian public life spanned many years and the list of his achievements is very long. Sir Garfield Barwick was born in 1903 to a middle class Methodist family. It was during these years that he learned the value of hard work and high standards. It is often quoted that his mother was his inspiration, urging him to make something of himself.

He won a scholarship to study arts and then law at the Sydney University where he won the 1926 university medal for law and the Dalley prize. Sir Garfield Barwick practised extensively in all jurisdictions: the state Supreme Court, the High Court and the Privy Council. During his time at the bar Sir Garfield was involved in prominent cases including a highly praised appearance before the Privy Council in the bank nationalisation case, and in litigation following the controversial awarding of the Archibald Prize to Sir William Dobell for his painting of Joshua Smith. In 1941 he was appointed a KC and from 1950 to 1952, and from 1955 to 1956, he served as President of the New South Wales Bar Association and was a member of the Law Council of Australia from 1952 to 1954.

In 1958, Sir Garfield Barwick stood for the New South Wales seat of Parramatta and was elected to the Menzies government. Sir Garfield became Attorney‐General in 1959 and Minister for External Affairs in 1961, holding both portfolios until 1964. During his term he led delegations to the United Nations in 1960 and 1964 and retained his interest in international affairs when, in 1972, he became President of the Australian Institute of International Affairs.

In 1964 Sir Garfield returned to law, taking up the appointment of Chief Justice of the High Court and remaining there for a record period of some 17 years. In 1975, as Chief Justice, Sir Garfield was to become part of events surrounding the dismissal of the Whitlam government. Following advice given to the Governor‐General, Sir John Kerr, Sir Garfield Barwick etched a permanent place for himself in the history surrounding this event.

Sir Garfield Barwick was said to be a good companion with a dry sense of humour. In his spare time he enjoyed gardening, fishing and sailing. He sailed his sloop Anitra V in 12 Sydney to Hobart races, winning the race in 1957. In later years Sir Garfield Barwick became patron of the Australian National Council for the Blind. He was knighted in 1953, appointed a KCMG in 1965 and a Knight of the Order of Australia in 1981.
We all mourn the loss of such an outstanding Australian and on behalf of the National Party in the Senate I extend our deepest sympathy to Sir Garfield's widow and the Barwick family and friends.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Wednesday, 6 August 1997, of Lance Herbert Barnard AO, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Bass from 1954 to 1975, Deputy Prime Minister from 1972 to 1975, the holder of various ministries in December 1972, Minister for Defence from 1972 to 1975, and Minister for the Navy, the Army, Air and Supply from 1972 to 1973.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on Wednesday, 6 August 1997, of the Honourable Lance Herbert Barnard AO, Member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Bass, Tasmania, from 1954 to 1975; Deputy Prime Minister from 1972 to 1974; Minister for Defence from 1972 to 1975; Minister for the Navy, the Army, Air and Supply from 1972 to 1973; Postmaster‐General and Minister for Labour and National Service, Immigration, the Interior, Primary Industry, Repatriation, Health, National Development and Social Services in December 1972; and Ambassador of Australia to Sweden, Norway and Finland from 1975 to 1978; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Lance Herbert Barnard was born on 1 May 1919 at Launceston, Tasmania. He came from a working class background and, like many others at the time, he had to leave school during the depression. He ended up working in a timber yard for two years, went back to night school, and started training as a teacher. During World War II, Lance Barnard enlisted with the 2nd Australian Imperial Force and served in the Middle East from 1940 to 1943 where he sustained permanent disabilities in his eyesight as well as his hearing in the Battle of El Alamein. After his discharge from military service in 1945, he went on to become a school teacher.

BREAK.PARA: In 1954 he was elected to the House of Representatives in the seat of Bass, following in the footsteps of his father, Claude, who had held the seat for the ALP for 15 years. His maiden speech in the House was characterised by his concern over a diversity of issues, ranging from social issues, such as housing and the impact of high interest rates on home ownership, to issues affecting the prosperity of his home state of Tasmania, to national issues such as the need for a progressive immigration policy.

In 1967 Lance Barnard became the Deputy Parliamentary Leader of the Labor Party and went on to become Deputy Prime Minister to Gough Whitlam in 1972. For an unprecedented period of two weeks, he and Gough Whitlam conducted a two‐man government which saw Mr Barnard holding 14 ministries and taking a series of major decisions.

He remained as Deputy Prime Minister in the Whitlam ministry until 1974. He was also Minister for Defence until 1975 and, as I said, was minister for the portfolios of Navy, Army, Air and Supply until 1973. His period as Minister for Defence saw many significant initiatives, most notably the amalgamation of the three service departments and the supply department into one expanded defence department, and the decision to establish the Australian Defence Force Academy.

During his 21 years in this parliament he contributed extensively to the work of a range of parliamentary committees, including Standing Orders, Public Accounts, Foreign Affairs and, not surprisingly, the Joint Committee on Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Legislation.

He left federal politics in 1975 to become Australia's Ambassador to Sweden, Norway and Finland. In 1979, in recognition of his service to politics and government, Lance Barnard was appointed an Officer in the General Division of the Order of Australia.

He will be remembered as a quiet, unassuming man—a quite achiever whose unswerving loyalty and personal integrity earned him the respect of all those who knew him. On behalf of the government I extend to his wife, Jill, his daughters, Tricia, Suzanne and Jacqueline, his son, Nicholas, and their fami lies, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Labor opposition I wish to support the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate on the death of the Hon. Lance Barnard, former Labor Deputy Prime Minister. Labor senators express our deep sorrow at the death of Lance Barnard, and we offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Jill, and to his family.

SPEECH.PARA: As Deputy Leader and representative of Tasmania in the Senate it is appropriate that I make a contribution to the condolence motion on the death of the former member for Bass and Tasmanian member of federal parliament. In addition to that, I knew Lance very well personally for a long time.

Lance was born in Launceston in Tasmania in 1919. He came from a working‐class background. He undertook a variety of occupations in the very difficult years of the Great Depression, including, as Senator Hill has mentioned, being a timber worker for some time.

He commenced study to be a teacher, but those studies were interrupted with the outbreak of World War II. Lance enlisted in the 2nd AIF in 1940 and served in the Middle East until 1943. At the battle of El Alamein his eyesight was partially affected as a consequence of some wounds he received and he was also partially deafened. This was while he was serving as an artillery officer. I understand also that one of his brothers died during that battle and another brother was seriously wounded. Lance himself was twice wounded during that battle.

After the war ended Lance became an active member in the Australian Labor Party. At the same time he finished his training to become a teacher. In 1954 he won the seat of Bass and held it until he resigned in 1975. The seat of Bass had previously been held by his father, Claude, who had been a minister in the Chifley government. There followed a very long and distinguished parliamentary career.

BREAK.PARA: Lance Barnard became Deputy Leader of the Labor Party in 1967. He served as Gough Whitlam's deputy—a very loyal deputy—in opposition and in government. I understand that there would have been opportunities for Lance to have become Leader of the Australian Labor Party if he had so wished.

When Labor was elected to government in 1972, the Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, and Lance shared 27 ministries between them. Lance held 14, while the then Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, held just 13, until the ministery was sworn in some three weeks later. During this period some 40 major decisions were taken together by Lance Barnard as Deputy Prime Minister and Gough Whitlam as Prime Minister.

Over thirty years after enlisting in the AIF, one of Lance's 14 ministerial responsibilities was the defence portfolio. Within 72 hours of becoming defence minister, he had ended conscription and he had Australian troops brought back from Vietnam. Lance was to retain the Deputy Prime Minister and defence minister positions. He was Deputy Prime Minister from 1972 to 1974 and Minister for Defence from 1972 to 1975. As Senator Hill, the government leader, has noted, one of his major achievements as Minister for Defence was the amalgamation of various defence departments and the establishment of the Defence Force Academy.

Lance Barnard resigned from parliament in 1975 to become Australia's Ambassador to Sweden. This decision was to signal the beginning of the end of the Whitlam government. Lance's seat of Bass was won by the Liberals with a very significant swing. The rest of course is history.

Another scenario could have taken place. In 1973 Gough Whitlam had wanted to appoint Lance Barnard as Governor-General when the then Governor‐General, Paul Hasluck, decided not to serve another term. I think it is typical of the man and his modesty that Lance believed that our Governor-General should have a legal background, and he obviously subsequently rejected being considered for that position.

Lance not only played a key role in the Whitlam government but was one of the architects behind the formulation of Labor policies throughout that period which led to Labor's election to power in 1972.

I first met Lance Barnard at a Labor conference in 1971. There were a number of characteristics that immediately struck one about Lance. He was a person of very great integrity of character; he was exceptionally honest; he was a very solid individual; and he was exceptionally loyal. In fact, when reflecting on the numerous times I discussed politics with Lance, I can recall that one of the man's enduring characteristics was that on no occasion did he make a vindictive or even a critical comment about any of the persons he served with in politics.

One of Lance's most impressive characteristics following his return from overseas when he had been Australian Ambassador to Sweden was that he continued to serve the community by working very hard on its behalf. At that time I had personal contact with Lance in two areas. Firstly, he carried out a great deal of work on behalf of group training schemes in Tasmania. Indeed, right up until his death he continued to make that active contribution. Often he was here in Canberra putting forward submissions and presenting arguments on behalf of those group training schemes.

His second area of service upon his return from Sweden involved continuing to act as an advocate for returned service men and women. Again, I recall the enormous hard work, dedication and tribunal representations that he made on behalf of returned service men and women, not least my own mother who had an issue requiring representation regarding my father who had been a merchant seaman during the war. I might say that Lance represented the issue successfully on that occasion.

Lance continued to work in a number of other areas, particularly for Launceston, the city where he was born and grew up. He made a very active contribution to local community life, as well as on behalf of men and women throughout Tasmania.

With the passing of Lance, certainly in a Tasmanian context, there ends an era. He was a very important contributor not just to the national political scene but to the Tasmanian Labor Party, from World War II right through until very recent times. When reflecting on the 50 years since the war, I cannot recall a single individual who has made such a significant contribution at both state and national levels to the Australian Labor Party.

Lance's passing, as I said earlier, signifies the end of a very important postwar era for the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania. It is a death that I know my colleagues, members of the Tasmanian branch of the Australian Labor Party, my mother, other members of my family and myself, all feel very deeply about.

In concluding my remarks, once again I express my condolences to his wife Jill, to his family and to his friends. When I look back and reflect on Lance's career, I think if any of us can leave federal politics having made the sort of contribution that Lance Barnard has made—as a minister and to the parliament in general through the many and varied committee positions he held—at the same time maintaining the same level of integrity to politics, I think we will have done well indeed.
With his death, unfortunately, comes the end of an era. It is a very sad time and, reflecting on that, once again may I express my heartfelt condolences to his wife Jill, his family and his friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the members of the National Party with the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) for the Hon. Lance Barnard, AO. I share the sympathy that will be expressed by my colleague Senator Harradine and that has been expressed by members of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Lance was an icon in the movement. He passed away during the winter recess. I wish to extend my sympathy to his family and many friends.

Lance Barnard was elected to the parliament in 1954 in the seat of Bass which was previously held by his father. In his first speech, he affirmed his commitment to social justice, education, housing and repatriation which he worked for tirelessly during his time in parliament. He will be well remembered for holding 14 portfolios after the ALP election win in 1972. The then Prime Minister held the other 13.

Lance Barnard was born in Launceston in 1919. He left school during the Depression and went to work stacking wood in a timber yard. He enlisted in the 2nd AIF in 1940 and served in the Middle East. After the war he became a teacher in Queenstown until, in 1944, he nominated for and was elected to his father's former seat, and he was then re‐elected until 1974.

His family's connection to politics was widened when he married the daughter of a former Western Australian Labor senator, Harry Cant. Lance Barnard was known for his quiet political shrewdness and loyalty to his leader, Gough Whitlam. He served as Minister for Defence from 1972 to 1975 and was instrumental in the ending of conscription and in the return of troops to Australia.

As Deputy Prime Minister, Australia was governed by the distinct contrast of a quietly and deliberately spoken man beside his outspoken leader, Gough Whitlam. Lance Barnard retired in 1975, six months before the Whitlam government fell. After retiring from parliament, he became the Ambassador to Sweden, Norway and Finland.

Lance Barnard served the people of Tasmania and Australia well for many years and he will be sadly missed. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending sympathy to his wife Jill and to their four children and many friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill, seconded by Senator Sherry and supported by Senator Boswell, the Leader of the National Party in this chamber. I do not intend to go over the matters which my colleagues have already mentioned. I think they have dealt with all the areas. Senator Sherry, in particular, has enlightened the Senate as to the work of Lance Barnard since he returned from his ambassadorial posting, I think in 1978. I had the privilege, as did a number of you, of attending the funeral for Lance in Launceston. There were a huge number of people present. That indicated to me that people from all walks of life felt a deep loss at the passing of Lance Barnard. He was a man of the people and a thorough gentleman.

SPEECH.PARA: He was a very good member for Bass and served the people to great effect. Despite the high office and the heavy burden that that office meant for him, he never turned people away. He had a deep and abiding sense of social justice—he would talk of the need for a fair go.

Of course, the Barnard family had been in politics for some time. Claude Barnard, as has been said, was a member for Bass. I was speaking to one of my strong supporters in Launceston who remembered as a boy being told by his father of an incident in the 1930s when `a well‐known figure' was walking through a Launceston park and saw a fellow begging without shoes. He took his shoes off, gave them to him and walked home barefoot. That is the type of thing that the Barnards would do. Lance Barnard was similarly very generous. Incidentally, one of my staff member's parents first met at one of Claude Barnard's election night victory celebrations. So his father was a bit of a matchmaker as well.

On a personal basis, I will never forget the support that Lance Barnard gave me within the councils of the Labor Party during the 1960s and early 1970s. That was not easy to do—it is certainly not very easy to support me at the best of times and these were not politically good times. Lance Barnard recognised that federal Labor would never regain office whilst there was a public perception that the federal parliamentary Labor Party was dancing like a puppet to the tune of the 36 faceless men. I say that as a matter of historical record.

I would like to associate myself with the sympathy of other colleagues around this chamber and, indeed, the sympathy of so many people from all walks of life, in Tasmania and elsewhere in the Commonwealth. My sympathy goes to Jill, Tricia, Suzanne, Jacqueline and to Lance's son Nicholas, and also to his many friends on his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill for the Hon. Lance Barnard. My memories of Mr Barnard go back probably longer than many on his own side. In fact, my memories go back to when I was between the ages of six and nine when we lived in Helen Street in Launceston, straight over the road. His eldest daughter Tricia was a very dear friend of mine in Launceston and I have very fond memories of Mr Barnard and the exact—
—They didn't know what would happen.

—I will come to that because it is a very interesting interjection. I have very fond memories of a man who, I believe, was such a gentle, decent and respected man. As I got older, I watched his career with more and more interest. My interest in politics stemmed in a roundabout way from that association, because in those days—back in the late 1950s—my father, who was a true‐blue Liberal, got on very well indeed with Mr Barnard. In fact, they were very good mates, but my father used to go up and down the wall every time a certain gentleman came to stay with the Barnards. That person's name is Gough Whitlam.

SPEECH.PARA: My father used to make prophecies about the things that would happen if that person ever became Prime Minister of this country. As a young child sitting at the dinner table, I very clearly remembered all those things that my father said. My father died at a very young age, in 1970. He did not live to see the day when Gough Whitlam actually became Prime Minister. After one year of that prime ministership, I started to have a distinct feeling of deja vu about so much of what my father had said around the dinner table in about 1959 or 1960—therefore, I went out and joined the Liberal Party.

Interestingly, although my father, as I say, was a true‐blue Liberal and Mr Barnard was a Labor member of parliament, they got on exceedingly well. As my father used to say, he was such a gentleman and such a decent man. He was always prepared to listen to all sides of the story. He and dad sat down and had many a conversation. I think it is an interesting thing, because many people ask me, `What on earth made you get involved in politics?' I recite that story, going back to that very early stage of my life.

It was also great to have seen Mr Barnard in latter years at the functions that are held here on 9 May for former members. It was terrific to have had that opportunity to renew the friendship and acquaintance. Of course, I always checked up on how Trish was going.

I think it is a very sad day. I was travelling in the Pilbara the day my office rang to say that Mr Barnard had passed away. Even my staff knew that he held a special little niche in my life as a person I had grown fond of at a very young age. I extend my most sincere condolences to his wife and family, and especially to his eldest daughter, Trish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself with the condolence motion for the Hon. Lance Barnard moved by Senator Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not know Lance Barnard as well as some of my other colleagues did, but I do know that when he retired from politics that was not the end of his commitment to the community. He continued to work as an active community member from the time he left politics to the time of his death. I know that in Launceston particularly members of that community will miss him terribly.
He was a humane kind man with enormous integrity. He was also a very humble man. He will be missed enormously by the community. To Jill, the family and his friends, I pass on my sympathy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, as a Liberal Tasmanian senator I, too, wish to be associated with the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: I met Lance Barnard after he had retired from politics—mostly at airports when he was involved in his group training activities. But there is no doubt, as we have read and heard, that Lance Barnard was by any standard a great Tasmanian and a great Australian. So much so that, at the Liberal Party state council meeting last weekend, the State President, Bill Gatenby—who, tragically, died this morning—mentioned the great service that Lance Barnard had given to Tasmania. I think that to be honoured in such a way at a conference of some 350 Liberals is an indication of how Lance Barnard was regarded by the Tasmanian people.
I would like to pay tribute to the late Lance Barnard, who served his state and his country in such an unselfish and outstanding manner.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to seek leave of the House to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the winter recess certain elements of the press ran an article that alleged that I had failed in my duty to register a certain directorship on my statement of interests. I confirm those allegations are true, and supply the following mitigation.

SPEECH.PARA: I was unaware that I was still a director of the company known as A‐CAP Development Ltd. Under no circumstances would I have treated this place with the slightest or any other contempt. By way of mitigation, I seek your indulgence to read two brief letters. The first one is under the letterhead of the Australian Securities Commission and it is dated 25 March 1993. It is written by a Mr D. Nemorin, the Manager of the Complaints Management Branch of the Australian Securities Commission. He says, inter alia:
I refer to your letter dated 18 March 1993 regarding the finalisation of the abovenamed administration.
The letter is addressed to Ferrier Hodgson, Chartered Accountants. He goes on to say:
I wish to advise that as no further action has been taken by the Commission you may finalise your administration in due course.

That letter is the last on my file with respect to A‐CAP Development Ltd at that time. There has, I understand, been other letters written. I have not been a recipient of those letters, nor were they addressed to me.
I have had nothing to do with A‐CAP Development by way of any meeting, by way of any decision making or any other contact since 1990.

If I may, I will continue very briefly with a further explanation that mitigates my position. This letter is under the letterhead of Coopers & Lybrand, chartered accounts of Perth, which is both a national and international accounting company. Coopers & Lybrand has been my accountant for 15 or more years. The letter, dated 25 July 1997, is above the signature of Mr Cesare Scalise, who is a partner with Coopers & Lybrand. Mr Scalise says:

On your appointment to the Senate you were requested to provide to the Registrar of Senators' Interests a statement of your registrable interests. Such interests include shareholdings in public and private companies and company directorships.
You requested us to provide information to enable you to complete your statement of Senators' Interests as we are your accountant and the accountant to your companies.

It has come to our attention that we did not provide you with details of your directorship and shareholding in A‐CAP Development Limited. We assumed that A‐CAP Development Limited had been deregistered.

As you know, we have been your group accountant for at least 15 years. We provided information for the entities for which we provide services. Each of those entities was disclosed on the statement. A‐CAP Development Limited went into liquidation on 4 October 1990. Coopers & Lybrand was a creditor of that company, and we received what we understood was the final distribution from the liquidator approximately four years ago. We believed that the company no longer existed. No doubt, you also believed that . . .
There are other paragraphs. I offer that by way of explanation and further add that, in so far as I caused embarrassment to this chamber, I apologise. I seek leave to table these two letters.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of Senate assembled:

That we are opposed to the extension of a user‐pays higher education system represented by the passage of the Higher Education Funding Act Amendment 1996. We believe that AUSTUDY/ ABSTUDY benefits and publicly funded education play a vital role in ensuring a broadly accessible higher education system, which is in turn fundamental to efforts in creating a more just and equitable society.
We the undersigned demand
fully publicly funded and accessible secondary, tertiary and TAFE education;

the abolition of the Higher Education Contribution scheme and of upfront fees in any form and in particular the abolition of post graduate fees, International Student Fees, ancillary service charges and any existent or future implementation of fees for permanent resident students or domestic undergraduates;
progressive taxation of the wealthy to fund education and
that public funding to education be increased to such a level until there is no unmet demand for it.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned respectfully submit that Social Housing is a major social `safety net', crucial for all Australians.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to maintain a commitment to the buying and building of new housing properties. The new Commonwealth State Housing Agreement must provide the States with monies to buy and build more Public and Community Housing. Dismantling the `safety net' of Social Housing will mean homelessness, overcrowding and the scrapping of public housing redevelopment plans, all of which will impact on the most disadvantaged groups in the Australian society.
Your petitioners support an increase in assistance to low income earners in the private rental market, but not at the expense of Public and Community Housing.
Your petitioners thus urge the Senate to reject current plans in the area of public and community housing.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: O'Chee, Sen Bill; Brownhill, Sen David; Patterson, Sen Kay
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable overseas `active service' under `Operational Service' at Section 6(1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

A defined group of Australians, who served in the Malaya area, being members of the Royal Australian Navy so affected, have been wrongly excluded, whereas members of the Army and Air Force were not so excluded, and this is supported by documents in the Australian Archives and elsewhere on public record.

Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for benefits under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnam Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of whom appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then secretly `unallotted' to enable the introduction of the excluding legislation.

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962, which act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) the Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of Australian citizens' honourable service with the Royal Australian Navy for Australia, Britain and Malaya, whilst on `active service' in the Malaya campaign between 1955 and 1960.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator O'Chee(from five citizens), Senator Brownhill(from 60 citizens)and Senator Patterson(from 19 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Boswell, Sen Ronald; Faulkner, Sen John; Knowles, Sen Susan; Sherry, Sen Nick; Troeth, Sen Judith
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are still the only Australians, sent overseas on active service, whose service has not been recognised in three important areas:
1. R.A.N. casualties are not yet included on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial alongside Army and R.A.A.F. casualties;
2. R.A.N. service has not yet been recognised with the visible signs of service to Australia; the Returned from Active Service Badge and the Naval campaign medal; and
3. R.A.N. service is still not acknowledged as eligible service for the Australian Service Pension, while service by Commonwealth and allied veterans from 55 other countries is.
Members of the Army and R.A.A.F. who served during the same period in Malaya had their service fully recognised 24 hours after arriving in Malaya.

In the 1997 Budget the Government partly recognised that R.A.N. service by providing the same recognition and benefits for that service. The cost will be minuscule, being mainly a transfer of pensions from `age' as paid by the Department of Social Security, to `service' pensions, paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Boswell(from 10 citizens), Senator Faulkner(from six citizens), Senator Knowles(from eight citizens), Senator Sherry(from 14 citizens)and Senator Troeth(from eight citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate their extreme concern at the proposal to charge entry fees for people needing nursing home care. Furthermore, the petitioners are extremely concerned that the charging of up front entry fees will force people to sell their homes in order to gain a nursing home bed.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure that access to nursing home care is available on the basis of need and further that the family home is exempt from any asset test used to determine eligibility for such care.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation of Postgraduate Scholarships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government recognise that taxing scholarships will:
(a) jeopardise links between universities and industry;
(b) increase the costs of scholarships resulting in few scholarships or scholarships of less value; and
(c) represents another attack on the education sector; and
Calls on the Government to ensure that any changes to the regulations or legislation governing the taxation of postgraduate scholarships maintain the tax exempt status of these scholarships.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Calvert, Sen Paul; West, Sen Sue
PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned nurses and members of the public shows their concerns with the Aged Care Bill 1997 and the accompanying changes to the funding and regulation of Aged Care announced by the Government in the 1996 Budget. In particular regarding the abolition of specific funding for the provision of nursing care to residents of nursing homes.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate amend the Aged Care Bill 1997 so as to provide a requirement that funding of aged care be in such a form that specific funds are allocated to aged care providers for the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents and that aged care providers be allowed to spend that money only on the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert(from 16 citizens)and Senator West(from 1,748 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Mobile Phone Towers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that certain citizens of the Central Coast of New South Wales draw to the attention of the Senate their objection to the proposal to erect a mobile phone base station on top of the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club building. Your petitioners are particularly concerned that position of the base station is within 300 metres of the Ettalong Public School and could potentially constitute a health risk.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure that a carrier must not construct a mobile phone base station within 300 metres of a child care centre, kindergarten, school or hospital.

PETITION.TITLE: Mobile Phone Towers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose the construction of a mobile phone tower on the Magill campus of the University of South Australia.

We oppose it on aesthetic and health grounds particularly given its proximity to the University of South Australia, its childcare facility, the Murray Park Kindergarten, the Jeffcott Montessori Preschool and the Magill Junior and Senior Primary Schools.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Murphy, Sen Shayne; Sherry, Sen Nick
PETITION.TITLE: Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industries
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are concerned with the recommendations of the draft Industry Commission report into the Textile, Clothing and Footwear industries, and that acceptance of these recommendations could see a further 1900 Tasmanians lose their jobs.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support Tasmanian Textile, Clothing and Footwear workers by rejecting the Industry Commission's recommendations to slash tariffs and export assistance for this vital Tasmanian industry.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Murphy(from 379 citizens)and Senator Sherry(from one citizen)

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Health
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of Senate that the Federal Govern ment wants to direct funding away from services aimed at women's health.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate ensures that funding is directly spent on providing vital health services for women. In addition we request that funding is directed to women's health centres so that women can continue to seek medical advice from places that cater specifically for their needs.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

that the proposal to introduce benchmark pricing to blood glucose test strips supplied through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and the National Diabetic Services Scheme (NDSS) is an ill‐advised cost cutting measure that could increase the risk of the complications of diabetes.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to reject the proposal, and ensure diabetes sufferers will be protected from further legislation of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that 15 sitting days after today I shall move that the following delegated legislation, a list of which I shall hand to the clerk, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The list read as follows—
1. Airports Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 104 and made under the Airports Act 1996 .
2. Civil Aviation Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 111 and made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988 .
3. Instrument of Approval No. 1 of 1997 made under sections 4A and 77H of the Customs Act 1901.
4. Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 109 and made under the Migration Act 1958 .

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include possible breaches of privacy, unfair provisions, administrative decisions which may not be subject to external review of their merits, invalid subdelegation of legislative power, removal of rights, inadequate notification of actions and a strict liability offence. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—
The Regulations provide a formula for the Minister to give an airport operator notice to adjust its foreign ownership to comply with the 49% maximum foreign ownership requirements.

The Regulations require a company to provide evidence to the Minister's reasonable satisfaction that an unacceptable foreign ownership situation does not exist. This discretion has considerable commercial significance. The Explanatory State ment does not indicate whether the discretion is subject to merits review.
The Regulations also provide for permissive rather than mandatory notification of rights and for a possibly unfair prosecution provision.
The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Civil Aviation Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 111

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations provide a regimen for the appointment of maintenance controllers and for appropriate maintenance manuals.

The Regulations provide that CASA may direct an operator to amend the maintenance control manual and to make the manual available for inspection. These are strict liability offences with a possible penalty for breach of $5000. The Committee has written to the Minister for advice on whether there is a requirement that CASA's direction or request be in writing and whether strict liability is appropriate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Instrument of Approval No 1 of 1997 made under ss.4A and 77H of the Customs Act 1901

SPEECH.PARA: The Instrument approves the `Application for a Customs Depot Licence' form as an approved form.

The Instrument requires the name, address (residential and business) and date of birth of an applicant, all partners, all directors, officeholders, shareholders and any employee who will participate in management or control of the depot. The Explanatory Statement does not provide any reason for this possible breach of privacy. The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

The Regulations make amendments relating to evidence of ownership of assets and provisions relating to internal review of decisions, introduce or increase certain fees and introduce a new form of visa.

The Regulations provide for the Minister to determine an applicant's score on the business skills points test and characteristics of a class of persons by Gazette notice. These provisions appear to a subdelegation of legislative power and therefore invalid.

The Explanatory Statement advises that the regulations omit provisions relating to refund of a fee where a review authority sets aside or varies the decision or where the decision is remitted to the original decision maker for reconsideration. There is no explanation to justify the reason for abolishing the right to a refund nor an indication whether this abolition will disadvantage people already in the system.
The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.
