TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 as a whole. The question is that amendment No. 2 on revised sheet 594 moved by Senator Sherry for the opposition be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just prior to question time, we were dealing with our amendment No. 2. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 as it currently stands provides for the CGT relief on up to half a million dollars to be granted where the net business asset of the taxpayer does not exceed $5 million. The opposition amendment that we are considering will extend this test by changing it to a net assets test to include all the personal wealth of a taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor does not believe that, when an individual retires, they only seek to live from the proceeds of business wealth; they will also access personal wealth. This being the case, it is the opposition's belief that all personal wealth should be included for the purposes of determining a taxpayer's eligibility for the half a million dollars capital gains tax relief.

This is the same amendment that we moved to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 , which was supported by the Greens, the Democrats and Senator Harradine. Senator Campbell, prior to question time I was seeking from you clarification of your indication that the Democrats and Senator Harradine had not supported this amendment on the previous occasion.

We see no reason why, when a person retires with considerable business wealth, their personal wealth should be ignored in the determination of what is a very significant benefit that will be paid for by the broader Australian community and Australian families. A number of concessions are means tested by the government. A few examples are the family payment, the family tax initiative and the spouse rebate—just to name a few.

Why then should taxpayers's significant business wealth of up to $5 million be excluded from their eligibility to receive capital gains tax relief of up to half a million dollars? Why shouldn't that significant personal wealth be taken into consideration? This to us is an eminently equitable measure and a fair measure.

BREAK.PARA: I note that 97 per cent of small businesses have net business assets of under $1.3 million. So Labor does not consider the measure inappropriate as it will ensure that we are rewarding the genuine small business and their operators who have spent many years working hard to build up the asset value of their business. We do not believe that what would be considered a very small number of wealthy small business operators can consider that excluding personal wealth of up to $5 million is reasonable. We just do not believe that it is an unreasonable approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, because I promised to do so, I wish to clarify the situation on the vote on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . I did not present the case accurately. I said I would correct it if it was not accurate. What happened was, when the bill was re‐presented, the Labor Party said that they would not proceed with their proposal. Senator Kernot reluctantly agreed. Senator Harradine said he did not want to have to make up his mind and moved that the Senate report progress, and we did not support him.
—I didn't.
—No, you said you wanted some more time to consider it, which is fair enough.
—The full picture at last.

—I will refer anyone who is really interested to a fascinating page—page 5,507 of Friday, 27 June 1997—to see what actually happened. Roughly, that was the way they lined up. Senator Margetts was the one who was absolutely consistent. She said she was going to stick by Labor's old amendment, but the rest of the Senate was practical.

SPEECH.PARA: From the government's point of view, it is important that this amendment not stand, for similar reasons to those put under Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . But, more importantly, as Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 now stands, by insisting on this amendment we would create inconsistency. We have already stated—I stated prior to question time—that the person al assets exclusion would create added compliance costs for small business in particular.

I say to Senator Margetts that the $5 million exemption is in the legislation already. Senator Margetts thinks we should put it in again, for some reason. One of the important things is that to gain the exemption under this assets threshold, you are looking at the value of the business. If you keep trying to squash this, you exclude more and more people from it. As I have said, we have just defeated the amendment in relation to halving the upper limit of the exemption relief, so that has been maintained. We believe that to do this further again restricts it, and restricts it unfairly. As I have said, it would make it inconsistent with the existing rollover provisions.

If there is anything that can be learnt from the confusion in the tax act—the hundreds upon hundreds of pages of amendments and laws and delegated legislation that flows from it—one thing that would be desirable, particularly when it comes to capital gains tax rollover relief, which this forms a part of, would be to keep it consistent. To do that you would have to go back to TLAB (No. 1) and try to retrospectively change it.

I commend the bill as it stands to the Senate. I would urge honourable senators who are making up their minds whether to support amendment No. 2, on the basis of consistency, on the basis of reducing compliance costs for small business—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax rort!

—That is another one of Senator Conroy's highly intelligent interjections. You can always trust Senator Conroy to come up with an incisive, brilliant interjection. He should be shadow Treasury spokesman. He is the senator for quorums, the senator for fire drills. I do urge even Senator Conroy to consider the good sense and consistency of this, but I doubt that I will get his vote. I do hope that some people up the other end of the chamber might vote against this amendment.

—It is a bit difficult for it to be two things at once: the amendment is either what is in the other legislation, or it is differ ent and it is going to be inconsistent. So there might be some elements of the exemption in the existing legislation, but obviously what is proposed in these amendments, you have admitted, is different from what is currently in the legislation. The Greens (WA) support that difference and we support that extension to make it fairer, not an ongoing give away to people with greater wealth. The last time I said that was when you jumped up and said, `It is exactly the same as in the current bill.' It cannot be both at once. It cannot be an extension which will be a problem for consistency and exactly the same as what is in the current bill. So we will support it because it is an attempt to extend and to make it fairer than what is currently in the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the amendment that we are dealing with at the moment has been around for some time. I am not sure of the precise time, but it certainly was not dropped on the table today. If it were passed, could Senator Campbell let the committee know how many high wealth small business individuals would be affected by the provision? We have got all the Treasury advisers here. I would be interested to know what number would be affected.

—The answer, I am informed, is that the amendment has been around for a while, but the one that you originally circulated was in the form that was agreed to by the Senate previously. As we understand it, this business about excluding personal assets was put in in recent times. I can be corrected; I am prepared to admit when I am wrong, which is quite often. It has only been circulated today. I am happy to be told differently by your advisers. The existing amendment, until it was amended today, did not include this personal assets matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will check on that. I know that it is not just those advisers here who are watching and listening to this debate; they are all watching on the Treasury internal in-house video system, ready to pick you up, Senator Campbell. I am sure they are watching the debate. Can you find out just how many people this will affect?

—One of the things I have responsibility for is the Australian Bureau of Statistics. As I understand it, we do not keep statistics on how many small business people have got assets, including personal property, in excess of $5 million. We could ask the people who put together the census to ask that question next time, and I could come back to you after the next census. But in the meantime, that sort of information in relation to the capital value of all those assets would not be available, even to the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be happy to accept an estimate without holding you to a precise figure. It is an important issue. I would be very surprised if the Treasury advisers were not down there now in the Treasury building. How are you all? They would be scurrying around watching us on the internal video service. Senator Harradine looks a little bit perplexed. Treasury actually monitor this debate, Senator Harradine, and they provide updates to the minister or the parliamentary secretary on little titbits of information that we ask about in the course of the debate, so we have discovered.
—Here he comes to help you out.

—Yes, here comes Senator Kemp to help you out with the statistics. Senator Campbell, when you were seeking a response to that last question, I was informed that the amendment was circulated some time ago. We had not included in the exclusion of business assets of less than $5,000, which we considered to be relatively minor in the context of the issue we are discussing. I do not want to unduly hold up the Senate, so the last point I want to make while we are waiting for the Treasury phone call, Senator Campbell, is that you placed a lot of emphasis on compliance costs for small business. How do you see that alleged in crease in the compliance costs affecting small business?

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, we do not know how many small businesses would be affected by this amendment. Secondly, surely that is an exaggerated claim—excuse I think would be a much better description—given the compliance costs you have added to small business, say, with respect to the superannuation tax. I have had numerous representations from small business about that issue. Senator Kemp well knows that and he is in here to help bail you out on this occasion. It seems to us that the excuse you have put forward of compliance costs in respect of small business is just that, an excuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I did not say that that was an excuse. I said that there were a number of reasons—
—You didn't say it?

—You said it was an excuse. There are some very good reasons for this not going in. I have mentioned consistency. There is also the fairness question, which relates to setting the criteria for the threshold. The compliance costs in terms of consistency, simplicity and equity are but one factor. If we cannot get you on that factor, can we just get you on the consistency factor? Clearly, the more provisions you put into it the more the compliance cost goes up. We are interested in cutting compliance costs and cutting red tape for small businesses. We are into getting small businesses to grow and create employment. We are about making the tax system fairer. We are about tax reform. We want to make it simpler and fairer. This is but one example of putting that philosophy into practice. We would hope that after 13 years you would agree.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, you have raised the issue of consistency. I would like your response to this issue. If we are to be consistent, why then do we have, and I referred to it earlier in my comments, different tests applying to other provisions—for example, in social security? If we were to be consistent across all forms of tax transfer and so on, we would have the same treatment of them all and yet we do not appear to have it. I gave a couple of examples of the family payment, the family tax initiative and the spouse rebate to name a few.

—I will have to make this my last contribution to this debate this afternoon. Senator Kemp is going to take over because I am struggling under this questioning. I actually have to give a speech in Sydney to another investment organisation. Senator Kemp will handle it. The consistency point I have argued is between Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) and Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which I am debating here today. Although I am sure your amendment is well intentioned, I would ask senators to oppose the amendment and to vote for consistency with Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1).

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) dealt with capital gains tax rollover for the sale of a small business. What we are dealing with here is a fundamentally different issue. It is capital gains tax rollover relief when a person retires into a retirement product. I accept that the logic of the previous measure in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) was to encourage reinvestment in small business and business growth. This is not what this bill is about. This bill is about what happens to a person and the way at least part of the capital gains tax is treated when they presumably sell the business and go into retirement. The aims being addressed in this bill are fundamentally different from those addressed in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1).

—I think that was a reasonable question. I was going to refer Senator Kemp to Hansard of Friday, 27 June at page 5470 and ask him to explain the relevance of what was debated there to what we are currently considering. I think that, in essence, is what Senator Sherry is asking for.
—Could you assist us by giving those references again, Senator Harradine?

—The reference is Hansard of 27 June 1997 page 5470. Senator Sherry asked a question relating to the $5 million. He reminded you that on 12 December last year he asked you a question about this, which stated:

BREAK.PARA: Will taxpayers with non‐business wealth (such as an art collection) worth many millions of dollars be eligible for CGT relief if their net business assets are less than $5 million?
I refer you to the response you gave to Senator Sherry and ask what precisely is the relevance of that, which has been referred to by Senator Campbell, to what we are dealing with now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —From my understanding, this issue has been very well canvassed. I am surprised that it continues to be raised. There will be a variety of views. The government's position on this is very clear. The issue of personal assets was excluded, if I can read Senator Campbell's notes accurately, for simplicity and equity reasons. The proposal which has been put forward by the Labor Party is that it will lead to a significant increase in compliance costs for small business. It is all very well to quote extreme examples of substantial art works and other things, but that is, I suspect, an extreme example and does not actually reflect the more likely instance of people with far fewer and lesser personal assets.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue has been thought about. It has been extensively canvassed. We believe that there is a consistency between the two bills. Senator Harradine, I hope that you will be supporting us. Having just come into this debate, I am not quite sure of the current state of play, but I trust that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the minister that the committee has dealt with opposition amendments Nos 1, 3, 4 and 5. I voted against those amendments. I am inclined to vote for this amendment in the absence of a response that was due to Senator Sherry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We are always anxious to try to persuade you, Senator, so I will try again. On my understanding, there are not figures available. There are simply not figures available on the number of people that are likely to be affected. It seems to me that the case that Senator Sherry has mounted is a fairly extreme case at one end of the spectrum. The fact of the matter is that, if this amendment is carried, it is more than likely that significant numbers of people who are not of the type that has been characterised by Senator Sherry will be adversely affected.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not possible to supply you with those figures, but it seems to me a commonsense approach would lead one to that conclusion. Senator Sherry wants to exclude what he sees as the very wealthy in relation to personal assets. In doing that, he may very well—and it is highly likely—sweep up far more people who should not be included, perhaps people whom you would be more inclined to support. The fact of the matter is that there will be additional compliance costs. It will require the valuation of personal assets. It will include the family home, I am advised. If you live in Sydney, it is not hard for the figure to rapidly mount up. Even for quite modest housing, substantial value can reside in the family home.

Senator, I do not have figures that I can give you, but it seems to me that this is an extreme example postulated by Senator Sherry which is likely to be one extreme of the spectrum. The fact of the matter is that it will sweep up people who are certainly not in that category.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a figure here of $5 million. That would be a pretty pleasant house on the leafy foreshores of Sydney Harbour. I want to challenge your contention of simplicity, Senator Kemp. If a person is to benefit from this measure and the previous measure that we were dealing with before the break, they have to work out—presumably they get their accountant to do this—the net value of their assets. That would, in many circumstances, be quite complex. I assume they would go to their accountant, business adviser, et cetera, to have the value of those assets and the value of their business calculated.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that would be much more complex than providing a schedule of their personal assets. If it is a car or a house, I cannot see how it is complex to provide that sort of basic information. If it is a long list of personal assets and it includes the yacht, the silverware, the paintings and all the other things that you claim are a bit extreme, it will take a bit more time. Even then it would not be, I would submit, as complex as meeting the requirements of your measure.

While you are seeking advice, I would reinforce this point: we are not dealing here with the exemption from capital gains tax on the sale of a business and the purchase of another business; we are dealing here with a person actually retiring and purchasing a retirement product, which is different. The person has made their contribution. It has been recognised in the measure that was approved in tax bill No. 1. It is being recognised here with a measure that is very beneficial.

We do not argue with the principle. We have already had that debate anyway in the previous amendments. We do not argue that small business deserves to be recognised. Our concern is for fairness and equity; that no-one else in the community will enjoy a benefit that anywhere near matches this type of benefit. When a person obtains a pension, part or whole, they are subject to asset and means testing of their pension. Not to include some sort of assessment of personal assets when we are extending yet another benefit to small business in this case seems to us to be very inequitable and unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make this very clear—and I urge people who may be wavering to reflect on this—we make no apology for extending a benefit to small business. It was part of our policy for the last election. We think it is important in relation to small business to redress some of the imbalances of the adverse effects of policies that were followed previously. This was one of the election commitments that the coalition made as it went to the last election. If the arguments so far have failed to persuade some people, we would urge those to reflect that this is a clear commitment we gave.
—You're telling us we don't need this amendment.
—We are opposing this amendment because we wish to deliver the commitment we made to small business. Senator Murphy often gets up, and we welcome his questions on small business—

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, I beg your pardon. My apologies.
—Who are you apologising to, Senator Murphy or Senator Murray?

—I will leave you to work that one out. We urge the Senate to allow us to fulfil what we see as a commitment that was made. I do not know whether I can add anything more to the debate over and above what Senator Campbell has said.

SPEECH.PARA: The net business assets would be relatively easily taken from a balance sheet, but people simply may not know the value of their home, their car and other personal assets. They will have to obtain those valuations specifically as a result of this amendment. As I said, we are opposed to this. On a number of grounds, certainly on compliance grounds, we are opposed to it. We are seeking to fulfil our election commitment to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just point out to Senator Kemp that we do not think it is overly complex because, presumably, most of these people who are retiring effectively will retire and will have to provide details of their personal assets in the event of the means test and assets test for an age pension, if they wish to seek access to part or whole of a pension. They are likely to have to do that anyway, given that they are retiring.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to your election promises, you have not explored the concept of core and non-core, and we have traversed this on many occasions in the Senate. But you are right; you did have a commitment with respect to a rollover exemption for half a million dollars for small business capital gains tax. You are right, Senator Kemp; we have passed that. We had an amendment. It failed.

We are dealing here with another issue. I have read your election commitment in this area. It does not say anything about whether or not personal assets would be included or excluded. So we are helping you. Your policy was silent on this matter. If, indeed, we had to approach all legislation on the basis that it was an election commitment, you would be honouring a lot more than what you have since the election. As I have said, your policy was silent on this matter. You have what you want with respect to amendments Nos 1, 3, 4 and 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I will try to avoid replying to every pathetic point scoring effort that you try, but fail, as usual, to sustain when you get up. This is the most obstructionist opposition we have seen in this Senate for a long time. There are many major bills which you have utterly refused to accept, core or non-core, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe, as I said, this will fulfil the election commitment we made. There is no question that this will involve a significant addition in compliance costs for individuals. Even people well below the limit may well have to value their assets. So, Senator, we are opposing the amendment. We hope that a majority of senators will join us.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry 's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 2, page 29 (lines 4 to 32), omit item 1, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Omit subparagraphs (ia), (ib) and (ic), substitute:

TAB.TAB: those rights to mine were acquired by the person before 7.30 pm, by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 20 August 1996 and the person was a bona fide prospector, that is to say—

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make some sense of that for the lay person. In my speech on the second reading earlier today I set out the history of this provision. In short order, the government announced in the 1996‐97 budget that it would close off what it characterised as a loophole in this act by removing the right of prospectors to a tax exemption when they sold their prospect for mining development. The opposition—that is, the Labor Party—supported that change, but with the very strong caveat that this new provision should not act retrospectively and that there should be some sensitivity shown to the interest of those people who had been developing leases for sale and the costs that they had incurred in doing so.

Indeed, it was not only the opposition that said that. The Senate economics committee, inquiring into this legislation, came to the same conclusion in principle and said so. My recollection is that that was a unanimous decision of that committee. When they embarked on putting forward the changes to the bill that they have before the Senate now, the government did so in the sure and certain knowledge that they were flying in the face of a unanimous decision of the Senate economics committee. That has not deterred the government; they have persisted.

The changes that I propose by this amendment are changes which would grandfather the rights of prospectors from the time at which the so‐called closing of the loophole change took effect, that is, 20 August 1996. Those people who had had a right to, and a normal expectation of, exemption from taxation and who had incurred costs in that knowledge—costs that they may not otherwise have incurred had they known that they would be taxed—would be able to be retrospectively protected. In my considered view, the only sure way of doing that is the sweeping type of catch‐all amendment that does that, the amendment that I have just now moved.

In being fair to the history of this subject, I might say that, last year when my amendment that I have just moved was defeated, another amendment was moved by my colleague Senator Murray, representing the Australian Democrats. His amendment was then carried.

I was persuaded at the time—and I believe that it was the case—that Senator Murray believed that his amendment was going to fix this loophole. Indeed, it seems to me that many of the senators in the chamber at the time believed that retrospectivity would be properly dealt with by the Murray amendment—albeit in a more stringent form than would have been the case in the one that I moved.

The facts are that retrospectivity has not been dealt with and that therefore the government are proposing to change the law by introducing their amendment so that the tax office can give effect to this change—there being some problems in the Murray amendment—but they are not answering the retrospectivity question.

Having said that, I hope I have put the issue in some context. I think this amendment should be carried. In fact, it is the only effective way of guaranteeing that the retrospectivity of the provisions that the government is proposing to enact is guarded against.

In closing the debate on the second reading, Senator Campbell, a Western Australian senator, said that there was no retrospectivity involved in the government position—which was quite extraordinary from him. Of course, that is not true. The government's position does allow for retrospective taxation in this particular case. All I can understand from Senator Campbell's comment is that he has not applied himself to this industry's needs; nor has he understood at all what the nature of these changes that he is advocating to this chamber is. That is a cross that he is going to have to bear, I am sure.

The other argument that he put in closing the debate on the second reading is that the cost of revenue forgone, if my amendment were to succeed, has increased with better and new figuring from the department. I had understood that the cost was in the order of $65 million and that that `so‐called' cost was revenue that rightly ought to go to the Commonwealth which, because of this amendment, would not go to the Commonwealth.

That figure has moved from $65 million to the more impressive three‐digit figure of $100 million: an exact, precise $100 million, not $101 million or $99.3 million but exactly $100 million. We are being asked to believe that on new and better figuring it is precisely $100 million—no cents involved.

We are asked to believe it by assertion. There is no argument adduced to show us why the figures have changed, no presentation of figuring, no exposure of the assumptions on which this figure is calculated so that we can test whether this figure is right or wrong, but I do know that the cost of revenue forgone is being used here as a telling argument.

I now say something about the extraordinary change in the cost of revenue forgone and the fact that it is now precisely $100 million. That is not a cost to revenue. If you accept the principle that this is a retrospective principle—which of course it is, a principle accepted by the Senate economics committee—then the so‐called cost to revenue is the amount of revenue to be obtained by retrospectively taxing activities that were lawful at the time and when people who were carrying them out believed them to be lawful.

This is the amount of tax achieved by retrospective application. You can characterise it, if you wish, as revenue forgone. I think the fairer characterisation of it would be that this is the amount of retrospectivity the government expects to obtain. Put in that light—which is the only reasonable light for it to be presented in, in my submission—I think that, whatever the figure is, it shows the enormity of the principle of retrospective taxation in this case and how negative retrospective taxation in this case is. It is negative to the tune of $65 million—no, on later figuring it is negative to the tune of $100 million, that is, $100 million of tax revenue to be garnered from people who thought they were doing lawful things at the time and now find, because of the passage of this legislation, that they are not doing lawful things.

The principle that the government cleaved to assiduously in opposition was to oppose retrospective legislation in taxation. They might wish now to argue that this is not true retrospectivity, but they would have to jump over the findings of the Senate economics committee report to do so. The point is that they argued strenuously in opposition that retrospectivity should not apply, yet in government their tune has changed. Here they are exacting, on the figures we have, $65 million, $100 million—or some other figure you can think of and pencil in—as the amount of retrospectivity.

Some may argue in any case, `So what.' I remind the Senate that the `So what' here applies to an important industry sector in Australia—the mining industry. While most of the prospectors concerned may be prospectors for gold—and certainly the government has an argument to answer about its treatment of the gold industry in recent months—it is also the truth that this industry sector refers to a lot of other minerals as well, and I read the list of those into the Hansard in my speech during the second reading debate. It was quite an exhaustive list of the many other minerals to which this exemption applies.

In the case of the gold industry, we do know that the sale of bullion by the Reserve Bank achieved an income to our national accounts of $2.5 billion, but it wiped over $2 billion off the value of shares held by investors in gold. In many respects, it was a direct transfer from the pockets of Australian gold investors to the pockets of Treasury. That is the economic effect of the sale of bullion. So you can argue that at one level.

At the other level, the important thing is that it has depressed the price of gold. At a time when the market has been artificially driven down by government action, we now have a situation in which, retrospectively as well, people who work in this sector are to be taxed.

One could argue, on the basis of degree of pain, that the degree of pain being inflicted on this industry is to pile pain on top of pain, and if you say, `So what,' you are approving the fact that even more pain should be exacted here—that when an industry is down we should tax it even harder. I think that is a proposition that most ordinary Australians would say does not fall under the heading of a fair go.

I have moved my amendment. I have two other amendments foreshadowed in case this amendment does not succeed, but I hope they will not be necessary. Before I resume my seat, if the Assistant Treasurer is going to reply in this debate—and I think he ought to—in his reply I ask him specifically to tell the chamber what, in his view, is the cost of revenue forgone by this measure; how that cost was calculated; what the assumptions were; and on what basis the figure was arrived at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be helpful if the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) had everybody's views and then responded appropriately. A character in Western Australia who is a prospector said that, if the government is determined to bury this scheme, at least it should give it a decent burial. The point that Senator Cook has made yet again is that that has not yet been done. Hopefully, this debate will finally do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a member of the Senate economics committee, along with Senator Cook, which originally examined this government proposal. We were, as Senator Cook rightly said, unanimously distressed at the retrospective and unfair consequences of the government's action as intended at that time. We are all aware that prospectors undertake the most difficult and the highest risk task in the mining industry and they are primarily a small business sector.

When the bill came before the Senate last December, it was at a time when there was a flurry of bills and it was the end of the session. The result was a fair bit of stress while these matters were being considered.

Senator Cook did put up his amendment and I put up an amendment. The government clearly understood that they did not have the numbers and they should accede to the general principles we were spelling out—that is, with respect to these conditions under paragraph 23PA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, prospective rights were necessary in order to prevent retrospectivity. That was because mining activity undertaken by prospectors was only realised in the future, and if you cut it off on 20 August 1996—which was the government's intention—it would result in a huge loss of income and benefits to those engaged in prospecting at that time.

We were persuaded by the industry advocates—although some of them wanted a lot longer—that five years was a reasonable period in which to resolve the issue of disposing of their interest in any particular claim. The government did accept that five years. Their legislation now, in terms of the amendment they accepted, states that you had to be a bona fide prospector prior to and at the date of 20 August 1996 and that you would have five years in which to dispose of your asset.

However, when I put up my amendment, which was somewhat narrower than that proposed by Senator Cook, the government came to me and said, `We understand where you're going. We're prepared to accede to your request. We would like to amend it,' and they presented me with an amendment which subsequently passed the Senate under my name. I took that on trust.

In fairness to the government, at that time they were under a great deal of pressure to produce the appropriate wording to get the result that was required. I recall a meeting with the Treasurer in his office at which we agreed the relevant terms of the amendment. That was on 12 December 1996. On 13 December the faxes started coming through from the prospectors saying that they were alarmed about certain aspects of it. That is to be expected but, nevertheless, some of the things that they raised did occasion me some concern. So on 24 December 1996, questions on notice went through to the Treasurer. On 22 April—119 days later—they finally replied to those questions on notice. I do not take kindly to a lack of cooperation and I will record that in my memory bank.

To the credit of government, they recognised that there have been some problems with the amendment and what had happened and they had, in March, introduced the amendments that we now see before us. On 2 May 1997, I wrote to the Treasurer with a rather fulsome amendment to see whether that would meet some of the concerns I still had. On 7 August—66 days later—we finally got a response. As the Democrats only have seven senators, I carry nine portfolios so I am pretty busy, but I think 119 days for a question on notice to be responded to and then 66 days for a letter to be responded to is not competent or efficient.

BREAK.PARA: Fortunately, about a week or two ago the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator Campbell, entered the scene. He has since proven efficient and competent and has been on my back about these amendments of Senator Cook's, which I welcome because the lack of interest, involvement or concern of the Treasurer and his department is regrettable.

What we have before us does go some way, but not all the way, to meeting the genuine concerns of the prospectors at losing a benefit which they had every right to believe should not be taken away from them retrospectively. I was persuaded by the government that my own amendment, which was rather fulsome, went too far, and I am not persuaded by the prospectors that we have to attend to the valuation issue. There is a ruling in FC of T v. Tully Cooperative Sugar Milling Association Ltd, 83 ATC 4495 (1983), 14 ATR 495 per Fox at ATC 4500, ATR 500 which says, `As a general rule, taxation provisions that provide a benefit are not to be defeated by an illiberal approach.' Basically speaking, that means that the valuations which prospectors bring forward should be treated on their merits and not illiberally by the ATO.

Turning to the amendments before us, my particular concern is that prospectors should be capable of getting rid of their asset in a manner which most suits their intention and their needs. That means that in many respects they may wish to sell that asset or that right to a mining house on a conditional sale basis. In other words, they receive the money for their asset after the sale—post facto. However, as I read the legislation, they would be restricted in doing so in terms of the withdrawal of the 23(pa) provision because that provision only applies at the time the income was derived. In other words, you only get the benefit at the time you receive the money. So if you sell something now and receive the money later, you are not going to get the benefit.

To my mind, the Labor amendment which meets that most important provision is the item at amendment 3. Amendments 1 and 2 on sheet 561—and we are just dealing with amendment 1 at this time—it is my belief, go a little too far and I think it is time to give this thing a decent burial. It will be my intention to recommend that the Australian Democrats do not support the opposition in amendments 1 and 2, but support them in amendment 3.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 2, page 29 (lines 4 to 32), omit item 1, substitute:

(ic) the person on or before 20 August 1996 was a bona fide prospector, that is to say—

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved this amendment because I believe this is a more literal translation of what was intended by the Senate when it last deliberated on this provision at the end of last year.

I am mindful that my Senate colleagues representing the Australian Democrats, the Greens and now Senator Harradine have all indicated that they will not support this amendment on the argument thus far produced. Obviously, the government will not either—it has called for all of my amendments to be defeated. You do not have to be Einstein to know that, therefore, I am without a majority in this chamber at the present time.

I do, though, out of respect to the chamber, want to take some moments to present some arguments which ought to be considered before this amendment is put aside. I think this amendment, given the failure of the first amendment, should be carried.

The two issues here are issues that have been set out in correspondence to me by the Australian Minerals Council and by various prospectors. Those issues relate to the question of a prospector not being entitled to an exemption unless he satisfies the test of being a bona fide prospector—which we do not object is an appropriate test—when he sells the lease, transfers it or assigns his right to mine and at the time in which the income is derived from the sale of the lease transfer or the assignment of his rights. Both those tests have to be satisfied: he or she has to be a prospector when he or she sells it and he or she has to be a prospector when income is derived from that.

One of the provisions of this amendment would mean that they only have to be prospector at the time in which the lease is sold. I think there is a fair bit of argument here to justify that as a reasonable proposition. One has to understand the goldmining industry or the mining industry to understand the proposition. It is clear the government does not. It is surprising to me that Senator Campbell from Western Australia does not.

For income to be derived may mean that, after the sale of the lease, a payment is made directly and the income is derived, and there is no substantial difference in time between the agreement to sell and the deriving of the income. It is frequently the case that there is a considerable delay in which the income is properly derived. No-one is foxing here. It is the nature of the industry that sometimes the income is derived by means of shareholding equity, a return on the mining venture or matters of that nature. The delay can be up to years. Certainly, it is not unsurprising if it is for several months.

What this provision is asking for is that a person remain a prospector until such time as they have received payment upon the agreement to sell, whether or not they choose to remain part of the industry. Given the price of gold, which this government has helped to depress, and given the more onerous natures of these taxing provisions, there are a number of prospectors who will not choose to remain part of the industry. Why should they be kept artificially prospecting or actually prospecting until such time as payment is made?

This point is strenuously made to me by the AMEC in notes that it has provided to me about its concerns about this provision. I have referred to that extensively in my speech during the second reading debate. Let me go to a couple of other points that I made during the second reading debate.

The loss of exempt status could arise where the purchaser moves onto the area and carries out extensive work such that the field work of the prospector is subsequently swamped by the purchaser's field work. So when you are talking about what the value of the field work done by the prospector is in order to make a valuation, as you are required to in the provision as the government now proposes it, how do you make that valuation when, immediately upon a sale, the purchaser can go along and conduct further and different work? You have got to have someone there at the site all the time. It just makes a ridiculous proposition. I put that to the government as well and ask the minister whether he can answer that question. What happens in the situation where a purchaser has done subsequent work which blanks out or swamps the field work done by the prospector?

The other point I make is that there is no evidence that the exemption was previously allowed only when the taxpayer could prove that they were a bona fide prospector at the time the income was derived. So given that there was no evidence that that was the past practice, perhaps the minister would like to enlighten the chamber as to why it is now proposed to introduce it as a new practice. I do not think there is any evidence to show that it was the case previously.

Even if one wants to say that this practice now ought to be introduced, while we are going through the transitional phase of introducing a new tax—a tax that did not exist before—I would suggest that it is advisable to tread easily and carefully and not to put up onerous provisions during the transitional stage. Allow the provision that I have moved to reflect the entitlement for exemption at the point of sale and not when the income from that sale has been derived.

I might also further say that a case decided at tax law, admittedly under old section 23(p), which the minister should be aware of, is the Biggs case. That involved a number of transactions which delayed settlements. My advice is that the court made no inquiry in that case as to the work carried out by the purchaser after the prospector had sold the tenements; further, the commissioner in that case did not raise any questions. So there is no particular material difference in the wording between that part of old 23(p) and the part that we are now looking at. So perhaps the minister might answer for me why he therefore thinks the provision should now be included when, in the particular case that was decided on in this matter, the extra work that was done was not considered an issue.

Finally on this point, the ATO in its tax ruling on bona fide prospectors makes it clear that the status of a bona fide prospector is determined at the time of disposal, not when the proceeds are received. To back my assertion, I will quote the following extracts from tax ruling 92/19 issued by the Australian Taxation Office in 1992. I think they prove that the government and you, minister, are wrong in your assertion that this represents a change of policy, because the policy has always been to determine eligibility for section 23(pa) exemption at the time the rights to mine are disposed of. In TR 92/19, under the heading `Future field work,' point 7 reads:

Field work carried out after a prospector disposes of rights to mine the relevant material doesn't affect the prospector's claim to have carried out the major part of the field work when the rights were disposed of.
That is fair enough. Then section 48 states:

A prospector may have carried out the whole or a major part of the field work at the time the rights to mine are sold, transferred or assigned. Any further field work after that disposal (by the prospector or by someone else) is irrelevant to the application of paragraph 23(pa). So further prospecting by future parties will not affect the status of a prospector when the rights to mine are disposed of.

I draw your attention to those concluding words: `when the rights to mine are disposed of'. Those are probably more than enough questions to go on with for the moment. But in trying to be complete within the time allocated to me, the other element here concerns the fact that you will need to obtain a valuation of the lease. There are certain rules about how valuations of mining leases are obtained. The Australian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy sets out a Code and guidelines for assessment and valuation of mineral assets and mineral securities for independent expert reports —that is, the Valmin code, which was issued in June 1995. I am sure you are familiar with this code, minister, so you might explain to me why it is you are proposing legislation which transgresses it. More importantly, in terms of weight of argument at least, the Australian Securities Commission, which is of course the government regulatory authority, has a Practice note 43 on valuation reports and profit forecasts . That practice note was released in 1993. Practice note 43, paragraph 48, says:

The complex valuations in an expert's report necessarily contain significant uncertainties. Because of this an expert who gives a single point value will usually be implying spurious accuracy to his or her valuation.

It goes on. I put that to you in terms of the type of valuation that is now required by the tax office in order to assess the value at the particular point of the mining lease. The Securities Commission does not believe that that type of valuation has credibility. So why do you, minister, believe it has? I think these are the two major deficiencies in what the government's position is. My amendment No. 2 will clarify those and resolve them. I hope that the chamber may be persuaded to join me in voting to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to ask Senator Cook for some clarification because most of the arguments he has given in asking the chamber for support for amendment No. 2 have related to the anomaly that he sees in relation to whether or not waiting for the money to be paid over is a sensible time to be required for a bona fide prospector. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a reasonable question to ask of me, Senator Margetts. SPEECH.PARA: The key point is that if you simply make amendment No. 3 there will still need to be a valuation obtained. The valuation will be a single point valuation. My argument here is that there are codes of conduct for valuations in the mining sector. Valuations are obtained all the time for particular reasons. Valuations of mining opportunities can be fraught with great difficulty if one is not careful about setting down the basis for them.

BREAK.PARA: There are two codes that deal with this. One is the Valmin code, which is the Australian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy code. That code is supported by the Australian Stock Exchange and is endorsed by the Minerals Council of Australia as the appropriate code to use when assessing the value of a mining lease. I will not read all of the code. Paragraph 57 states:
When the extent of data available permits,

(a) a range (high/low) of values must be determined and stated reflecting uncertainties in the data and the interaction of the various assumptions that have been applied. In all cases, the most likely Value must be identified, unless there are cogent reasons stated in the report for not doing so: and
(b) the Report must include a sensitivity analysis showing the effects of changing the most significant assumptions.

The data used must not be invalid due to the passage of time and its cut‐off date, which must be disclosed in the Report, must be as close as practicable to the date of the Report or the Valuation Date, as may be appropriate.

In essence it says what the parameters are that might be changed, how you identify those and how you cannot arrive at a single point valuation. I am advised that many independent experts in fact refuse to quote a most likely value on the basis that it cannot be reasonably determined. Where a most likely value is determined it is generally at the median between the high and low values and is therefore of little significance. That is from the Valmin code.
The Australian Securities Commission at paragraph 38 in Practice note 43 on valuation reports and profit forecasts states:

The complex valuations in an expert's report necessarily contain significant uncertainties. Because of this an expert who gives a single point value will usually be implying spurious accuracy to his or her valuation. An expert should, however, give a narrow range of values as possible. An expert report becomes meaningless if the range of values is too wide. An expert should indicate the most probable point within the range of values if it is feasible to do so.

That is the relevant extract. Both these guidelines to valuation show that you cannot simply make a single point valuation. My amendment would not require you to do so. It would avoid that point and make the appli cation of the entitlement for exemption retrospective to the people to whom it should apply but without all this paraphernalia about valuations which cannot in any sense be accurate anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook has raised a number of issues and Senator Margetts has posed a question to Senator Cook. Essentially, our advice Senator Margetts, if I can also provide an answer to the question you asked Senator Cook, is that, unlike amendment No. 3, this amendment exempts from tax any increase in the value of mining right after budget night 1996. This is inconsistent with the outcome sought from the Senate's amendment of December 1996. In the first part of his remarks Senator Cook seemed to imply that a bona fide prospector was some new feature.
—No, I didn't.

—In that case I take that interjection and I will be interested to read the Hansard on that. For the record, Senator Cook's amendment removes the requirement that a person must be a bona fide prospector at the time when the income is derived. The important part is that this requirement has existed since 1977 when the exemption was introduced.
—Not so.

—That is the advice I have from the officials. You have different advice. I put that on the record. I do not want to misquote you or misinform the Senate, but the advice I have is that this requirement has existed since 1977 when the exemption was introduced.
—Well, how do you explain the Biggs case?

—My advice on the Biggs case is that the case clarifies the basis for determining who is a bona fide prospector. Again, I would want to re‐read the Hansard . You have made your remarks, but that clarifies an issue which you raised and which may have been of interest to senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of the valuation came up. Senator, I have some further advice. The Australian Tax Office states that it has provided guidance to taxpayers on the concept of market value in numerous public rulings, including IT 23/78, which deals with the disposal of mining rights. In all of these rulings, the ATO has referred to market value as the value determined by an open and unrestricted market of willing—but not anxious—informed, independent buyers and sellers. Senator, I think that responds to the issue you raised. The government will not be supporting the amendment for the reasons which I have stated. I think it is time we moved on to debating your third amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 2, page 29 (lines 12 and 13), omit ", and at the time the income was derived,".

I have made all the arguments about this amendment in the debate on the foregoing amendments. I note as well that the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine have indicated support for this amendment. On that basis, I adopt all my previous arguments and ask the chamber to adopt this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not given up, however, Senator. The battle continues over amendment No. 3. Senator Murray, I will address specifically some remarks to you. We have received some additional advice from the officials. We are opposing this amendment for three reasons. Let me state those.

SPEECH.PARA: It removes the requirement that a person must be a bona fide prospector at the time when income is derived. Again, I stress it is a requirement which has existed since the exemption was introduced in 1977. I think that that is an important point. I hope that that will weigh in your considerations on this issue. Secondly, to remove this requirement during the phasing out period is inappropriate and inconsistent with policy which has always applied in respect of the exemption. Finally, it could create potential opportunities for avoidance by entering into deferred payment or contingent contracts for sale.

We are opposing Senator Cook's amendment. We hope that Senator Murray may reconsider his position. After all, we were trying to give effect in all this to the original. However one views the history of this matter, there is no argument that the intention was to give effect to the amendment that was settled by this chamber in December last year. There is no argument on that particular issue.

We oppose the amendment that Senator Cook has brought forward. We hope that Senator Murray may reconsider his position. He is a man of some influence; therefore he may be able to influence his colleagues. I wait to hear with interest your remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —An issue that is clear to me which I think should be clear on the record is in relation to the bona fide prospector provision and the provision that income so derived be recorded in the definition. It still applies up to 20 August 1996. It is only thereafter that that is changed. That is the clear intent of Senator Cook's amendment and the reason we have accepted it. It does not apply prior to 20 August 1996.

—Just so we can fill in some time while our advisers now ponder the comment you made, I will seek some additional advice on that. If you can bear with us, I will seek to respond. It might assist the officials if we make sure that we are going to provide exactly what you seek. Would you mind repeating the comment you made?

—Let me put it in a different way. For someone who was in the industry and was a bona fide prospector and had disposed of their assets in the normal way up to and including 20 August 1996, there is no question that the law, as it always was, applied. For someone subsequent to that date who still has to dispose of their assets, the intention is that the amendment offered by Senator Cook would alter the definition. The reason for that is so that anybody in that circumstance would be capable of enacting a contingent sale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have to say that the initial advice is that what you said the second time around was a bit different from what you said the first time around. I am not trying to frustrate this because this is clearly a very important point. We want to be able to effectively address the issue that you made, but there is a feeling amongst my advisers that there was a difference between your first remarks and your second remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference is that, under your first amendment, you stressed the person had to be a bona fide prospector and they had to be a bona fide prospector at the time the income was derived. That was your original amendment in December 1996. In a sense, we are trying to make that work. It hinges on the issue of bona fide, it seems to me. It seemed to me that you were waiving that particular requirement. I will seek advice on this, but it may therefore be opening up a real problem, I suspect. Senator Cook was going to make some comments, so I shall continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me put you out of any agony you might be in, Minister. The discussions the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and I had in December 1996 which resulted in the final amendment which was accepted by the government and by the Senate hinged on the intention we were trying to achieve at that time, but at no time was it my intention not to allow prospectors after 20 August 1996 who were bona fide prospectors at or before 20 August 1996 to enjoy the full return from their efforts. In my view, Senator Cook's amendment achieves that. I do not intend to alter my position as a result of your statement. We can talk more, if you wish, but the vote is going to go through on my part for amendment No. 3.

—Senator Murray, I think you are playing it a bit tough there. I took you to say that, regardless of any arguments I can produce, you are sticking with your position. For a man like you, that is an unusual position to adopt, I would have to say. Senator, I have always felt that you were accessible to argument. If I misinterpreted you, I would very much like you to correct it. From what you were saying, I took it that, almost regardless of any advice my officers can provide, you will not change your mind.

—Minister, I am trying to be helpful to the Senate. I spent 20 minutes, or whatever it was, with your advisers today on this very point. Regrettably, I have heard nothing from your point of view which alters my view. It is not regardless; it is the fact that I am at the culmination of a long process. You should be glad that you have won two out of the three. By your lights, No. 3 is the best option for you.

—I just have a question for the minister. Minister, as far as I understand the discussion that has gone on between you and Senator Murray, it is clear that last year Senator Murray and the Treasurer got down and nutted out the amendment which then became the majority view of this chamber and amended the bill before the chamber on this section. That it was the work of Senator Murray and the Treasurer, is that a correct understanding of what happened?

—I have been at a number of meetings with Senator Murray and the Treasurer. My view is that this was an amendment essentially drafted by Senator Murray, but we attempted to get it fixed up at a very late stage and on the run. It did not achieve what was expected. Senator Murray can speak for himself on the nature of any agreement, but I am not sure that I can add anything further to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all I needed you to tell me, Minister, because I have in front of me a memorandum of 13 December 1996 signed by Senator Ian Campbell, Senator Winston Crane, Senator Alan Eggleston, Senator Chris Ellison and Senator John Panizza. It has a note at the bottom:

SPEECH.PARA: Sue Knowles is unable to sign this memorandum because she is at sea travelling to the Antarctic.

This memorandum is to the members of the state council of the Western Australian Liberal Party. It claims the aforementioned senators obtained the amendment, not Senator Murray. I think you have just killed that one. It concludes with these words:

BREAK.PARA: The WA senators have welcomed the five-year extension to the deadline as it will enable prospectors to rationalise their leases without undue pressure.
If you persist in your argument, you will render inaccurate that last line, Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard some stunts in my time but, Senator Cook, for an almost distinguished former minister to be carrying on like that—I said that Senator Murray can speak for his memory of the history of this matter. You have obviously acquired some material, and it throws a greater perspective on the considerations.
—You are amending your answer.
—No, I am not amending my answer. If you read the Hansard , I think you will find it is quite consistent.

—I think I am obliged to indicate on the record that I had an amendment and the government said they would like to improve that amendment. I had a meeting with the Treasurer. It was hasty. I am not offended by the fact that neither of us got it right at the time. There was a great deal of pressure. The fact is, at the meeting in the Treasurer's office, we resolved the final amendment that was passed.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Before speaking on my opposition to schedule 10 I would like to make some brief comments about schedule 3 and also ask some questions in relation to schedule 9. Schedule 3 makes changes to the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . I wanted to point out with these minor modifications in the Income Tax Rates Act as yet more wrinkles come to light.

SPEECH.PARA: Do you remember when we dealt with the family tax initiative? It was the Greens (WA) who offered the government a simpler way of achieving the same amount of benefit to families. It was the government choosing to do things in a way which looked as though they were giving people $1,000, even if they were giving them roughly $200, that created the difficulty. Here we have perhaps the first of many endeavours to fix up the problems which occurred because of that desire to make something look like something else.

Basically, this is attempting to pass off a rebate as something else while maintaining a relatively constant $200 benefit regardless of the rate the taxpayer is paying. So it is fiddling with the rates, and we knew it was going to be a constant problem.

In relation to schedule 9, we have increasing age for superannuation contributions. This requires compulsory superannuation payments to continue to be made in respect of people over 65. There is no requirement for people to work until this age. I suspect that this is nevertheless a measure designed to push back retirement age—at least conceptually.

I want to find out and seek some assurance about whether or not there are moves by the coalition to put up the retirement age, particularly considering the fact that they are putting out a policy of running down superannuation for those unemployed after the age of 55. Perhaps we will find a time when people will not be able to choose to retire at 55; they will be required to run down their superannuation and maybe there will be an official retirement age which is after 65. I would like the reassurance that this is not on the books for the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, by this proposal and by increasing the age at which individuals are generally allowed to make superannuation contributions, we are seeking to help those who have had poor access to superannuation in the past. In our view, by providing a longer period in which to accumulate an adequate retirement income, this will benefit women who leave the work force to care for children and it will benefit other individuals whose work force experience is characterised by breaks. This reflects, among other things, the increasing longevity of the work force and will lead, we believe, to an increase in retirement savings. We think that the measures are welcomed and that they reflect current developments. I am not sure, Senator, what more I can add to assist you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not view this measure with concern. As I understand it, at the moment if a person works beyond 65—I have had a case referred to me personally about this matter—they can have SG paid on their behalf up to the age of 70. But if a person is working beyond 65, it is not compulsory, and this is what this change does.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts, I think that the critical issue is the age at which the pension is paid—and that is 65. Any government that wants to tackle that issue—and I certainly would not suggest that Labor would be tackling it, nor would I would want to increase the age at which the government provided that to pensioners. It is 65; it is in statute. I suggest that any government that wants to do that would be very brave indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it to you that there already have been changes to pension age—especially in relation to women moving up from 60. So these questions about general retirement age are not coming out of thin air. I would like to know what the current level of unemployment is for people between the age of 55 and 65, compared to, say, people between 40 and 45. The reason I am asking this is that when someone becomes unemployed after 50 it frequently means that they become unemployable, and the problem increases with age. The treatment of over‐55s, that is, to require them to run down their assets, obviously has to be realistic with the level of employment and unemployment at that age. Do you have any rough figures of the relative levels of employment for those two groups?

—Senator, I do have not have figures with me at present. I am looking to my advisers to see whether they can produce some figures. I do not know whether we can do anything in the dinner break, but we will see whether there is any further information that we can provide. Unusually, I thought that Senator Sherry expressed the issue on retirement age rather well. I do not think I need to add anything further to Senator Sherry's remarks, except that Senator Sherry raised the matter of the SG being payable after 65 and the advice we receive is that this allows the SG to be provided for people up to the age of 70.

—Minister, I just think that this is a rather odd contrast. You are working to create legislative support for those who work beyond 65, and that in fact could be seen as an encouragement. In times of high unemployment that ought to be taken into consideration. For those who are spouses of well‐heeled partners it does seem a bit odd that the treatment of over-55s who would choose to retire is becoming shabbier whilst you are choosing to create incentives for those who might voluntarily choose to work past 65.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —There are options that recognise the diversity among people. There are people who wish to work after 65 and there are those who do not. There are those who would prefer to retire earlier. It is not surprising that we have a measure which encourages greater options.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be some people—and I am sure you have heard of some and we have heard of others—who would prefer as their own option to remain in the work force. That is what they wish to do, but the retirement age for aged pension purposes, as Senator Sherry said, is 65. For women, that age is moving towards 65. I have nothing further to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Except that you have said, Senator Kemp, that the government acknowledges that there would be people below the age of 65 who would like to retire earlier. Could you explain to the Senate what incentives the government is providing for those people who desire to retire but cannot because of the fact that they need to receive income right up until they are 65? Is the government going to provide similar incentives for them to retire early, just as they are proposing to give incentives for those who reach the age of 65 and work until they are 70? I will have a bit more to say about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry mentioned that there were some Treasury people looking at this. This really is one of the most interesting proposals presumably emanating from the fertile Treasury mind, because this particular proposal is going to be a net saving to the government at least in the first two years.

I did see some figures which said that 12 per cent of males eligible for that particular incentive will actually be dead before they receive any payment, but of course they will be working away and paying tax in the meantime. I think that was a very important point that was raised by Senator Margetts. If we cannot have the information from the minister now, I would like to hear what may emerge after dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —That certainly is what we were getting at—that, basically, there seems to be a very odd thing going on in relation to commonsense choices within the community and whether or not the government is making punishments or incentives for certain behaviour to take place. We want to know what the rationale for all that might be at a time of high unemployment and when the youth are actually being blamed for being young and unemployed. I would appreciate further information perhaps after the dinner break.

SPEECH.PARA: I might at this stage mention my proposal for schedule 10, which is to oppose the schedule. This is basically looking at the whole issue of whether you can pick out a particular group of otherwise fortunate people and say, `We're going to give you a special deal for putting aside money as potentially a tax dodge and give you the taxpayers' money to do it.' We would like to see that whole schedule looked at. There are a number of amendments to alter this schedule and they are only pertinent if our attempt to oppose the schedule fails.

Fundamentally, we see the spouse superannuation contribution as a perk for the rich and as the pursuit of the coalition's so-called family policy, which seems to consist of trying to bribe or penalise people into a structure where one partner is out working and the other is at home—no marks for guessing which gender goes where. For the less intelligent, I refer them to the family tax initiative, where the government makes clear that the purpose of the partner staying home is to `look after the kids', though this measure does not have that effect. I oppose this measure on both grounds.

I am disgusted at the way this government rewards the wealthy while cutting back services used by the poor and the middle class. It is worse when this government pretends to be pursuing the rich while calling all its perks for the rich `a benefit for the battlers'—ordinary workers in the case of the savings scheme, small businesses with the CGT and spouses at home, for which we read women in this measure.

I dislike the way that, in this case, often the media seems to repeat what the government says without considering whether or not what it is saying is true. This is not a measure for spouses. It is a measure for the rich, so they can arrange their affairs to pay a little less tax. Even with the amendments that may be made—putting an income and assets test on the taxpayer and limiting the operation to the unmarried, and therefore, less protected spouses—this will still be a measure that will support primarily upper management, people with a far higher income than most. We would like to say that we oppose the schedule and we recommend that other senators do so.

In a vacuum, it may be a good thing that these management executives be given incentives to give superannuation to their spouses, but we are not here in a vacuum. It is a proposal to give $38 million in tax breaks to the well-off, and it must be put in the context of cuts to health, education programs and so on that will affect every parent. It must be put in the context of changes, the intent of which is to make young people economically dependent on their parents until they are in their 20s. Those changes will affect all parents, whether or not they are well-off, and it will affect single parents and divorced and separated parents. This little perk goes only to the well‐off and only to families living together.

On page 86, the explanatory memorandum makes it very clear that the definition of spouse does not include a partner who does not live with their husband `even though legally married'. So we are not talking about providing independence. The Greens (WA) oppose schedule 10 in the following terms:

BREAK.PARA: (4) Schedule 10, page 61 (line 2) to page 64 (line 17), TO BE OPPOSED .

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 7.00 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, there is no incentive at all for a rich person to provide superannuation for even a married partner if the taxpayer is living somewhere else for work reasons or if the partners are separated, perhaps trying to work things out. There is no incentive for providing anything to a separated partner, even if that partner is not working because they have the children. It is not a measure which many feminists in our society would think would be worthy of support because it provides a level of independence, because it specifically does not do that—it cannot do that. It is not a measure to look after people. The tax revenue that is deferred here would be better collected and used to provide for all families, not just rich families. I ask other senators to seriously consider whether or not it would be better to provide benefits for all families than simply to support the rich and only the rich in a lifestyle that the government finds socially appealing—the one where wives stay at home with the kids.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, we are moving a long way from the traditional notion of government providing universal benefits for all. Such benefits are generally acknowledged as minimum standards for society. Such measures are being dismantled and replaced, either with nothing or with heavily targeted charity measures which, increasingly, for people to receive they need to show they are totally impoverished.

In the case of older unemployed people over 55 with some superannuation, the government demands that they use those resources and totally impoverish themselves before they can even get unemployment benefit. This is breadline mentality, and guess what? It creates consumer uncertainty—I put that as an aside. It counters the notion that unemployment is meant to provide for people in transition from one job to another. Unfortunately, there are few jobs available. Dumping all the rhetoric, the statistics show that, where jobs are available, unemployment in almost any time or country falls to around 1.5 per cent—that being people in transition from job to job. Those people are actually unemployable. This is not the case in this country today.

We are winding back almost all universal benefits, all the minimum social standards. Things we saw as basic provisions of any advanced nation are disappearing: a free education through secondary school for all, a free tertiary education based on merit, a medical system that seeks to assure that no‐one is denied health simply through lack of money, and that health is a provision made by society and of benefit to everyone in society.

These social ideals seem to be going. We see a huge push to user pays. The corollary of that term is, `If you can't pay, you can't use,' which may sound fair until you realise it is being applied to primary and secondary education. A GST will make it worse: everyone must consume to survive. Clearly, everyone cannot get an income. The push for so‐called labour market reform is designed to assure fewer people get a decent income.

In this context, I cannot see how it is remotely ethical to cut back on revenue, to help out those with surplus cash. I do not agree with the social objective that seems to be pushed here. Some form of marriage is fine and a valid personal choice. It is a fulfilling one for some people. I do not believe that it is available to all people without economic hardship and I do not believe that this is a social objective that should be supported through the tax system.

I believe this measure is also designed to support a move away from a universal pension and towards self‐funded income based retirement. There is no obligation here to create a superannuation fund for a non‐working spouse, so far.
