But given the general trend towards obligatory superannuation provision or other retirement savings, the push for making retirement savings unavailable until retirement age and the desire of government to shed social responsibilities I think is a move towards a two‐tiered retirement system. It is a particular worry in light of other moves to up the retirement age.

BREAK.PARA: This is our preferred option: throw the schedule out and say to the government, `This isn't good enough. You cannot impose Lyons Forum values on the rest of society, providing taxpayers' money to do it. You cannot do that in 1997.' I urge all senators to oppose this schedule.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will not be opposing schedule 10 and, therefore, we will not be supporting the Greens amendment which is effectively to oppose schedule 10. We have some concerns about the spouse rebate proposal as it relates to equity issues. I made some comment on that in my speech on the second reading. Labor will be moving an amendment and I will make some comment about that when we get to it. Our preferred option is to seek to amend schedule 10 to improve it and refocus it in a more equitable and fair way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to say similarly. I agree with Senator Margetts's observations about the direction in which the tax system is, in rhetoric, being pushed to support a particular kind of family, but in reality it is really heavily skewed towards higher income earners, because they are the only ones who will be able to find the amount that is going to be paid into the account on behalf of a spouse. Rather than say that we do not agree with the principle of providing an opportunity for this to happen at all, I agree with Labor's proposal which is to target it more fairly by using the same tests that the government used; in other words, to use the same means test as the family tax payments and the same assets test as is used in determining social security benefits. At the moment, as it stands we have something like $58 a week being able to be paid in, that is $3,000 a year, and you really have to ask yourself: what kinds of families can support that?

SPEECH.PARA: While I agree with Senator Margetts's comments, I would prefer not to oppose the whole schedule but just work at better targeting the incentive through the Labor Party's amendments. I would like to ask the government a question. I made some comments earlier, I think, about what this is going to add to national savings. Can you tell us? There has been no modelling provided. Your arguments as to why we should do these things always seem to be predicated upon it assisting national savings. You have been unable so far, Minister, to provide any details about modelling and how much will be added to national savings as a result of this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I think the substantive debate will occur on the next amendment. Unlike Senator Kernot, I am finding it pretty hard to agree with practically anything that Senator Margetts said. I would have to say the assumption seemed to be totally wrong; it seemed to be a misreading of the nature of the measure we stated in our election policy.
—Just because it's in your election policy doesn't mean it's perfect.
—Senator Kernot does not like me saying something was an election policy. It is—
—But it doesn't mean it's perfect.

—Do not get excited. It was in the policy when we went to the election. You do not agree with it. You are the person who wants to keep everybody honest. We will just record for the record that you and I differ on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The intention of this rebate is to provide an incentive for people to provide superannuation support for spouses who do not earn any income or earn a low income. In the majority of cases, I suspect, the spouses will be women who have had a break from full‐time work to raise their children. This measure is consistent with the objectives of the government's superannuation policy, because women make up the majority of older people in our society and often have limited access to superannuation. It is particularly designed to assist women.

Senator Margetts, we have to recognise that modern society is made up of great diversity. This is an attempt by the government to address what we see as a gap in the superannuation policy and to encourage provision for low income spouses. It is not a construct of a Lyons Forum or anything else; it is essentially designed to fill what the government saw as a gap. The government went to the election with it as part of its superannuation policy. The reason this measure is now before the chamber is to give effect to that policy commitment. The substantive debate will come on the amendments but, Senator Margetts, I put on the record that we do not agree with you. We support the bill standing as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice, Senator Kemp, that you did not address the question that Senator Kernot raised: what will the modelled increase in saving be as a consequence of this measure? It is not the first time you have been asked about this issue in respect of a range of the superannuation reforms that you have announced or legislated.

SPEECH.PARA: On a number of occasions I have asked you for the modelling relating to this and other changes to superannuation; it is not as though the modelling has not been done. I do not have this year's budget announcements on superannuation with me, but I do know that there is an estimate of the total increase in saving that will result from changes to superannuation. If we have an estimate of the total increase in savings that will result, then this measure, along with a number of other measures, must have been input to the RIM Task Force model on the effect of savings with respect to the various superannuation changes that have either been legislated for or been announced.

I put it to you, Senator Kemp: is it that you are simply afraid to disclose what the changes to saving will be as a consequence of these measures? We do not want the overall increase in saving; we want the specific increase in savings that will result from this measure and, for that matter, any other measure, because Labor will contend that the reality is that any increase in savings from this and other changes is negligible—if, indeed, there is any; it is all as a result of the increase in the superannuation guarantee which is currently six per cent rising to nine per cent over the next four years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment. The minister obviously has some comments to respond to in relation to what Senator Sherry said, but perhaps I will give him a job lot and give him some more to comment on.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp mentioned that it is designed for low income spouses. I really do think that that deserves a response. Low income? We are talking about a society where the vast majority of people can barely afford what is being taken out of their salary for compulsory superannuation levies and other things that are required to be taken out. In many cases, they thought superannuation was about them being able to choose what to do with the money that they have taken out or sometimes volunteered to have taken out of their spendable income. They are finding that that will not be the case under the coalition government; that you are saying that more and more you will tell them what to do with that money, which will be to provide for their own income if they happen to become unemployed at 55.

We are talking about people who have taken a cut in pay, in reality, to provide for their own retirement. The vast majority of people can barely afford a cut in their own spendable income. In fact, it looks like, over time, it will replace the right to a pension.

You are saying that you are benefiting low income spouses but the reality is that you are providing a benefit for people who can afford to make not only a healthy superannuation contribution for themselves but a substantial contribution for their spouses. That is not low income. You might be talking about a person in a family who is not earning another income perhaps supplementing a substantial first income. That might be worth while looking at. But we are not talking about low income families here; we are talking about people who would like to minimise their tax. I object to the fact that you are pushing this as a low income benefit. It is not. It is something which people on middle range to upper range incomes will be able to access, not people on lower incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the reality is that you and I march to a different drum on this issue. I find myself in many ways in profound disagreement with the views you are putting.
—Who do you think could afford it?

—I do not have any figures I can give you on the impact on national savings. We argued the case for this in our policy on superannuation. It addressed a gap, as we saw it, in superannuation provision.
—You can't even prove that it adds to national savings.
—I remember you standing in front of the sign saying `Keep the bastards honest'. I record this as another example, that is all.
—Well, okay, tell us what the facts are.

—I have not got any figure I can give you in relation to the impact on national savings. The argument we adduced in favour of this was that we saw a gap in the superannuation policy. It assists women who are either not in the work force or who have a low income. We believe it is a measure which is welcomed and we are seeking to give effect to this election policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of points on the issues that Senator Kemp has addressed. The issue of any increase in savings level—particularly as the budget paper claims that there will be an increase in private savings as a result of this measure and others—is an important one.

SPEECH.PARA: I put Senator Kemp on notice that Labor would expect to see the breakdown of the increase in savings. We know it is being modelled. We think you are afraid to show us the detail. We would expect to see that in respect of a major initiative such as the savings rebate which was announced in the budget, because we know that is being modelled.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know that that adds nothing, too.
—I agree with Senator Kernot. We certainly suspect that it adds nothing, or very little, to any increase in private savings.

SPEECH.PARA: On the issue of election promises, Senator Kemp, you had an election promise to deliver the co‐contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —You lost the election.
—We did lose the election—
—But you are picking and choosing.

—Exactly, Senator Kernot. The minister picks and chooses the promises that he seeks to justify, depending on the circumstances. It is not as though the government did not have the money, because the fascinating issue about the co‐contribution, which is a guaranteed payment into the superannuation of almost every Australian worker, is that it was funded in the forward estimates from last year's budget. The cost was delivered into a savings rebate.

SPEECH.PARA: I share Senator Margetts's concern about the theme of this government's approach. It was clearly enunciated in the budget papers, which used the term `universal incentive'. This measure is justified on the basis of a universal incentive for women, just as the savings rebate is justified on the basis of universal incentive. However, I make the point to the committee that universal incentive is not universal coverage. The reality of universal incentive is that those who have the money, who have the disposable income to take advantage of the incentive, are generally high‐income earners.

The evidence clearly demonstrates that this theme of moving away from universal coverage towards universal incentive will benefit higher income earners. It is not going to benefit lower income earners. If this measure passes, in whatever final form, it will be interesting to analyse just who benefits in terms of the income of the persons who pay the 18 per cent rebate on behalf of their spouses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, has an amendment been moved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —No. The question before the committee is that schedule 10 stand as printed.

—I indicate that I will be supporting schedule 10. I know that there have been and are an enormous number of anomalies in this area of superannuation which need to be addressed and need to be addressed urgently. In the area of superannuation for women, the book Women in Super is very interesting. One of the submittees to the book says:

SPEECH.PARA: The exclusion of women who perform the unpaid work of our society is an issue that falls into the `too hard basket'. Diana Olsberg sees a great problem in the way in which women's work is valued. `Only certain women's work is valued in terms of the allocation of superannuation. Women caring for children, and increasingly, women out of the paid workforce to care for elderly and infirm relatives, are devalued. Somehow, ways must be found to recognise paid and unpaid work. It is this type of work which is unpaid at the time which denies future quality of life. Unpaid work should somehow or other attract paid superannuation.'

The capacity for people who are not in paid employment to contribute to superannuation was raised during a number of the interviews and there was agreement that this along with many other `women's issues', would in the future be applicable to both men and women.

Do we have to wait until that time occurs? Many of us know people where the homemaker is actually the male, so let us just use the word `spouse'. In the situation where both major parties are promoting this idea of superannuation for retirement—there should be contributions to superannuation in order to ensure that persons live with some sort of dignity in their retirement which would also save money on pensions—why should certain women because they are doing unpaid work or certain men because they are doing unpaid work, which one sometimes feels is far more important than the type of work that we are doing and being paid for, be at a disadvantage when retirement age comes? That is a real problem.

I suppose the minister might say in relation to schedule 10, `Well, we are allowing for such contributions to be recognised for the purposes of taxation.' Okay, that is probably a start. I know there are vertical inequities in that, but at least let us have a look at the need for horizontal equity. The principle of horizontal equity asks why a family with dual income, on two incomes, should be at a greater advantage than a family on one income, when the spouse is employed in one of the most important jobs that a person could do in this nation—and that is the nurturing of children.

Even at the level we are talking about in this particular legislation, why should we deny horizontal equity so far as superannuation is concerned in that particular area? That is why I am going to vote for schedule 10. Not because it is perfect; it is certainly not perfect. It is very imperfect when it comes to vertical superannuation equity for spouses, but at least it goes some of the way. I will be looking forward, as other colleagues have said, to other government initiatives which focus on the question of vertical tax equity as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of unpaid work is extremely important. If you look at the concerns that Green parties all throughout the world have been interested in over time, certainly unpaid work is amongst one of the prime issues of equity and justice. However, we are not talking about unpaid work. There is no measure of unpaid work here. We might be talking about groups of people whose income is such that they probably have a high percentage of nannies, housekeepers and gardeners, but we are not talking about paying unpaid work. We are actually talking about providing a tax incentive to minimise tax basically for high income families. It is not related to unpaid work at all; it is not related to need; and it is not universal, as has been mentioned by Senator Sherry. I would be the first in line to be cheering any real and genuine initiatives that recognise and deal with the issue of unpaid work. But this is not it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up a couple of the points that Senator Harradine has raised, because I have certainly thought about these points deeply in the last few years when considering our attitude to superannuation. I accept, Senator Harradine, that in our supporting schedule 10 we are establishing horizontal equity in that, at least notionally and on paper, a low income spouse can receive a superannuation contribution. But, as you have indicated, you are sceptical about the vertical equity that will result.

SPEECH.PARA: In one sense, with this issue of how to take account of the homemaker's contribution—whether it is male or female—to `work' in a retirement incomes policy, the current age pension does that because it is a guaranteed minimum retirement income for a person who is not involved in the paid work force at all and who could never hope to accrue sufficient superannuation which is linked to the paid work force. So society does take that into account, at least to some extent.

How you can carry that principle further I am not sure. It is certainly an issue that I have thought about and that does perplex me, but it is a problem that all retirement income schemes right around the world have. All retirement income schemes are—at least to a significant extent—based on your time in the work force income, which is always a major problem with any system based on that concept. At least in Australia superannuation has that principle in part.

The critical issue is to ensure that the funding of the basic pension is maintained at the level of 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings. That to me is one of the critical issues we have to face, given the era of at least lower taxes, in whatever form that is delivered. Also, Australia currently has 1.7 million people who are over the age of 65 and it is estimated that by about 2050 there will be six million people who are over the age of 65. As a proportion of the population, that is one in 10 rising to just over two in 10 and that is a very significant demographic change which has enormous implications for retirement incomes. But that is just a bit of reflecting or philosophising on our approach to this long‐term problem. I will conclude my remarks there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their comments. Some of the issues that have been raised are very important issues and they touch on, but certainly go wider than, the specific issue which is before us in the chamber, and which we now have to decide on.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this measure goes some way to addressing some of the concerns that Senator Harradine has raised and, to the extent that I could get a theme out of Senator Sherry's comments, it goes some of the way to addressing some of those concerns as well.

I urge the Senate to support the measure that has been put forward by the government. We think it is an important measure; it was flagged in our election policy, and I hope the Senate will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say to Senator Harradine, who has gone, that this is not about unpaid work. I want to add to those comments. The only thing different that I would add is that this is about giving some, mainly women, an opportunity to have retirement income based on the income of their working spouse. The reality is that those women are in a relationship with spouses who earn enough money to be able to do that, so it is not about low‐income or even middle‐income Australians. That is the point that we are taking issue with. It is not a recognition of unpaid work, and it is not low income.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may suit the convenience of the committee to reconsider schedule 10. That can be done by leave at the request of the Greens and the opposition. Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 10, item 1, page 61 (after line 19), after paragraph (1)(b), insert:

TAB.TAB: (ba) the taxpayer's assessable income is less than $65,000, increased by $3,000 for each dependent child; and

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Schedule 10, item 1, page 6 (line 20), at the end of subsection (1), add:

TAB.TAB: ; and (d) the value of the taxpayer's assets does not exceed $376,750.

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Schedule 10, item 1, page 61 (after line 22), after subsection (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) For the purpose of paragraph (1)(d), the value of the assets of a taxpayer is taken to include:

TAB.TAB: (a) the value of the assets of the taxpayer's spouse; and
(b) the value of the assets of the taxpayer's dependent child or children.

PARA.TAB: (1B) Any assets that are to be disregarded in valuing a taxpayer's assets are to be determined in accordance with section 1118 of the Social Security Act 1991 .
(1C) An asset that is subject to a charge or encumbrance is to be valued in accordance with section 1121 of the Social Security Act 1991 .

(1D) The amount referred to in paragraph (1)(d) is indexed annually in line with CPI increases, to be calculated in accordance with sections 1191 to 1194 of the Social Security Act 1991 . The first indexation is to take place on 1 July 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendments 6 to 8 go to the question of vertical equity that Senator Harradine has touched on. I have to say that vertical equity is not a term I would use too often, but it flows on from his concern about horizontal equity. In supporting schedule 10, we have established the very clear principle of horizontal equity—to use Senator Harradine's terminology. We have already made comment that the reality is that the persons who have significant disposable income in which to make up to $3,000 a year of contributions are highly likely to be higher income earners. So that does not ensure vertical equity.

Our amendments will introduce an income and assets test on the contributing spouse's eligibility. In regard to the income test, to claim the rebate, the contributing spouse's income must be less than $65,000, plus $3,000 for each dependent child. This is the same as the eligibility requirement to claim part (b) of the family tax initiative assistance, which I am sure Senator Kemp is thoroughly across.

TALK.START.PARA: —About consistency.

—Yes, that is right—`consistency'. In regard to the assets test, the combined assets of a couple must not exceed $376,750. Again, this is the same assets test requirement as that used to determine family payment eligibility.
—Consistency again.

—Thank you, Senator Kernot—`Consistency again'. This amount is indexed annually to the CPI. The first increase is to take place on 1 July 1998. Any assets to be disregarded in valuing a taxpayer's assets are to be made by reference to section 1118 of the Social Security Act, and this is the assets test that applies to determine the eligibility for family payment.

SPEECH.PARA: So in our approach to this we are attempting to ensure some level of equity and fairness in the application of the spouse rebate. It would save the government some money. I do not know how much, because certainly the opposition—and apparent from the government—does not have very detailed data on this particular measure. So we would urge the Senate to ensure some level of vertical equity and fairness in respect of this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in the second reading debate, I support the ALP move to limit the opportunity to use this government measure simply as another tax loophole accessible by the rich, because it is a tax deduction ultimately dependent on high income. I support the move to include a means test applied to the taxpayer as well as their spouse. There is really little need to give tax breaks to rich people to provide for their spouses. They can, and do, provide adequately. If they do not, there is general legal recourse open to at least the married spouses of such rich people.

SPEECH.PARA: I have opposed this schedule, as honourable senators know. Given that I have been unsuccessful in eliminating it, I do seek to limit its ambit as a means for the well-off to rearrange family assets for the purpose of tax minimisation. A minimal means of doing this is to exclude the very rich from a scheme through an income and assets test. I will support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting opposition amendments Nos 6 to 8 for a number of reasons. We think in these circumstances, given the nature of superannuation, a means test on the contributor would discriminate against the low income partner. This measure is an incentive to encourage superannuation support for low income spouses; that is the purpose of the measure.

SPEECH.PARA: In the majority of cases, the low income spouses will be women. But, as Senator Harradine mentioned, there are increasing numbers of men who would see themselves remaining at home. The reality at present is that in the majority of cases the low income spouses will be women who have probably had to break from work to raise children.

In the event of a family break, it is possible that the low income partner may be left with little or no superannuation. The major benefit in the form of superannuation support goes to the low income spouse and this spouse is appropriately means tested. In means testing the contributing spouse, you are penalising, in effect, the low income spouse.

Finally, I understand from the tax advisers who are with us that asset testing is not a concept that is commonly used in tax law. To introduce asset testing would be complex in this case and expensive.

So, as I said, the government will not be supporting the measure. We do not support the proposition that somehow you can say, `You can rely on your husband's super,' or, `You can rely on your wife's super,' if the male is the low income spouse. We will not be supporting the amendments which have been proposed by Senator Sherry.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to raise a point of order. A problem which will be apparent to most people who were listening in the chamber has emerged in relation to the last motion, which I think needs to be sorted out. The issue may be one of pairing. I seek the indulgence of the Senate. I might ask the whip to see whether he can enlighten us as to the precise nature of the problem. We could then have a discussion as to where we proceed from there.
—by leave—In my records here, Senator Lightfoot had a pair until seen. Obviously, my writing was not seen. My deputy sent someone out when he should not have.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This does raise the issue of what we are going to do for the rest of the evening if the government has got a problem with its numbers.
—by leave—We have not got a problem with numbers. We have five pairs at the moment. Unfortunately, the deputy whip sent one person out when he was not aware that there was a pair given to our side.

—by leave—On the point of order, to assist the Senate, as I understand it the normal procedure is that if a senator who should have been in the chamber was not—as appears to be the case, because Senator Lightfoot was not paired for that division in the arrangement between the two parties—it is normal for the senator to come in and make a personal explanation and for the government then to move to recommit the vote if that is what they wish to do. I do not know why we are having this debate now. It is really in the government's court; it is not for us to tell the government what to do. We either move on, or the government seeks to follow the normal procedure that they have had to follow on so many occasions in the recent past.

—by leave—It is difficult to bring in the person who was paired, but I am sure that Senator O'Chee, who was sent out, would be more than happy to come in and make an explanation as to why he was sent out.

—by leave—What has happened is that Senator Lightfoot in the book is paired until seen. I was led to believe that he was seen. He was not seen, and I sent Senator O'Chee out and I should not have. It is as simple as that. I seek leave to recommit the division.
—You are seeking leave of the committee to recommit the previous division. Is leave granted for that recommittal? Leave is granted.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 10, page 61 (after line 5), before item 1, insert:
1A Section 6 (definition of spouse )

PARA.TAB: Repeal the definition, substitute:

TAB.TAB: spouse , in relation to a person, includes another person who, although not legally married to the person and regardless of whether that other person is of the same sex as or opposite sex to the person, lives with the person on a bona fide domestic basis in a marriage‐like relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 10, item 1, page 63 (lines 2 to 4), omit paragraph (a), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (a) includes another person who, although not legally married to the taxpayer and regardless of whether that person is of the same sex as or opposite sex to the taxpayer, lives with the taxpayer on a bona fide domestic basis in a marriage‐like relationship;

SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Assessment Act, the bible of personal tax, defines `spouse' as anyone living in a marriage‐like relationship whether or not they are married. The tax act, like the Social Security Act, looks at realities in society most of the time rather than seeking to preserve the sanctity of marriage. It is a secular thing and recognises that the key element of concern in taxation is the economic relationship between people and the social bonds that create expectations of economic cooperation and mutual support.

In this sense, the tax act supports a fairly realistic reflection of society. It acknowledges that people live together with bonds of love, cooperation and mutual support whether or not they are legally married. Those bonds are no less real and no less material because they are not sanctified in a religious rite. This has been recognised by people in general for millennia. Living together predates marriage. The understanding of common law marriage has been applied in the past though it is superseded here by the more defined definition of de facto marriage, a marriage in fact though not formalised.

The tax act recognises most such unions. It should really recognise all such unions. Unfortunately, it says a spouse is a person living with a taxpayer in a bona fide domestic relationship as husband or wife. Someone decided that a husband is a male, a wife female and that a person cannot live as a husband to a man or a wife to a woman and therefore interpreted a very broad definition to exclude same sex couples.

On what basis are they excluded? It is clear, even to the most homophobic in our society, that same sex couples really do live together in love and in relationships that are fundamentally no different from relationships of opposite sex couples in any social or economic way. Same sex partners make life plans, buy houses, raise children, support each other, look after each other when sick, buy furniture together and live lives as couples. They live together, some in bliss, some in strife, just like opposite sex couples. Like opposite sex couples, some are better at fidelity, some cheat and some make conscious choices to live more open sexual lives. The key phrase is `like opposite sex couples'.

Diversity exists regardless of gender, just as love and bonding, romance and living as life partners exists regardless of gender. The key thing is that, economically, and in fundamental social terms, there is no point in discriminating between couples on the basis of gender. Such discrimination should not be in law. There is no discrimination that says couples have to be of the same religion, race, economic or educational background or blood type. Why gender?

It is time to eliminate this discrimination from the law. I do not really think it was ever intended to be in the tax law given the fairly careful non-gendered language. `Taxpayer' is not a gender term. `Spouse' is not a gender term. `Bona fide domestic relationship' is not gendered. When I first read the definition of spouse, I for one could not see why same sex couples were not already included. It was explained to me that they were excluded due to the interpretation of the term `husband and wife', an interpretation that does not allow for the cognitive leap that a woman may be the wife of a female partner. They may act as wives to each other and as husbands too, just as people say a single parent must be both mother and father to their child regardless of their gender.

My amendment would make a more inclusive definition clear. Spouse should include same sex relationships as well as de facto opposite sex relationships. It cannot currently include de jure relationships because we have made it illegal for same sex couples to marry. We have prevented these people from making those kinds of legal, spiritual bonds.

I know there is no unanimity on this issue, even in the gay and lesbian community. Some do not wish to be included as couples and fear that, if same sex couples are recognised, they will be so included against their will. Of course, not all opposite sex people in relationships wish to be considered couples and some are so considered in law against their will. I suggest that this is an issue to look into in terms of our treatment of all couples rather than an excuse to continue to discriminate against same sex couples.

The push for legal recognition of couple status allows people to be recognised. It does not force people to be couples or have the kind of relationships that include making life plans together. What legal recognition would do is begin to overturn the type of systematic discrimination that leads a same sex spouse to be disinherited on the event of a partner's death and a challenge by a family member of their spouse on the basis that they legally cannot be married or cannot be considered to have a de facto relationship and therefore cannot be considered a spouse with a spouse's right to joint property.

This is in spite of the fact they may have lived openly together, bought property together, raised children together and been seen in the community as having a relationship in all ways equivalent to at least de facto marriage. They may even have been religiously married. All that is currently taken as having no legal standing and that is unjust and wrong.

BREAK.PARA: A legal recognition of same sex relationships would begin to reverse this kind of discrimination where a spouse of 25 years, married religiously and clearly identified in the community as partners in a life relationship, cannot get to see their partner in a hospital after a car accident because they are `not related'. There are dozens of examples of places where discrimination is applied on a fairly systematic basis—the treatment of life insurance, superannuation and in various aspects of relations—because, legally, same sex partners cannot be considered even to have a de facto relationship in spite of the fact that even homophobes today generally recognise that such relationships do exist and in spite of specific cases where it is clear such relationships exist and the community accepts that the people concerned are in such a relationship.

Yet nothing can be done because such relationships are legally defined out of existence. It would not take much to include these people with the inclusion of a specific phrase saying it applied to people regardless of respective gender. I do think it needs to be that specific, given the legal loading of terms like `husband', `wife' and `marriage'. I commend my amendment to the Senate. I do not think we can fail to support this amendment and still claim to support an internationally accepted notion of human rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by the Greens (WA) propose that all references in the income tax law to spouses include same sex de facto spouses. This would be a very major change in tax policy and it would have very significant unquantified financial implications in this case, unless Senator Kemp could enlighten us.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor will not be supporting the amendments as moved by the Greens. If there is a case for this type of reform, we believe it should be done on a considered basis after an analysis of the implications across a range of government legislation. It should not be done on the basis of what is an ad hoc approach to particular provisions as they are moved in legislation that we consider from time to time.

BREAK.PARA: If there is a case for reform—and I think there should be a careful analysis and study done of the case for reform—it should be carried out on that basis. For those reasons, Labor will not be supporting the Greens' amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting amendments Nos 1 and 3 because they are consistent with our support for this across a range of legislation. As you say, Senator Sherry, I do not think anybody else is going to propose a detailed analysis of this. That is why I think it is appropriate for us to recognise this as we go.

—The government will not be supporting this measure. The change that has been proposed by the Greens (WA) goes way beyond the scope of the measure we are debating. It would be a very major change to the lax law, as Senator Sherry said. We will not be supporting the measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry said some rather disturbing things in his speech, and I just want to address them. The fact that Senator Kemp has agreed with him makes it even worse, but I suppose it is understandable. They say it is about a change in tax policy. But, no, it is not. It is about changing the way we treat people, changing the way we recognise people in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not expect to see much written in the tax policies of particular parties in respect of the groups they would exclude. You generally do not write down and define the people you do not think fit in as human beings. I do not think it is about financial implications. You do not make a tax assessment of whether you think people have human rights. At some stage you have to start looking at the words that are used in legislation, instead of going along with what is put there, and, sometimes deliberately, you have to start working on changing it.

Yes, perhaps it should be done, and I would like to think that the Labor Party would at some stage support a systematic review of language within legislation. But there are anomalies. If we do not pick them up, if we do not start challenging them, nothing will ever be done. If Senator Sherry is saying that the Labor Party will at some stage address this, I will look forward to seeing it. I still urge the committee to support these amendments. I am grateful to the Australian Democrats for their support on these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —To correct Senator Margetts, the budget implications are not an overriding matter although that is certainly something that you would have to take into consideration. But, as I said, if there were to be a change in approach in this area, it should be conducted after a proper review of such a change and all its consequences. Part of that consideration—and I do not think it would be the major consideration, Senator Margetts—would be the effect on the budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 10, item 1, page 61 (line 20), at the end of subsection (1), add:

TAB.TAB: ; and (d) the spouse is not legally married to the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure would further limit the availability of the tax rebate to the wealthy. I understand that the avowed intention of the measure is to provide for a dependent or partially dependent spouse on reaching retirement age. Since a spouse is generally provided for, whether or not they have personal superannuation when they reach retirement age, simply because they remain a spouse and continue living in a house and sharing everything with their partner, it really does not matter in whose name the superannuation resides.

There is one exception. If a dependent spouse is separated from their working or formerly working partner, they may wish to have some independent source of income. Also, if the spouse of a dependent person denies or limits access to funds, that dependent person may want independent income. Otherwise, in most relationships a joint income may be fine.

Where a person with money denies or limits a spouse access to that money, it is possible in the case of separation or divorce for the spouse to take legal recourse to obtain a portion of the income and/or a share of the assets. It is also possible to take such measures in the case of a de facto marriage where there are children from the marriage. It is my understanding that such income is not as secure being tied to the dependency of the children. In other words, a married spouse will always have legal recourse to claim a share of income and assets of the marriage both within marriage and in the case of marriage breakdown.

So for a married spouse there seems little need for a measure to ensure that they have individual superannuation. The area where provision for an independent retirement income becomes important is in the case of a de facto spouse, particularly one without children or one whose children have reached or nearly reached the age of independence, which, under the Family Law Act, now seems significantly less than the assumption of independence under things like Austudy regulations.

If the government is legitimate about supporting women who are separated, I would say the vulnerable women are precisely those who are not married. While it is not certain that a married spouse will get half the assets in decisions under the Family Law Act, decisions which take all assets including a husband's superannuation into account, the precedent under family law is that in most cases a de jure spouse does get a significant portion of the assets and income.

I would also like bring up a concern raised with me by some women's groups. The normal practice, since superannuation assets cannot be split, in the event of a breakdown of marriage, is to award the superannuation assets to the husband and the house to the wife. It was raised as a potential downside of the government's scheme that provision by a spouse of superannuation assets for the woman may result in the sale of the house and the splitting of that asset. This would mean that the wife would lose the house and have less in liquid assets since they cannot access the superannuation their spouse contributed until they reach at least 55. I am not certain of what the outcome will be and I guess we will have to wait for the first court cases to see what it will be in the case of a ruling, but they have raised these issues with me and I express some concern.

They certainly do not want to say that the woman having superannuation is a bad thing, but they also do not want it to result in unintended penalties. I wonder whether the minister would be able to tell me what the ramifications are likely to be for distribution of property in the event of separation where a person has contributed to a married spouse's superannuation. I would also like to know what the general practice and precedents are in relation to distribution of property in a separation between de facto spouses, particularly where there are no children of the marriage, as that term is defined in the Family Law Act.

I believe that this is a highly dubious measure for most people in Australia, and since it comes from a revenue base it comes at the expense of other, potentially far more beneficial, programs. That is why I took issue with Senator Harradine saying that if the government wants to be generous, then let them. They are generous at the expense of other groups who may well need the revenue measures far more.

But if it is to be provided as an incentive at the expense of revenue for the provision of support of dependant spouses in event of separation, as the government has argued, then I would think the measure should be targeted at those most at risk. These are the de facto spouses—not necessarily the married spouses of the people who are able to make those sorts of contributions. My amendment would ensure that this most vulnerable group is the one that is targeted and I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just make the brief observation, and Senator Margetts can correct me if I am wrong, that I think that the effect of what you are proposing asks us to discriminate in favour of de facto couples instead of treating them equally, which is what we have been in favour of in supporting various amendments that you have moved in the past. We would be of the view that while the Family Law Act and the courts certainly have made some progress, and we agree that they have a way to go, we would prefer to attack this issue still through family law processes rather than active discrimination in this case in favour of de factos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, I think, has summed up one major reason for taking a different approach from the Greens. The issue of the splitting of superannuation in the event of the breakdown of a relationship is a very complex issue. I understand Senator Kemp might be able to inform us—the Attorney‐General, I think, is undertaking some sort of review of this issue generally at the present time. As I understand it, on the dissolution of a relationship, the Family Court does calculate the total assets—that is, house and superannuation of the couple—and split them down the middle. But the difficulty is that the Family Court cannot split the superannuation fund. The superannuation fund cannot be accessed; it cannot be split between the two parties legally.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts, I think, is correct when she says there are a number of effects. One, of course, is that one of the partners, and it will usually be a woman, if she is awarded the property, in order to obtain some income, sells the property. There are a range of social and economic problems associated with that. I might say often the person, and it is generally the male because of the background associated with superannuation, keeps the superannuation and, in fact, often takes out a loan to pay the balance—if there is a balance—to his ex‐partner.

It is a very complex issue. It is an issue that does need a coordinated policy approach. For that reason, and the reason that Senator Kernot has raised, I do not think this is the correct way to deal with this matter. If think that if we are dealing with division of superannuation assets in respect to the ending of a relationship, Labor's approach would be that we should consider that issue in the context of family law, and we should consider all of the difficulties associated with making sure there is a fair and equitable distribution of superannuation assets on the dissolution of a relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess the main reason for putting this amendment is to draw attention to the fact that there are anomalies in the system which this measure by the government probably will make worse. It is not actually addressing those people who probably most need some income assistance in the event of a death or separation, divorce or otherwise. There are many reasons why couples in fact cannot make provision for their spouse. Even if they do in their wills, we all know that there are legal challenges that have been successful where the law enables those people who have a claim under the law to take that away from a same sex partner, de facto spouse and so on. There are real problems in the way the system works and, if nothing else, this amendment has drawn attention to what those real problems are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —On the matter raised by Senator Sherry, I think the Attorney has announced that he is looking at part of the wider issue in relation to property. If there is any information I can give you on that, I will be happy to pass you the material.

SPEECH.PARA: I find myself in agreement with Senator Kernot—which is a worry. In our view, the amendment discriminates against married spouses, and we certainly will not be supporting the amendment. If we did support it, of course it would also be a breach of our election commitment. On a philosophical basis we do not support it. We think it is a discriminatory amendment, and we will be voting with the opposition and the Democrats on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just one small comment. The government are happy to discriminate against same‐sex couples. The government are happy to discriminate in various ways against de facto marriages. It is not discrimination they have a problem with: it is against whom.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 14, item 48, page 120 (lines 4 and 5), omit ", in the opinion of the Commissioner,".

This amendment will remove the apparent discretion given to the Commissioner of Taxation relating to the consideration given for the transfer of revenue losses between related companies and the extent to which payment is given, as such consideration is a matter of fact, not a matter of discretion. I think the law will reflect this more clearly.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 129 (after line 12), at the end of the bill, add:

PARA.TAB: Omit "the employees", substitute "the permanent employees".
Omit "⅔", substitute "75%".

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Part 4 of Schedule 2 to the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 2) 1995 applies in the same way to the amendment made by item 1 of this Schedule as it applied to the amendments made by Schedule 2 to that Act.
(2) The amendment made by item 2 of this Schedule applies to shares or rights acquired on or after 1 July 1996.

This amendment moves schedule 17 into the bill. It implements an announcement that was made publicly on 25 July 1997. The schedule amends subsection 139CD(5) so that it refers to permanent employees rather than to employees.

The amendment will not affect the ability of employers to allow non-permanent employees to participate in employee share schemes. The amendment will ensure that the deferral income tax concession for employee share schemes will be available for schemes offered to at least 75 per cent of permanent employees. The initial legislation unintentionally did not include the word `permanent', and the previous government had foreshadowed that it would amend the law to rectify the omission.

The schedule also amends paragraph 139GF(4)(b) to change the reference to `two‐thirds' to 75 per cent. The amendment ensures a common 75 per cent threshold for eligibility for the exemption concession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before we deal with this—Senator Kemp moved too fast for me with respect to the previous amendment—I did have a couple of questions on schedule 12. We do not have any amendment but we do have a question.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 12 refers to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classification) Act and to audiovisual services. Could you outline for us what audiovisual services are?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —According to advice I have just received, the term `audiovisual services' is used in an amendment to the sales tax law currently before the parliament. The amendment will ensure that the sales tax exemption for certain goods used to deliver electricity within consumers' premises does not extend to goods of a kind ordinarily used to provide telecommunications and audiovisual services.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment is a response to the Federal Court decision in the Telstra case, which found that certain equipment used in a telephone exchange qualified for exemption as fixed electrical installations. Given the nature of the goods and the continuing innovation in this area, it would be both difficult and counterproductive for the amendment to be too specific about the goods that will be excluded.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my concern: the amendment is not specific. Would this, for example, cover video games? It seems to me to mean any reasonable interpretation of `audiovisual services' or educational audiovisual tapes.
—Senator, I am advised that this just excludes items from an existing exemption.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you indicate to us what the existing exemption is—what `audiovisual services' means. It seems to me that it could mean an incredibly wide range of services.

—The existing exemption refers to electrical fittings. I am looking to my advisers—but this would exclude audiovisual services. It would exclude from that exemption goods involved in the delivery of audiovisual services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to be clear on this: is there a concern at the moment that, in respect of the sales tax, audiovisual services are excluded and schedule 12 is attempting to include them, whatever they may be?
—We are amending it to ensure that it is not read wider than the government intends it to be. This is the reason for the amendment that we are now proposing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the court has ruled that audiovisual services—whatever they are, and we have not yet got an indication of that—are exempt from sales tax and if we are to amend the sales tax act to include audiovisual services, that is an extension of sales tax beyond the current interpretation of the law by the courts.
—We have sought to preserve the base that successive governments have long understood it to be and we wish, with this amendment, to make that clearer. It is a basic protection measure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That may be, but I would like to know what the basic protection measure is attempting to protect government revenue against in respect of the application of sales tax. What is an audiovisual service? Can I have some examples of what an audiovisual service is? What is the Tax Office concerned about in respect of the sales tax applications in this area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of the court's decision was to erode the WST base by exempting telecommunications equipment from being subjected to wholesale sales tax through changes to legislation passed by the parliament in 1987. In addition, the court's decision has the potential to create further anomalies and complicate the interpretation of the item, increasing compliance and administration costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance, the government has decided to act to prevent the erosion of the tax base to ensure that the existing revenue base is protected. This decision is consistent with the general policy of subjecting telecommunications carriers to the wholesale sales tax. Telstra, for example, was made subject to the wholesale sales tax in 1987.

The Federal Court's decision would have meant that telecommunications carriers would have been exempt from wholesale sales tax on potentially key elements of their business inputs. The government believes that the decision to preserve them maintains the integrity of the existing tax base in this regard. The decision does not in any way affect the existing wholesale sales tax exemptions provided under item 43 of the act relating to goods to deliver electricity within premises, such as internal wiring, power points, fuses and adaptors.
I do not know if I could add anything more to that. A press release was issued by the Treasurer Costello) on this matter in November 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —To add to the concerns in relation to schedule 12, the sales tax provision, there are problems in relation to the exact nature and impact of this provision, and I agree with Senator Sherry that it is not very clear. It potentially applies a higher level of tax by classifying things like a transformer in a telephone as telecommunications equipment instead of electrical equipment. It is hard to think the Tax Office can have it both ways.

BREAK.PARA: At the same time, it is arguing against giving things like water storage units or the bolts used in the fabrication of a solar water collector the same concessionary status as the rest of the collector on the argument that it is potentially multiple use. Here we have a situation where transformers—which clearly are multiple use—are being charged at a higher level of tax because they are used in telecommunications, but we have tax concessions for items which might be quite clearly part of a solar system, like a water tank, which cannot be used for anything else because they are used only in solar systems. But transformers are taxed and do not attract the concessionary status. This does not seem to make any sense.

The transformer units that I was talking about in telecommunications are often actually separate and plug into a phone but could equally plug into other electrical equipment. What principles are there in relation to goods that are sold as a unit but are made up of components which would otherwise get different tax classifications?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is serious, Senator. It is another vicious attack on schools. Your brother has been at this hasn't he?

—Senator Carr has finally woken up. The exemption has long been understood to cover the delivery of electricity to a home up to the point of consumption. The Federal Court, I think it is correct to say, took a broader view. The amendment, as I have said, seeks to protect the tax base.

—That clearly has not answered the question that I asked. Perhaps I could ask the question in a different way. If the policy is that things sold as a unit be taxed as a unit—if you have bits and pieces that end up being a telecommunications system, they get taxed at the higher rate because they are part of a telecommunications unit—why don't many components of solar hot water heaters get concessional tax treatment as a unit, as a solar hot water system?

—You seem to have thrown my advisers. We cannot give you a detailed response to the issue of solar heaters. We do not have the material available, but I will look at that question you raised and respond to it. Unfortunately, we have not got the information here in regard to solar heaters.

—The principle seems to be either you lump things together and give them the same tax treatment, or you treat them separately depending on their individual use. There seems to be absolute confusion as to what the government is doing. It depends, obviously, on the part of the tax act, and this certainly is not very satisfactory.

—There is a broader argument, which you may wish to join, that there is a need for substantial tax reform. The reality is the wholesale sales tax area does have a wide range of anomalies. I make no argument in relation to what you have raised. It is one of those areas which I would have to look at and get some specialised advice on. Senator, I will seek that advice and write to you about that matter.

—This may be slightly cynical, but if there was a higher tax rate on solar systems, perhaps then the tax department would be happy to link all of the components of a solar system together and tax them at the same rate.

—We will be able to make that judgment when I can provide you with the detailed response. The officials have been listening to your arguments and making copious notes. I will get back to you as soon as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not wanting to waste time, but I am not happy with the response we have had on this.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you want the legislation passed, you are. We have had some representation from the Fallon group who wrote to us on behalf of the New South Wales Sales Tax Practitioners Association raising concerns about this. Certainly, if we are to support this, I would like an indication of the audiovisual services that would not be affected by this sales tax provision. I have given a couple of examples—video games is one. I do not know how sales tax applies to that at the moment, if it does apply. There may be other educational audiovisual services that are tax exempt at the moment that may be caught by this provision. Just reading a letter from the Taxation Office on this matter, the tax office was loath to provide any specific example of what they meant by audiovisual services. In fact, they say:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not consider it appropriate to provide your association with examples of taxable and exempt goods currently in the marketplace. It has not been the approach to define the goods which are listed in the legislation, whether as exempt or taxable goods. Such an approach would make the legislation overly complex and would create unnecessary restriction in an environment where technology and product differentiation and development is moving at a rapid rate. Neither of the terms `telecommunications' or `audiovisual services' has been defined, nor would it be appropriate to seek to define them. If, as you have indicated, there is no specific meaning of the term in the electrical supply and construction industries, then the normal rules of statutory construction and interpretation would apply.

What is of concern to us, notwithstanding the court ruling, is whether the effect of this amendment will be to catch whatever audiovisual services or some form of computer items that have not in the past been understood to be covered by this extension of sales tax. I would seek your assurance that it is not intended to cover any form of audiovisual service, whatever that is—and it is not defined—that has not been covered by sales tax in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the video games, which was one of the examples that you used, it is very clear, on the advice I have here, that such things as video games could not be exempt as an electrical fitting. Item 43(3) of the Australian Sales Tax Guide , which I have before me, refers to the following goods: if they are of a kind ordinarily used as part of fixed electrical installation at a consumer's premises; electrical fittings, including electronically operated electrical fittings; electrical accessories, including electronically operated electrical accessories; and electrical materials, including electrical conduit. Then there are sub‐items under part 2 and it goes through a range of various fittings which sub‐item (1) does not cover. I would like to be more specific. Do you have a copy of that letter?
—Yes.
—If you were prepared to forward that, I could seek further advice on it during the debate. I would like my advisers to see the material which you have before you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps, Senator Kemp, you could check with your adviser. If the Tax Office cannot give us at least some precision in respect of the definition, how is the industry to know what is to be covered by sales tax and what is not?

—I think you are perhaps looking at it in the other direction. The idea is to maintain the scope of item 43 as it currently is, not to broaden it. This is a revenue protection measure in that sense. But in item 43 there is a very substantial list of items which are included and items which are not covered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it, looking at this letter, that it would be intended to cover new technological developments, and I can understand they do emerge with significant frequency. Would that mean that new technology would be covered by sales tax when it otherwise would not be if there was a definition of what audio‐visual services is?

—They would be covered by sales tax unless this item exempted them. As I said, we are seeking to maintain the general understanding of how that item applied. You are right: given the nature of the goods and the continuing innovation in this area, as I mentioned before, it would be very difficult and probably counterproductive for the amendment to be too specific about goods that will be excluded. Again, I think if you saw the item you would see that we are seeking to maintain what were commonly understood to be the existing arrangements.
—Could I ask a question about schedule 11?
—I think we ought to dispose of the amendment that is before the chair at the moment. We can go back to yours, Senator Margetts.
—That is right, but I think the amendment we are dealing with is schedule 13—
—No, we are dealing with a new amendment to create schedule 17.
—Yes. That is okay, as long as there is an ability to ask questions in between—
—Yes, you have that ability. That is why the recent 10‐minute debate has been going on, I think.
—I agree with the chair: why don't we dispose of what is before the chair, and if there are other matters you wish to raise, we will seek to deal with them.
—Then you can speak, Senator Margetts.

—I have a question in relation to research and development for cooperative research centres. What exactly is the government going to be doing about research and development in the light of cooperative research centres?

—Senator, there is a whole range of things the government is doing in the research and development area, but I think that probably goes significantly wider than what is here. We do not have the advisers here to deal with that. I am happy to supply you with the information. It is a very wide‐ranging question; if I had my brief here I could give you a very wide‐ranging answer. I think that probably goes beyond what is before us today.
—Sorry, I was referring to schedule 11 of the bill. You do not have any advisers on schedule 11 of the bill?

—They were here, but of course the debate has moved on and we now have a new set of advisers in. As happens, when going through the bill we dealt with their area. They have now left, as is the normal practice in these matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, we are not going to finish this tonight. I ask Senator Kemp if my adviser can talk to his advisers about sales tax on audio‐visual services in the morning?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we are always happy to speak to your adviser, Senator. I will see if we can facilitate that. In relation to the matters that Senator Margetts raised, if you wish to further pursue those we would be very happy to provide you with some advice as well.
