INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 9.50 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to once again draw the attention of the Senate to the situation facing some 500,000 Australian citizens in Canberra and the surrounding region. I am, of course, referring to the Australian capital region, as it is now collectively known, and the economic pressure being brought to bear as a direct result of the decisions by the federal government to cut jobs. It is well documented that over 20,000 jobs have been and will be cut from this region. They are all from the same sector; it happens to be the public sector in this particular region. But we also know that job losses will flow through to the private sector as a result of these cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: What is also well documented is how the federal government quite rightly rallied around the community of Newcastle when BHP made a specific decision that deprived that region of 2,500 jobs. In addition, the state government matched some of the support with a financial contribution in a bipartisan effort to cushion the impact on that particular community.

That support was forthcoming in the following ways: $10 million was put in in cooperation between the federal government and the New South Wales state government. That money will be used to generate longer term economic and employment opportunities in the region. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) also announced that there would be a $2 million jobs package, including $1.2 million for the creation of new small businesses. In his press release the Prime Minister said:
More recently, we have allocated $1.9 million for 174 extra training places under the special employer support program.

My point this evening is to draw the parallels between Newcastle and the Australian Capital Region. My point is not only has there been no support forthcoming but there also has been a barrage of criticism from Liberal quarters about Canberra. Canberra bashing has now reached new heights with the coalition government. They have launched a two-pronged defensive which can be described in the following ways: one angle is this deafening silence on any support package to assist our community in establishing alternative industries and hence future employment sources; the other angle is the active Canberra bashing campaign that Minister Fahey gave renewed prominence to during the parliamentary recess.

But this lack of support and active denigration of Canberra is perhaps most succinctly demonstrated by the Prime Minister's refusal to reside here. I am, of course, referring to his decision to choose Kirribilli as his place of residence. This symbolic rejection of Canberra has become quite a feature of John Howard's general political agenda to deconstruct the direct government administration.

Putting aside for a moment the politics of public sector cuts generally, I believe that, if it were not for a patently anti-Canberra campaign, this government would have been obligated to provide a support package to assist this region's economy through a very difficult transition period. This package, if you applied, to a degree, proportionality with the support package that was afforded to the Newcastle community, would be quite substantial. If you were to apply direct proportionality between the anticipated job losses here in the ACT and the joint support package offered by the New South Wales and federal governments, you would be looking at a support package totalling some $100 million.

There are those other support areas that I mentioned before—a jobs package and special employer support programs.A bit of targeted support where it is needed most, where the jobs are going and where they are going to come from in the future, needs to be specifically addressed. This package, however, is not forthcoming. We have seen no indication from the federal government that they are in the least bit sensitive to the ACT's spiralling bankruptcy rates and to the marginalisation of local businesses through the outsourcing of government services to large multinational corporations.

We have seen no response to the downward pressure on property values that are undermining the principal asset of the vast majority of ACT residents—their houses. There is also no response to plummeting business confidence, outside the sector that is capitalising on the advice that the government is procuring on outsourcing and contract management. You would think this government would have got the message when local Liberal Party members, who are also small business owners, start resigning from their party in disgust.

There are, however, a couple of opportunities for the federal government to try to hang on to the last remnant of credibility—I do not think they have any credibility left in the local community but, if they did, there are some things that they could specifically do. They could review the current employment situation and the pending employment situation in Canberra as a result of these cuts. They could acknowledge what is happening in the regional economy because not only are their cuts taking away up to 20,000-odd jobs over the next few years but they are also having a significant impact upon the potential growth of the private sector and small business.

The government could come up with a package that involved some direct support to promoting the growth of business in the ACT; they could come up with a package that funded some job and retraining programs; and they could come up with a package that saw the ACT government join with the federal government in providing some quite specific grant assistance to local companies who are struggling under the pressure. There is a need to focus on industry diversification in the ACT. Both local business and local government have known that for quite some time.

The Prime Minister could also renounce what is quite a shallow, vitriolic vendetta against Canberra and take away the perception, which exists very strongly, that he has no time for this place. But I do not think anyone should hold their breath. In my view, there have been two remarkable features of John Howard's leadership to date. The first is his indulgence in pursuing his pet hates—unions, the ABC, Canberra, multiculturalism and the public sector generally. The other feature, of course, is the Prime Minister's willingness to use his family as justification for his personal intervention or activity in a given policy area. His move to Sydney is far more symbolic of taking away the symbolism of Canberra as the national capital than anything else that he has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am reluctant to interrupt someone during the adjournment debate, but I am not quite sure whether I understood Senator Lundy correctly. I think she made a quite outrageous imputation against the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). If it was as I understood it, then I think the senator should be asked to withdraw.
—I am not quite sure that I heard it either.
—Madam Deputy President, I made some general comments, but if there was any outrageousness about them, then I unequivocally withdraw.

SPEECH.PARA: What this government obviously has not cottoned on to yet is that, despite a carefully contrived anti‐Canberra sentiment designed to glean popular support for cutting public expenditure generally, Australians are, in fact, very proud of Canberra as their national capital. They are not proud of the politicians who are prepared to denigrate the nation's capital for a shallow and partisan campaign.

From a local point of view, everyone feels as though they are bearing the brunt of a prime ministerial grudge. Those not employed in the public sector directly are paying a price through the general recession in the local economy. Those in the federal public sector are demoralised by a thankless employer and a thoughtless administrator. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment tonight on the case of Mr Konrad Kalejs, an Australian citizen accused of involvement in horrific war crimes in Nazi controlled Latvia during World War II.

SPEECH.PARA: How Mr Kalejs became an Australian citizen may well warrant further examination. He attained citizenship in 1957, during a nine‐year stay in Australia. He was deported from the United States back to Australia three years ago following a nine‐year battle against the United States Justice Department, which claimed that he had lied about his wartime activities on his entry papers when he said he was a farm labourer.

In February 1995, he fled to Canada following the release of secret US files about his alleged wartime activities. Canadian authorities found that he was a member of a notorious Latvian death squad during World War II and that he was allegedly responsible for the deaths of at least 30,000 Jews. A 10‐month inquiry found that he had helped to run a slave labour camp in Nazi occupied Latvia, where prisoners were starved, tortured and killed.

The United States and Canadian investigations based some of their findings on an investigation carried out by the now defunct Australian Special Investigation Unit which had, apparently, insufficient evidence to mount a prosecution. The Special Investigation Unit was disbanded in 1992, following three unsuccessful prosecutions of alleged war criminals. It was initially set up by the federal government in 1987, and it investigated 841 people suspected of being directly involved in the murder of millions of Jews during World War II. It was later revealed that $22.5 million was spent investigating these cases, with a further $5 million spent on legal aid in the defence of three accused men.

Under the current citizenship act, Mr Kalejs is immune from deportation from Australia. Earlier this year, the government amended the citizenship act and revoked the 10-year limitation on actions. This means that, no matter how much time has elapsed, anyone found to have fraudulently obtained citizenship could be deported. However, the amendment is not retrospective and, therefore, will have no effect on people who obtained citizenship prior to the amendment taking effect. Whether there is, in extreme cases, an argument that the legislation should have retrospective effect that would enable citizenship to be revoked if in the national interest is beside the point.

The compelling issue is: what can Australia realistically achieve in this perplexing matter? Firstly, there can be no argument that there is a moral imperative to pursue alleged war criminals—no matter how old the atrocities and no matter how feeble the accused. The probability that Mr Kalejs was the perpetrator of unimaginable crimes seems overwhelming. How could we ignore the call for justice by those survivors and relatives of those dispatched so callously by the Nazi machine? How could we seemingly condone his actions by failing to take every available form of recourse?

However, there are obvious limits to investigating the allegations of war crimes against Mr Kalejs through the Australian judicial system. The Attorney-General, Mr Williams, has asked his department to contact Canadian authorities to obtain materials used in the decision to deport Mr Kalejs. These materials will be examined by the Australian Federal Police and, if appropriate, the Director of Public Prosecutions.

To get to court, the Director of Public Prosecutions must make an assessment about the prospects of successfully obtaining a conviction and also determine whether or not court proceedings are in the public interest. It is the same standard that must be applied to the case of Mr Kalejs as to other criminal matters. There are obvious problems with this approach. The age of the defendant, insufficient witnesses and establishing the authenticity of documentation mean that securing a guilty verdict is very difficult.

Other nations such as the United States rely heavily on the use of revocation of citizenship and deportation as a method of dealing with proven war criminals. Even if deprivation of citizenship and deportation were more readily available in Australia, there are frequently unforeseen difficulties in the path of stripping someone of citizenship if it renders them, in turn, stateless or a refugee.

Last year, the Latvian government indicated that it would seek the extradition of Mr Kalejs but that his Australian citizenship may prove an obstacle in prosecuting him in Latvia as, obviously, he is not a Latvian citizen. When Latvia gained independence from Moscow in 1991, it established war crimes legislation in line with international conventions with no statute of limitation on prosecutions. However, it would be futile to believe that, even if it were available, a prosecution of Mr Kalejs in Latvia would be less difficult than in Australia. Moreover, for survivors and the victims' families, a failed prosecution may well prove as much a travesty of justice as no trial at all.

What the Kalejs case teaches us is that dealing effectively with war crimes is as much about dealing with the future as it is about dealing with the past. The war atrocities committed in Rwanda, Bosnia, Cambodia and the Gulf War provide graphic examples of contemporary genocide.

BREAK.PARA: The need for justice and to redress the wrongs of these conflicts has again brought to the fore the possibility of international cooperation and responsibility in the coordination of information and detection of suspected war criminals. The establishment of a permanent international criminal court to try those accused of crimes against humanity would provide international recognition of the enormity of the problem where it is beyond the resources of one nation to solve.

In May 1993, the Security Council of the United Nations determined that the situation in the former Yugoslavia constituted a threat to international peace and security and so established the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, the ICTFY, as an enforcement measure under chapter VII of the United Nations Charter. The establishment of the tribunal and its twin, the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, the ICTR, represents significant and groundbreaking steps by the international community to enforce international humanitarian and international criminal law through criminal prosecutions.

Not since the Nuremberg and Tokyo trials following the end of World War II have there been international prosecutions for violations of international humanitarian law. The ICTFY is the first international body in almost 50 years to prosecute war crimes and related international crimes. These two tribunals also set important precedents regarding the rules of procedure and evidence to apply in international criminal proceedings. The International Law Commission has been in the process of drafting a Code of Crimes against the Peace and Security of Mankind and a statute for a proposed permanent International Criminal Court.

If and when the international community deems it appropriate to establish a permanent international criminal court with jurisdiction over a wide range of international crimes, these tribunals will provide a rich body of law and useful precedents on a multitude of aspects of this important part of international law. In the meantime, the tribunals espouse the message that those who commit crimes that threaten international peace and security will be brought to justice, and provide an important vehicle for the victims of these two tragic conflicts to express the horrors of the wars they endured.

The establishment of a permanent international war tribunal will no doubt be too late to deal with Mr Kalejs and will no doubt be too late for the victims of the Holocaust. Even if Mr Kalejs is brought to trial, there is little basis to believe that he would be tried and convicted in a time frame that would deliver any meaningful outcome. Perhaps the best Australia can hope to achieve from past experiences in prosecuting war criminals, is the vigorous pursuit of justice for more recent victims in an international forum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to talk tonight on the Kimberley and the damming of the Fitzroy River. The Australian Democrats unequivocally reject the way in which economic growth is calculated. We totally reject the notion that economic growth must be pursued at any cost. We reject the idea that economic growth is a good in itself and that it must be maximised in the short term at every opportunity. Economic growth is good when it delivers significant net benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: We reject the notion that sacrifices must be made—environmental sacrifices, cultural sacrifices, social sacrifices or long-term economic sacrifices. We support the view that any development must be appraised on a full cost‐benefit basis and that long-term net benefit is required to make a project acceptable. It is no good always telling us what the benefits are. Honest governments should also tell us what the costs are.

In the case of the planned resource development projects now being proposed for the Kimberley region in Western Australia, the sacrifices will be in all of those categories. The environmental, social, cultural and long-term economic wellbeing of the region is at risk. No appraisal has been undertaken.

In the push to pursue economic growth at any cost, we are seeing renewed pressure on our remaining remote and relatively unspoilt areas. There is a relentless push by a few to maximise the exploitation of natural resources and to extract wealth quickly from environments which are seen as exploitable and vulnerable to selfish interests.

In the case of the Fitzroy River, there is fierce and united opposition to plans for a massive new irrigated cotton/ horticultural industry, supported by the damming of the Fitzroy River. Aboriginal communities, the tourism industry, the pearling and fishing industries, and many pastoralists all are saying no to the proposal, but the vested interests of a few may well jeopardise the very future of those people and their industries. If the Kimberley region is the next to suffer from short-term economic exploitation, it will not only be just the many local residents and local businesses who will suffer; it will be at the expense of all Australians and future generations in particular.

Regions like the Kimberley are rare on planet Earth at the end of the 20th century—a wide landscape which, although substantially altered by Western civilisation and agrarian and mining industries, still retains a strong character of remoteness, freshness and naturalness and one which is much valued by those Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal groups, and individuals, who enjoy it. Its natural values—its myriad of landscapes, spectacular wetlands and escarpments, its coastline and its stunning, wild Fitzroy River—make the Kimberley a national treasure.

The region has many internationally significant environments, including Ramsar‐listed wetlands and remnant rainforests. Other places, like the Purnululu National Park and the majestic wilderness coastline, have been spoken of as possible world heritage areas. The North Kimberley is believed to be the only part of Western Australia which has so far suffered no extinctions of native fauna species. In a state and country which have lost so many species since colonisation, this is a record that must be maintained.

The value of the natural features of this area, from the spectacular gorges to the unique species that frequent the open plains, cannot be measured in just dollars. They have an intrinsic value. They are valuable for their own sake. We do not need to exploit them to increase their value. But even when you talk in dollars, our state does not put their value, intangible and tangible, on the state's balance sheet; it is just a blank space marked `for exploitation'.

For some, such as tourist operators and those involved in the fishing industry, the areas have a high economic value as they are. They do not need to be developed to enable people to make a living. Indeed, we risk putting in jeopardy the livelihoods of many if we dedicate these resources to the cotton industry. The understanding and appreciation of these unique areas of the Kimberley, and in particular the Fitzroy River, is becoming widespread—both nationally and internationally. Yet despite all this, we probably are at great risk of losing the unique values over the next few years.

We have a state government and, it seems from the answer to my question in the Senate today, possibly also a federal government, prepared to facilitate the building of a dam and the development of huge cotton production through irrigation. If this scheme were objectively and scientifically appraised, we doubt that such economic land use would be found to be appropriate or sustainable in the long term. And that is without talking about the environment and cultural and land factors.

Following the initial rush to open up pastoral and mining activities in the late 19th century, the character of the Kimberley changed gradually over the first half of this century. These pastoral activities have caused widespread changes to ecosystems and, in many cases, significant environmental damage to what are often fragile lands. In some areas, such as those affected by the Ord River Valley, the impact has been devastating.

As well as the long-term impact on the environment, major social and cultural changes have occurred as Aboriginal people have been dispossessed. By the 1960s big engineering projects began to be seriously contemplated and in some cases, such as the damming of the Ord, the projects went ahead without any adequate assessment of the impact on the environment—to this day—and no assessment of the social or cultural impact on the local people.

BREAK.PARA: It was in the 1980s, 100 years after the first concerted colonial move into the region, that a renewed push to intensify the exploitation of the so-called `last western frontier' really began to bite. The 1980s commenced under the dark cloud surrounding the infamous Noonkanbah confrontation between mining interests and the state government on one side and the Aboriginal people, seeking respect for their rights to their land and culture, on the other.

Later in the decade, the Argyle diamond mine was opened to state, national and global fanfare. Mineral exploration programs all across the Kimberley and in the adjacent marine environment have continued relentlessly to this day. At the same time, tourism levels began to increase rapidly and Broome became the focus of international interest rising on the back of Lord McAlpine's controversial patronage. Proposals for tourism developments—ranging from international airports to remote wilderness resorts—began to emerge, and to some extent those developments did begin to multiply across the landscape.

Changes to the operation of the pastoral industry have accelerated, with a shift away from traditional grazing towards more intensive methods of exploiting the land. Pastoralists have also become increasingly involved in tourism ventures on their leases, raising important questions about leasehold legalities. Now, as we stand on the edge of the millennium, the momentum for major industrial development in the Kimberley has reached very disturbing levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Privacy protection in Australia needs to extend to the collection, storage, security, access, correction, use, destruction and disclosure of all personal information. The present legislative scheme set out in the Privacy Act 1988 addresses the collection, storage, use and disclosure of personal information held by the Commonwealth government. This scheme also extends to credit reporting and some telecommunications suppliers and operators. But this scheme does not otherwise extend to the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: On 12 September 1996 a discussion paper was released by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) which set out a scheme based on the existing information privacy principles in the Privacy Act 1988 and added to this codes of practice and a range of additional provisions which addressed the particular concerns of the private sector. In essence this was a proposal for industry codes of practice supervised by the Privacy Commissioner and subject to statutory backing—a co‐regulatory approach. This scheme is consistent with the schemes adopted by Hong Kong, New Zealand and the European Union.
Then on 21 March this year the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced that the Privacy Act 1988 would not be extended to the private sector. The Prime Minister said:
The Commonwealth opposes such proposals which will further increase compliance costs for all Australian businesses, large and small.

That was it—the end of Australia's international best practice privacy scheme and another election promise broken. The reasons for this decision and the relevant information the Prime Minister relied on in making this decision have not yet been made available. A decision of this importance cannot be passed off without some explanation.

The coalition's `backflip' is also at odds with the major industrialised countries which have recognised the economic and social benefits of privacy protection. The ministerial meeting of G7 industrialised countries in February 1995 and APEC ministers in May 1995 identified privacy as an issue which was important for commercial reasons. The European Union has adopted a legally enforceable law in the form of the Privacy Directive, which can prevent the flow of data. New Zealand has its own Privacy Act, which creates a comprehensive national privacy scheme applying to both the public and the private sectors. So failure by this government to introduce privacy legislation for the private sector is likely to threaten future interactions between our nations. This is serious and should be reviewed and is particularly import ant to the telecommunications and information technology industries.

I know that a number of state and territory governments are presently examining privacy legislation options. If state and territory governments do introduce privacy schemes, businesses will be required to satisfy those requirements which may be different for each state and territory, therefore increasing overall compliance costs and the regulatory burdens—apparently the very thing that our Prime Minister sought to avoid.

A fragmented approach to privacy protection is likely to increase compliance costs and the regulatory burden for many businesses. This approach has been adopted in Canada, where there is a centralised scheme for public agencies and a hotchpotch of province laws with varying requirements. This is not what Australian consumers or businesses need.

It is a fundamental principle that a person has a right to know what personal information is held about them and, if the information is lawfully held, that the information is correct. The International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights identify privacy in terms of their specific concerns. Privacy is a human rights issue and the government should deal with this issue appropriately by introducing suitable legislation on a national basis which complies with Australia's international obligations.

The Australian Democrats have long supported a strong and enforceable privacy scheme which goes to assuring consumers that their personal information is adequately protected. This is reinforced by the concerns that businesses are likely to be affected detrimentally and excluded from data flows through inadequate regulation. We must have some direction from the government to satisfy consumers and business interests and avoid the possibility of an array of state and territory laws.

I have asked, and my party has asked, the government to reconsider its decision on a variety of occasions, and we have asked that they consult a little more widely. Unfortunately, it seems they are relying on the interests of a few to the exclusion of an international best practice privacy scheme and the potential to develop and lead the information businesses of the future.

I have therefore brought before the Senate an exposure draft document which addresses some of the concerns. I propose to seek leave to table this document tonight together with an explanatory exposure draft document which outlines my suggested amendments and the rationale behind them. I also consider privacy legislation to be quite a complex matter which would benefit from the cross‐party analysis and scrutiny that goes with the Senate committee system.

The exposure draft, which I have brought before the Senate this evening, implements a scheme where industry is either covered by legislated privacy principles or develops its own codes of practice with the cooperation of the Privacy Commissioner and subject to approval by the parliament. The privacy principles and codes of practice maintain comprehensive and enforceable privacy protection with powers conferred on the Privacy Commissioner which are similar to those currently set out in the Privacy Act 1988.

The definition of `agency' would be extended to include all persons, including unincorporated bodies, who would be covered by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and in particular article 17 of that covenant dealing with corporations and trading corporations and financial corporations. However, acts or practices which are done for personal or family reasons, household affairs or journalistic, literary or artistic purposes would not be covered. Other amendments could be suggested which are directed at including codes of practice in the operation of the act in its present structure and application.

New information privacy principles are added which cover areas of justifiable purpose, limiting the retention of information, maintaining anonymity and unique identifiers. In the absence of codes of practice, these principles will apply to all agencies. Where an identified grouping generally, a specified person, a specified class of person, a specified agency, industry, profession, calling or specif ic act or practice has been identified by either the Privacy Commissioner or at the request of that class, the Privacy Commissioner may issue codes of practice.

Before this code of practice is issued there must be reasonable efforts to inform affected classes and accept their submissions. The code of practice comes into practice following a resolution passed, say, by both houses of the parliament. A code of practice may override the operation of the information privacy principles or specify how that principle is to apply to that industry, et cetera.

The exposure draft would also expand the functions of the Privacy Commissioner to enable the commissioner to make public statements about privacy. This additional function the Democrats consider would be an appropriate addition as it would allow the Privacy Commissioner to undertake community education campaigns on privacy issues and prepare materials that relate to public interest matters. The Privacy Commissioner will also be able to promote the protection of individual privacy.

I believe, and certainly the Democrats believe this strongly, that consumers and large and small businesses alike deserve some kind of standard, some uniform national laws, when it comes to privacy in the private sector. I am glad of this opportunity to bring this exposure draft before the Senate tonight. I seek the leave of the Senate to table the exposure draft document along with the exposure draft explanatory document.
Leave granted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 22 July 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Minister's announcement on 28 June 1996 of the closure of 26 Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) offices:

(1) Were any representations made to the Minister, by any members of Parliament, in person, by telephone, in writing or by any other means, in advance of that decision seeking to keep CES offices in their particular electorates open; if so, (a) who were the members of Parliament in question; and (b) will all documents, notes or other records of those discussions be tabled.
(2) Was it decided not to close some CES offices following representations from any members of Parliament; if so, which CES offices were saved from closure.

(3) Were any members of Parliament informed in advance, either formally or informally, of the possibility that CES offices in their electorates would be closed; if so, who were the members of Parliament in question.
(4) How much notice was given of the closures.
(5) What were the criteria used to determine which CES offices would close.
(6) Was the level of unemployment in the local area considered in the decision to close each office; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There were sixteen letters received prior to 28 June 1996 from Federal and State members of parliament in relation to the closure of CES offices.

One of these letters related to the Manly CES office, which had been earmarked as a potential site for rationalisation and relocation with the Department of Social Security into a "one‐stop‐shop" at Brookvale, by the previous Government in late 1995.

The remaining 15 letters were received from 11 individual Federal members and two State members of parliament and concerned 11 CES offices, three of which were subsequently closed. In total, of the 26 offices closed, 18 were located in Coalition seats and 8 were located in seats held by the Opposition.
(2) No decision was made to not close a CES office as a result of representations from a member of Parliament.
(3) All Coalition Members of Parliament in whose electorate a CES office was to close was advised informally by members of the Minister's Office and Departmental officers on Friday 28 June 1996.
The Secretary of the Department also wrote to all Members of Parliament in whose electorate a CES office was to be closed. This advice was faxed to the members' electorate offices on 28 June 1996.
The Minister also personally contacted a number of Labor MPs whose electorates were affected by the closure of an office on 28 June and during the following weekend.
(4) The decision to close CES offices was taken on 28 June 1996. The first office was closed on 26 July 1996 and the other offices involved were closed before the end of 1996.

(5) The rationale for these CES offices to be closed was based on providing the most effective client service delivery network within the resources available. These closures followed careful case by case consideration, taking into account the loss of staff through voluntary redundancies and the need for the Department to live within its financial means. Other factors taken into account included impending office lease expiry dates, existing accommodation which had concerns in terms of occupational health and safety for both staff and clients, client service demand levels, the relative ease for clients to travel to another office to obtain services including proximity to public transport, and alternative and more cost‐effective means of providing services including the use of enhanced technology such as touchscreens.

Closure decisions were aimed at ensuring that the overall network would continue to function effectively and maintain essential services to clients. The transition to the new servicing arrangements sought to minimise any disruption to clients who were informed locally when the changes would take place.
(6) The level of unemployment was one, only, but not the consideration in the decision to close each office.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 26 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Where does Australia currently rank among the 18 Organisation for Economic CoOperation and Development (OECD) countries in terms of per capita school expenditure relative to gross domestic product (GDP).
(2) Where does Australia currently rank among the 18 OECD countries for the level of public funding for private schools.
(3) Where does Australia rank in the OECD as an overall taxing nation.
(4) Is there a minimum number of students in a state school beneath which that state school will not be funded; if so, what is that number.
(5) Is there a minimum number of students in a private school beneath which that private school will not be funded: if so. what is that number.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The OECD's "Education At A Glance" (EAG) contains a number of tables providing information on expenditure on educational services per student. Country data are compared using the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), whose main categories do not exactly match institutional sectors for Australia.

Table F3.2 provides data on expenditure per student relative to per capita GDP. According to this table Australian expenditure per student at primary level in 1993 was 17.2 per cent of per capita GDP compared with 18.3 per cent for the total OECD. Australia ranked 14th of the 23 OECD countries for which data were available. For secondary education, expenditure per student was 28.1 per cent of per capita GDP compared with the OECD total of 25.8 per cent and we ranked 9th of the 24 OECD countries for which data were available.

The above data for secondary education include some of the Australian Vocational Education and Training (VET) sector. OECD Secondary Education data comprise ISCED 2 (Lower Secondary) and ISCED 3 (Upper Secondary). It should be noted that the VET sector in Australia does not easily fit into the ISCED classification system used by the OECD, and award TAFE courses are allocated to Secondary Education (mainly ISCED 3) or to non-University Tertiary (ISCED 5). Owing to lack of data figures for private VET providers are not included.

In regard to the OECD educational indicator data cited, the OECD's "Education At A Glance" publication presents data for 27 member countries and 3 non-member countries. Owing to missing data for some countries international coverage is incomplete for many indicators. The data need to be interpreted very carefully since there are a range of factors affecting comparability, including differences between countries in education systems, statistical methodology, data availability and classification practices. Financial statistics are further affected by differences between countries in accounting practices and in the way countries disaggregate costs.
Expenditure on education data across countries are highly sensitive to classification practices. Significant issues affecting comparisons include the following:

. In many cases countries do not collect all the data requested by the OECD or have difficulty in providing data that fully accord with OECD definitions. Household spending on education, and expenditure by private firms on the workplace component of apprenticeship training are commonly undercounted (to varying degrees).
. Comparisons on a per student basis are impaired by problems in quantifying fulltime equivalent enrolments.
. Countries differ in how pension costs are treated (in accounting for the cost of teaching and other staff) and this impacts on cost and expenditure comparisons.

(2) The OECD does not publish data on the level of public funding for private schools in member countries. It is, however, possible to rank Australia in this regard using unpublished OECD financial data for 1993 taken from the OECD's internet site, which is located at http://www.oecd.org/els/stats/els stat.htm..

Australia ranks as the country with the third highest level of Government Direct Expenditure on Private Institutions relative to Gross Domestic Product for ISCEDs 1, 2, and 3 combined (ie Primary and Secondary education). It should be noted that these data have been compiled using OECD definitions as to what constitutes a private educational institution and what levels of education are included in "school" education. The Australian figure was 0.54 per cent of GDP, which is relative ly small compared with overall spending on education.

(3) The 1996 edition of the OECD Revenue Statistics publication indicates that Australia's tax revenue to GDP ratio for 1994 was 29.9 per cent. Australia thus ranked 24th Of the 28 countries listed. Countries with a lower tax to GDP ratio than Australia for 1994 were Mexico (18.8 per cent), Turkey (22.2 per cent), the United States (27.6 per cent) and Japan (27.8 per cent). The OECD average (unweighted) tax to GDP ratio for 1994 was 38.4 per cent.

Compulsory contributions made under Australia's Superannuation Guarantee arrangements are not treated as taxes by the OECD on the basis that the OECD defines taxes as compulsory, unrequited payments to general government. Compulsory superannuation contributions are not paid to general government and are not considered to be unrequited, as they are linked to either a specific amount being invested on behalf of an employee, or a negotiated arrangement (between employers and employees) for the provision of benefits based on salary levels and length of service.

(4) & (5) With the abolition of the New Schools Policy of the former Government with effect from 1 January 1997, Commonwealth minimum enrolment numbers for non‐government schools have been removed. The primary eligibility requirement of a non-government school for Commonwealth
general recurrent funding is now that the school has State or Territory recognition. The States and Territories are able to set minimum enrolment numbers as part of their registration requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 May 1997—With reference to Child Support Agency guidelines:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that non‐custodial partners are unable to seek a reassessment of their financial obligations unless their income has decreased by more than 15 per cent from the previous financial year.
(2) Is it a fact that a reassessment can only occur if the custodial parent seeks a review of the non‐custodial party's income.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are two avenues available to parents paying and receiving child support to obtain a reassessment or review of a child support assessment. These are the estimate mechanism and a departure from the assessment through a child support review.

Where either parent estimates that his or her income for the current child support year is at least 15 per cent less than the taxable income used to calculate the assessment, he or she may on application have the assessment recalculated based on an estimate of current yearly income.

The option of a review of a child support assessment is also available to both the paying parent and the payee in relation to assessments arising on and after 1 July 1992. Clients can be granted a departure from their assessment if they have special circumstances which satisfy a ground for departure under subsection 117(2) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and if it would be just, equitable and otherwise proper to so depart. Examples of this includes those situations where a client has high costs maintaining contact with the child, where a client has a legal duty to maintain another person and where the income or earning capacity of the parent is not adequately reflected in the assessment.
(2) No. The parent paying child support can both lodge an estimate of his/her income and can initiate a review of the assessment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked The Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 92 (Senate Hansard, 18 September 1996, p.3576):

(1) Is it the case that the Federal Office of Road Safety requested legal opinion and engineering opinion on the legality of bull‐bars, following a statement by a Melbourne coroner regarding Australian Design Rule 42.9.1.1; if so, was this advice concurrent with the opinion of the coroner.

(2) In relation to parts (1) and (2) of the answer to question on notice no. 92: (a) how much power do the States and Territories have to exempt themselves from the Australian design rules; and (b) have all States and Territories specifically exempted themselves from the Australian design rules relating to bull‐bars in the same way as, or a similar way to, the example given from the Victorian Road Safety Act.

(3) Is the Minister aware whether accident report forms used in the various States and Territories have any area on them which prompts police to report the presence of a bull‐bar in any vehicle accident.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Office of Road Safety obtained advice from the Department's legal staff on the legality of fitting bullbars, following a statement by a Melbourne Coroner regarding clause 42.9.1.1 of Australian Design Rule 42. The legal advice provided was that the Rule needed to be read in the context of what was technically essential to the operation of a vehicle.

Engineering staff in the Federal Office of Road Safety were asked to offer their opinions as to whether they considered a bullbar to be technically essential to the operation of a vehicle. An engineering opinion offered at the time was that bullbars were not technically essential since the vehicle could operate without them. Another view, as indicated in the reply to question on notice no. 92, was that bullbars could be considered technically essential when operating in areas where there was a risk of collisions with wild animals or stray livestock, in that they could mean the difference between the vehicle being disabled or not. It is possible that a bullbar could prevent an animal from entering the passenger compartment through the windscreen and causing injury to the occupants.

The issue of whether or not a bullbar is technically essential hinges on consideration of the environment in which the vehicle operates; country drivers argue strongly that a bullbar is essential for rural operations. Many vehicles are used in both city and country areas.

(2) (a) The Australian Design Rules apply to vehicles before they are first supplied to the market for use in transport in Australia, while State and Territory authorities have powers to control the in‐service fitment of bullbars. The States and Territories are not obliged to incorporate the provisions of the Australian Design Rules into their legislation. However, as stated in the reply to question on notice no. 92, the States and Territories generally require on‐going compliance with the Australian Design Rules which applied at the time the vehicle was manufactured. (b) The State and Territory authorities (except in Victoria) have advised the Federal Office of Road Safety that they have no legislation of the kind that applies in Victoria.

(3) The State and Territory authorities have advised that the police accident report forms do not have any prompts which encourage reporting of the presence of bullbars. However, in the case of fatal accidents, information on the vehicle involved is usually quite detailed and information on the presence of bullbars can generally be obtained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that `leakage' of electromagnetic radiation from overhead broadband cables can interfere with free‐to‐air television reception.
(2) Why does this interference occur.
(3) Is this a widespread problem.
(4) How many complaints have been made to Austel and/or the department about such interference.
(5) Have any complaints been registered by the free‐to‐air television networks; if so, what is the nature of such complaints.
(6) Are there any emission/cable standards in force to mitigate the problem.
(7) What is the Government doing to mitigate this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, `leakage' of electromagnetic radiation from overhead metal based cable is possible and this can cause interference to free‐to‐air television reception.

However, there is no `leakage' of electromagnetic radiation from overhead optical fibre cable and therefore such cable cannot cause interference to free‐to‐air television reception. (However, equipment used to convert the light signals to electromagnetic television signals have been known to radiate signals which cause interference when not installed properly).

(2) Broadband metal‐based cables use frequencies in the television frequency bands and may cause interference where the cable or associated equipment is incorrectly installed, damaged or worn, allowing the egress of signals. In such cases, it is possible, although because of the low signal power levels, not likely, for these signals to interfere with domestic television reception.

(4) The Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) is aware of two reported occurrences in Melbourne and the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) has received some half dozen complaints over the last two years.
(5) No complaints have been received by the SMA from the free‐to‐air networks.

The ABA is aware that the free‐to‐air networks have received some complaints. In general, they concerned faulty cable set top boxes re‐radiating interfering signals that affect free‐to‐air reception in nearby homes.

(6) Currently there are no emission/cable standards in place. However, I am advised that a Standards Australia technical committee is about to finalise standards to restrict the levels of interfering radiation from cables and associated equipment.

(7) Under the Radiocommunications Act 1992, the Government has the power to take action where interference to television services occur from any source, including cables. Action has been taken in Melbourne in relation to interference from broadband cable to free‐to‐air television services.
The Government is actively involved in the communications standards development process through the SMA's participation in Standards Australia technical committees.

Under the new Telecommunications Act 1997 the Australian Communications Authority will be working with the Australian Communications Industry Forum on the development and implemen tation of communications and cable standards where deemed necessary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 21 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What evidence is there that one‐third of year nine students cannot read.
(2) (a) What research has been carried out by the Australian Council for Education Research into literacy and numeracy levels recently; and (b) what are the findings.

(3) When the National Literacy and Numeracy Plan was adopted in March 1997, why was there no mention of the National Equity Strategy adopted by the Ministerial Council of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs in 1994.
(4) What progress has been made by States and Territories in implementing the National Equity Strategy.

(5) Given that the National Equity Strategy requires school authorities to monitor and report on agreed performance measures: can details be provided of the reports prepared to date and a program of future reporting.
(6) Will the National Equity Strategy and the National Literacy and Numeracy Plan be coordinated to produce a comprehensive national set of aims and strategies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) & (2) The evidence to which the Senator refers is contained in a report released recently by the Australian Council for Educational Research. The report is titled Reading and Numeracy in Junior Secondary School: Trends, Patterns and Consequences. A copy of the report is publicly available.

(3) The National Literacy and Numeracy Plan and the National Strategy for Equity in Schooling (NSES) are different in nature and purpose. The National Literacy and Numeracy Plan, agreed by the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) in March 1997, is a plan for action towards achieving agreed National Literacy and Numeracy Goals. The NSES is a framework to address educational disadvantage.

(4) There has been considerable progress since the implementation of the NSES and a number of States continue to provide and promote a range of programs relating to the equity groups identified by Strategy. The NSES goals have been adopted, examined and progressed through professional development activities in systems and school communities and established in the planning and documentation by which schools are guided. For example, reports from Western Australia indicate that access and participation for all equity groups have continued to improve as a result of the wider application of technology, revised program delivery strategies and the development of management information strategies. In New South Wales, the Board of Studies has adopted a set equity principles (Statement of Values) that acts as a guide to all curriculum development activities. The Statement aims to ensure that curriculum and assessment activities develop fully the talents of all students.

(5) As part of their commitment to the NSES, school authorities have agreed to participate in annual reporting and monitoring of agreed performance measures which are consistent within the framework developed for the National Report on Schooling in Australia (known as the ANR). In 1998 provision has been made for the MCEETYA to conduct a mid‐term review of the overall strategy, using available data. This will be repeated in 2001. The annual reporting and monitoring will provide the data to enable informed decisions to be made concerning the strategy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the announcement in the 1997‐98 Budget that the method of assessing a child's eligibility for the Child Disability Allowance (CDA) would be reformed and that those reforms would see a move away from assessing a child's eligibility for the CDA by deciding whether or not that child requires `substantially more care and attention' than other children of a similar age, to the introduction of a set of child disability tables against which the level of a child's disability can be measured: Given that the Government has said that the introduction of these tables will result in the CDA being much better targeted and that this better targeting will result in approximately 4 000 fewer new grants of CDA each year:
(1) How did the Government arrive at this figure of 4 000.
(2) Why is the Government so sure that the `better targeting' of CDA via the use of child disability tables won't actually result in more children qualifying for CDA.
(3) Which disability groups will the Government be consulting with during the process of formulating the proposed child disability tables.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The draft child disability tables were field‐tested from September 1996 to February 1997 with new claimants for CDA. The figure of 4,000 is an estimate based on the field test results.

The child disability tables are two questionnaires—one to the parent and one to a treating health professional—which cover a range of age related functional abilities and behavioural, emotional and special care needs associated with childhood disability. The results of field testing indicated that the questionnaires are a valid means of obtaining an objective indication of a child's level of disability. Analysis of the field testing data included a comparison of the outcome of a customers application for CDA with the score achieved for their child under the questionnaire assessment.

(2) Field testing has also indicated that a significant proportion of claimants who are granted under the current rules are claiming for children whose disability or medical condition has little or no impact on their level of functioning. This data is also confirmed by a 1993 survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics which indicated approximately 21% of children attracting CDA had no handicap.

The field test indicated a small proportion of customers will qualify under the new assessment tool who may not have qualified under the current assessment process. This appears to be related to the subjective nature of the current assessment and the difficulty some claimants have in articulating how they provide "substantially more care and attention" for their child.

(3) The development of the new assessment method for CDA has taken place over several years with significant community input. The concept of using child disability tables was first raised by the Department of Social Security in `Child Disability Allowance—Policy Discussion Paper No.3, October 1993' which was distributed to more than 1200 community organisations. Overwhelmingly, responding community organisations were in favour of developing a simpler and more objective assessment tool.

In the recent work on further developing and refining the questionnaires, three reference groups were formed. The reference groups were made up of representatives from consumer groups, treating health professionals and staff involved in administering CDA. The community (or consumer) reference group included nominees from organisations such as: the Carer's Association of Australia; the National Association for Autism; the National Council on Intellectual Disability; the Australian Psychiatric Disability Coalition; the National Federation of Blind Citizens; and the National Ethnic Disability Alliance.

The Department is conducting further community consultations by releasing a paper on the new assessment tool to more than 250 community organisations and seeking written submissions in response. This paper gives detailed information on how the new assessment tool will work and seeks input from the community organisations on:
. improvements to the wording of the questionnaires;
. additional descriptors to be included in the functional areas of behaviour, emotional state and special care needs;
. who might be an appropriate independent person to complete a set of questionnaires where there is non‐correlation between the parent's and treating health professional's score; and
. additional conditions which should be included as part of the manifest disabilities and chronic medical conditions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Adelaide Hospital: Telstra Research Study

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can details be provided of the design brief for the recent Telstra research study, carried out at the Royal Adelaide Hospital.
(2) What were the objectives of this research study.
(3) Why were transgenic mice used in this research.
(4) Is this study to be replicated: if so (a) by whom; and (b) when.
(5) What are the implications of this study for the exposure standards applicable to cellular mobile phones.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have been advised that the general design of the Telstra research study was based on a similar study that had been previously planned to determine whether 50 Hz powerline fields influence cancer rates in transgenic mice. Telstra saw a unique opportunity to conduct a parallel experiment alongside the original proposed study that would replace the 50 Hz fields exposure with digital mobile phone radiowaves. Both experiments were performed under the auspices of the Royal Adelaide Hospital which devolved the responsibility for the design, conduct, analysis and publication of the two studies to an independent Steering Committee chaired by professor Tony Basten from the Centenary Institute of Cancer Medicine & Cell Biology in Sydney. This Committee had sole responsibility for publishing the results of the digital mobile phone study in the recent issue of Radiation Research (May 1997). A copy of the paper was provided to Telstra after it had been accepted for publication.
(2) The objective of the study as stated in the abstract of the journal paper reporting the experiment was:

"The aim of the present study was to determine whether long‐term exposure to pulse‐modulated RF fields similar to those used in digital mobile telecommunications would increase the incidence of lymphoma in Eu‐Pim1 transgenic mice, which are moderately predisposed to develop lymphoma spontaneously".

(3) I am advised that transgenic mice of the type used in this research carry an extra gene which makes them unusually prone to developing cancer of the immune system (lymphoma) following long term exposure to known carcinogens. These mice are therefore a highly sensitive model for testing the very subtle effects, if any, of agents like electromagnetic fields. Such a model was considered to be a valuable tool given the fact that over thirty years of research into electromagnetic fields has failed to provide conclusive evidence of any carcinogenic effects.

(4) (a) & (b) The researchers have recommended that there be independent confirmation of the results and to test the effects of varying exposure doses. A well designed proposal could, if submitted, be considered for inclusion in the NHMRC managed Australian EME Research program. Given the international interest generated and the scale of resources that may be required for confirmation studies there may be scope for international cooperation on the follow‐up studies.

(5) The Australian standard AS2772.1 was developed through a consultative process by Standards Australia, an independent, non‐Government organisation. Any questions about the standards development process should be addressed to Standards Australia.

It is, however, difficult to see the study on its own affecting current standards, particularly in the absence of confirmation and establishment of any dose/response relationship. In addition, the researchers themselves, in reporting the work, qualified the results and specifically indicated that they should not be extended to the human exposure case. This study would also need to be considered in the context of other published or continuing research in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there some delay, for example of more than a day or two, between the time child support payments are received by the Child Support Agency from one parent before being forwarded on to the other parent; if so: (a) what is the average length of this delay; (b) what are the reasons for this delay; (c) where is the money held/invested during this time; and (d) if interest is accrued on this money, do either of the parents receive this additional amount?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (a) Payments of child support are required to be forwarded to the Child Support Agency (CSA) by the seventh day of the month following the month to which the debt relates. If the child support due is received by this time, it will be forwarded onto the payee by the Department of Social Security (DSS) on the third Wednesday of the month. Payments received after the seventh of the month will be forwarded to the payee by DSS on the first Wednesday of the following month.

(b) Once child support payments are received by the CSA they are reconciled with the payer's account and paid into the Child Support Trust Account. The payments are drawn from this account by DSS in time to accord with their regular disbursement days on the first and third Wednesdays of each month.

(c) Between receipt in the CSA and disbursement by DSS, child support payments are held in the Child Support Trust Account, which forms part of the Commonwealth Public Account, the daily credit balance of which attracts interest.
(d) Neither parent receives any interest accrued.
