ATTORNEY‐GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT
Chief General Counsel
18 April 1997
PARLIAMENTARY PRIVILEGES ACT 1987 , s.16: IMPACT ON CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION
MEMORANDUM

The issue of the impact of s.16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 has been raised with me in the context of a suggestion that the Senate might, possibly through a Privileges Committee inquiry, undertake its own investigation of allegations concerning Senator Colston. I understand the Director of Public Prosecutions has raised concerns about the impact of s.16, if a Senate inquiry is held, for the presentation of evidence in any criminal case that might result from the present criminal investigation.

2. Section 16 was enacted following concern at the narrow interpretation of the scope of parliamentary privilege in relation to the use of evidence in criminal trials given by two judges of the NSW Supreme Court in relation to the prosecution of Justice Murphy (see Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, 7th ed. pp.3‐5). The Murphy trial followed extensive separate Senate inquiries at which much evidence critical to the subsequent trial had been produced, and evidence had been received at those inquiries from key witnesses subsequently called during the trial. The narrow interpretation given to the then applicable parliamentary privilege (derived from Article 9 of the 1688 Bill of Rights) enabled much evidence and cross‐examination to occur that would not have been possible on a wider view of the extent of the privilege.
3. Parliament's response was to enact a very broad provision in s.16. For present purposes the two key sub‐sections are subsection (3) and (4) which are as follows:

(3) In proceedings in any court or tribunal, it is not lawful for evidence to be tendered or received, question asked or statements, submissions or comments made, concerning proceedings in Parliament, by way of, or for the purpose of:

PARA.TAB: (a) questioning or relying on the truth, motive, intention or good faith of anything forming part of those proceedings in Parliament;
(b) otherwise questioning or establishing the credibility, motive, intention or good faith of any person; or
(c) drawing, or inviting the drawing of, inferences or conclusions wholly or partly from anything forming part of those proceedings in Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: (4) A court or tribunal shall not:

PARA.TAB: (a) require to be produced, or admit into evidence, a document that has been prepared for the purpose of submission, a submitted, to a House or a committee and has been directed by a House or a committee to be treated as evidence taken in camera, or admit evidence relating to such a document; or

(b) admit evidence concerning any oral evidence taken by a House or a committee in camera or require to be produced or admit into evidence a document recording or reporting any such oral evidence, unless a House or a committee has published, or authorised the publication of, that document or a report of that oral evidence.

ANSWER.PARA: 4. Subsection 16(2) defines "proceedings in Parliament" for purposes of the section. Again it is a broad definition and includes the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) the giving of evidence before the House or a committee, and evidence so given;
(b) the presentation or submission of a document to a House or committee;
(c) the preparation of a document for purposes of or identical to the transacting of any such business; and
(d) the formulation, making or publication of a document, including a report, by or pursuant to an order of the House or a committee and the document so formulated made or published.

ANSWER.PARA: 5. There are two aspects to section 16 or relevance for present purposes:

PARA.TAB: ‐ production of documents in a Court
‐ questioning of persons concerning "proceedings in Parliament"

ANSWER.PARA: 6. As to the first, S.16 does not prevent the admission in evidence in a court of a document tabled in Parliament or submitted to a Senate committee as evidence, unless it was evidence taken in camera (s.16(4)(a)). Thus, documents made public and published with appropriate Parliamentary authority are not prohibited from being admitted in a court, but there are significant limitations on the use that can be made of those documents, as I will outline below. Oral testimony before a committee given in camera can be produced only if the House or committee authorises the publication (s.16(4)(b)).

7. The other and potentially more significant limitation imposed by s.16 is the use that can be made in court of any evidence or documents given to the House or committee that is lawfully before the court. Subsection 16(3) significantly limits the ability to question a person about the veracity of anything forming part of parliamentary proceedings, and from questioning the credibility, motive, intention or good faith fo a person, or drawing inferences or conclusions wholly or partly from anything forming part of those proceedings in Parliament. The effect of subsection 16(3) read with the broad definition of "proceedings in Parliament" in subsection 16(2) is to severely restrict the ability of a court to test evidence or undertake cross‐examination of a witness in relation to matters forming part of proceedings in Parliament.

8. Thus, I understand that statements presented to the Senate on 24 March 1997 made by Senator Colston and Mrs Smith, having been authorised for publication, have already been identified as "proceedings in Parliament" to which subsection 16(3) would apply. This would not prevent Senator Colston or Mrs Smith from giving their accounts in court of relevant events. However, the statements which the Senate authorised for publication could not be used in court proceedings to support or contradict those accounts. Nor could they be used for any other substantive purpose in Court proceedings.

9. The same position applies in relation to facts or matters dealt with in any other documents forming part of the "parliamentary proceedings" as defined. It would be necessary to establish the facts or matters in question for purposes of any court proceedings without reliance on the parliamentary proceedings. This suggests serious problems may arise if the originals of any key documents eg, travel vouchers were to be tabled or presented to Parliament. In relation to answers to questions arising in Estimates or answers to questions on notice, the same limits apply to the use that could be made fo the answers as applies to other documents forming part of parliamentary proceedings, as outlined above. The information contained in the answers would need to be established in court other than by reliance on the answers provided to the Senate or its Committees. Nor could there be cross‐examination in court of any person based on what may appear prior inconsistent statements by them in parliamentary proceedings. Hence, the greater the relevant information or material that becomes part of "parliamentary proceedings:, the more that that information or material will not effectively be open to questioning and testing in any court proceedings, and the actual parliamentary proceedings will not be able to be used to establish key facts.
10. The legal position created by s.16 outlined briefly above points to the following conclusions:

PARA.TAB: (a) if the Senate investigates, takes evidence or authorises the publication of material relating to the matters at present under criminal investigation in relation to Senator Colston, this may have the consequence that much material will be privileged and immune from the testing and examination which is an essential part of a criminal trail and the material cannot be used to establish the facts in question.

(b) the current criminal investigation can best proceed and subsequent criminal proceedings, if any, are likely to be less hindered if the Senate does not undertake its own investigation into matters that may be relevant to the criminal proceedings. The likely impact of any particular statement evidence or material provided in such an inquiry on the actual investigation and any subsequent proceedings is, of course, a matter on which the Director of Public Prosecutions is better placed to comment, given his responsibility for the consideration of the evidence that may be necessary to sustain any particular charges. However, pending the conclusion of the investigation and the identification of any particular charges it will be difficult to identify in advance what material may have relevance to any charge.

ANSWER.PARA: Henry Burmester
Chief General Counsel
ATTORNEY‐GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT
Chief General Counsel
21 April 1997
PARLIAMENTARY PRIVILEGES ACT 1987 , s.16: IMPACT ON CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION
SUPPLEMENTARY MEMORANDUM

The Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, has written to Senator Faulkner, outlining his views as to whether any difficulties would be occasioned by a Senate inquiry into statements made by Senator Colston and Mrs Christine Smith and presented to the Senate on 24 March 1997.

2. I have been invited to comment on the letter, of which I have a copy, in light of my memorandum of 18 April 1997 on the impact of parliamentary privilege on a criminal investigation. I offer the following comments:

3. In determining the likely impact of a Senate inquiry on a criminal investigation and possible subsequent prosecution, the scope of any inquiry is clearly important. Mr Evans says "the proposed Senate inquiry would not be into the same matters as are subject to police investigation". Mr Evans envisages an inquiry confined to the truth of the statements, which are already immune from use in criminal proceedings as they are proceedings in Parliament within the meaning of s.16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 . It is a matter for judgment whether a Senate inquiry into these matters could in fact be confined in a way that did not trespass more broadly into matters the current subject of criminal investigation.

4. Mr Evans notes that a Senate inquiry would not create "insurmountable difficulties". This seems to acknowledge that at least some difficulties might arise. The inability to cross‐examine a person in relation to their parliamentary evidence is acknowledged "as a limitation on either the prosecution or defence in seeking to attack the veracity of (`the persons's) court evidence". Whether if further statements and evidence are taken this would "only marginally increase" the difficulty, as contended by Mr Evans, is again a matter for judgement. As I indicated in my first memorandum, it is difficult in advance of knowing the outcome of a criminal investigation to identify what material may be relevant to any charge that might eventuate.

5. The one area in the letter of Mr Evans that I consider significantly down plays the effect of an inquiry is in relation to documentary evidence. Mr Evans suggests that if documentary evidence, not being documents formulated for the purpose of the Senate inquiry, was presented to a Senate Committee and authorised for publication it would "depending on its nature. . . .thereby attain the same status as the statements by Senator Colston and Mrs Smith and could be used in legal proceedings." Mr Evans suggests that if there was a concern about particular evidence "the committee could avoid any difficulty by not ordering the publication of the documents".

6. Presumably what Mr Evans has in mind is that the originals of eg, travel documents would not be tabled, only photocopies, so that the originals would still be available for use in Court. I have adverted to this issue in paragraph 9 of my earlier memorandum. The fact that evidence before a Committee is not published ensures that it cannot be ordered to be produced in court (see s.16(4) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act ). If evidence is treated as "in camera" this will avoid matters being placed on the public record and then becoming immune from being tested in a court. This has been one particular concern raised in relation to s.16. However, it will not avoid the basic difficulty, namely, that evidence given to a parliamentary committee that may be critical to a criminal trial cannot be tested or questioned before a court. The fact that material is kept confidential does not help if that material represents key evidence that would be of importance for the proper trial of an issue that ends up before a Court. Nor may it be politically practicable to take evidence in camera, given the great public interest and the fact that the material is not of its nature inherently sensitive information.

7. In short, Mr Evans and I generally do not disagree about the legal effect of the Parliamentary Privileges Act . The difference in our views relates essentially to the likely impact of a Senate inquiry, given the acknowledged legal consequences of the legislation.

Mr Evans considers the issue on the basis of a narrow, carefully controlled Senate inquiry. Whether that is a feasible scenario is a matter of judgment. Given the uncertainty in advance of knowing what material may have relevance to any possible charge that may eventuate, and the uncertainty about the scope of an inquiry. I confirm my earlier views.
Henry Burmester
Chief General Counsel

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did an operation known as `Brook Island Trial' take place in north Queensland in February 1944 which involved the testing of mustard gas on volunteers; if so, can details of that testing be provided.

(2) Was an army hospital established at Woodstock, north Queensland, to handle medical cases from the mustard gas testing; if so: (a) over what period did it operate; (b) were medical records maintained for all patients of that hospital; (c) would those records still be in existence today; (d) where would they be held; and (e) are those records accessible or are they `classified information'.
(3) During this operation, were personal health cards kept by those volunteers who were injured showing the parts of their body affected by the mustard gas.
(4) Were Dunk, Brook or Hinchinbrook Islands used for mustard gas testing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question :

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The `Brook Island Trial' took place on North Brook Island in February 1944. It was the culmination of various tests which had been conducted in the Innisfail area. Aircraft weapons, comprising both gas filled bombs and various types of gas spray were tested using Beaufort bombers from Bowen. The effects were measured on Japanese‐style bunkers and foxholes containing goats. Chemical sampling equipment was installed, and troops landed at various times after the bombing in different types of anti‐gas protection equipment. The testing of mustard gas on volunteers took place on the mainland at Innisfail. This physiological research was to determine the effects of mustard vapour on the human body under tropical conditions. Other tests conducted at Innisfail included the tolerance of man to dibutyl phthalate, which was used to suppress the vector of scrub typhus, and the effect of wearing anti‐gas clothing on the ability of troops to perform normal duties and do heavy work in a tropical rain forest. Details of the testing are summarised in the `Gillis Report', which was tabled in Federal Parliament on March 1987 by the then Minister for Defence.

(2) There was no Army hospital at Woodstock. The 2/14 Army General Hospital was located in Townsville. During the mustard gas trials at Innisfail, a ward at Innisfail hospital was dedicated for use by the medical and scientific staff conducting the trials. The ward was used from 1943 until the end of 1944 when the Field Experimental Station and the 1st Field Trials Company were moved to Proserpine. Medical records or case histories were maintained on all volunteers, not all of whom were hospitalised. Most, if not all, of these case histories are contained in `Chemical Warfare—Trials', Australian War Memorial Series 54, 179/5/7, Parts 1 to 10. These records are open for public access.

(3) Yes. Personal medical records were maintained during the trials and would have formed part of the volunteer's medical record. At the end of the war, the medical records of all ex‐servicemen were sent to the then Repatriation Department in the State of enlistment of the member.

(4) Brook Island was used for the aerial delivery of mustard vapour. Hinchinbrook Island was not used for testing purposes, but was used occasionally as a staging area for personnel waiting to go to Brook Island to check the equipment after bombing had taken place. There is no evidence that Dunk Island was used for any military activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 16 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Regional Forest Agreement for western Victoria was to rely heavily on the outcome of a special investigation by the Victorian Land Conservation Council into box and ironbark forests and woodlands.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the Victorian Government abolished the Victorian Land Conservation Council before it could complete its report into that investigation.

(3) How can a guarantee be given that the Commonwealth forest reserve benchmark of 15 per cent of the pre-European extent of each forest type will be satisfied in the Western Victorian Regional Forest Agreement when the study integral to the agreement process has not been completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. The Victorian Government has announced the replacement of the Land Conservation Council with a new body, the Environment Conservation Council. The Victorian Government has also announced that the Environment Conservation Council will be responsible for the completion of the Box/Ironbark Special Investigation and that completion of this investigation remains a priority.

(3) The Commonwealth and Victorian Governments remain committed to establishing a Comprehensive, Representative and Adequate forest reserve system in the West region of Victoria which meets the nationally agreed reserve criteria. The West region Regional Forest Agreement is scheduled for completion in 1999 and the findings of the Box/Ironbark Special Investigation will be available for consideration during the preparation of the agreement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 16 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is Australia's annual rate of native vegetation clearance.
(2) How does this compare to Brazil, India, Indonesia, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Mexico, Bolivia, Venezuela, and Thailand.
(3) What is Queensland's annual rate of vegetation clearance.
(4) How much money is allocated to Queensland in the 1996-97 financial year under: (a) the Natural Heritage Trust; and (b) the Bushcare program.
(5) How much of that funding may go to State government agencies.
(6) What percentage of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions come from vegetation clearing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Current estimates are somewhat uncertain however the best information available puts the rate of clearing across Australia at approximately 400,000 hectares per year. Research is underway which should provide a more accurate assessment.
(2) Data on vegetation clearing in these countries are not currently available.
(3) Most recent studies found the rate of land clearing in Queensland to have averaged 308,000 hectares per annum from 1991-95.

(4) Bushcare integrates and significantly enhances several former vegetation programs including the Save the Bush and One Billion Trees programs. These programs were funded in 1996-97 in Queensland for $229,250 and $85,400 respectively. In addition the Wet Tropics Tree Planting Scheme received $1,472,601 and the Sugar Coast Environment Rescue Package received $2 million.

(5) State agencies are eligible for funding under the State-Commonwealth component of the Natural Heritage Trust. It is my intention that about 80% of funding for Bushcare will go toward community grants and on-ground outcomes. The State-Commonwealth component in partnership with State agencies will therefore be a lesser percentage of funding. Allocations for both community and State components will be based upon the merit of project proposals received.

(6) Although there is considerable uncertainty in the inventory data at this stage, the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory (1994) suggests that the category "landuse change and forestry" accounts for 26% of Australia's total greenhouse gas emissions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why are there no representatives on the WEST 2000 Board from Aboriginal groups, non-government conservation groups, or the tourism and mining industries, given that it is a program meant to promote sustainable land use and industry diversification for the entire New South Wales Western Division community.

(2) Given that WEST 2000 will provide considerable subsidies to assist unviable pastoralists to leave the pastoral industry, what measures will be taken to prevent the re-sale of leases to new producers with no better prospects of managing this publicly-leased land in an economically and ecologically sustainable fashion.
(3) How much funding will be allocated to the control of grazing resistant native plants, so-called `woody weeds'.
(4) How is woody weed eradication and control reconciled with election commitments to seek no net loss of native vegetation.
(5) Why is the public subsiding the eradication of native vegetation through WEST 2000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The WEST 2000 Management Board was appointed by the NSW Minister for Land and Water Conservation, the Hon Kimberley Yeadon to implement the WEST 2000 Strategy and to coordinate stakeholder input. The WEST 2000 strategy provides for Community Reference Forums which are convened by the Board to provide opportunities to seek input from the community on the implementation of the WEST 2000 initiative.

(2) The objective of the re-establishment grants provided under WEST 2000 is to facilitate the exit of landholders who have taken the decision to leave the industry. While the Government does not interfere in the sale of properties, a range of measures are included in the WEST 2000 Strategy to encourage the economic and ecologically sustainable management of all land in the Western Division. The productivity enhancement measure aims to facilitate farm build up, and other measures seek to widen management options by facilitating the development of alternative industries, improving management skills and assisting with property planning.
(3) Assistance totalling $843 311 has been specifically allocated for the control of woody weeds over the period 1997-2000.

(4) Woody weed eradication is part of a strategic approach to integrated management of native vegetation in the Western Division. Reduction in shrub density of species that have become dominant in the relatively low fire/high grazing management regimes since European settlement, is a precursor to integrated management of rangeland vegetation to enable the re-emergence and continuing health of diverse rangeland plant communities.

(5) WEST 2000 is funding integrated scrub management which is regarded as the most appropriate long term management strategy for the Western Division rangelands. These strategies are expected to yield significant natural resource management and economic benefits to the region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 17 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the petition presented by members of the public, including prominent Australians, the Friends of the Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC) and ABC unions to the Prime Minister, on 27 March 1997, from more than 63 000 signatories expressing outrage and deep concern at the savage funding cuts to the ABC:
When will the Prime Minister present this petition to the Parliament, as required in the wording of the petition, given that it is now approximately 3 months since the petition was presented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The petition will be tabled in the next session of Parliament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 18 June 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the foreign currency limits imposed on Indian emigrants upon departure from India.
(2) What advice is given to overseas applicants for Australian permanent residence visas regarding the availability of Social Security income support in Australia.

(3) Is the Minister considering restricting the issue of permanent visas to applicants who either have sufficient funds for self‐support for up to 2 years from the date of arrival in Australia or have a sponsor or pre‐arranged employment in Australia.
(4) Has the Minister been alerted to the fact that unsponsored applicants with minimal assets are being approved for permanent residency despite having no ability to support themselves in Australia.

(5) Has the Minister drawn this issue to the attention of the Minister for Social Security, particularly in respect of the guidelines for the payment of special benefit, for example the disallowable instrument gazetted on 21 March 1997.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister is aware of the amounts that can be transferred out of India. The amount of foreign currency that a migrant can transfer out of India is, as a general rule, limited to $500US per person. In addition, a migrant can seek permission to transfer other amounts out of India by lodging a fixed deposit equal to the amount to be taken out of India and signing an undertaking to remit that amount back to India over an agreed time period.
(2) The following advice is included in visa grant letters to intending migrants (except refugee and humanitarian entrants):

PARA.TAB: "All migrants except refugee and humanitarian visa holders and their immediate family members (partner and dependent children), must wait two years before they are eligible to receive certain payments, including unemployment payments, from the Australian Department of Social Security.
You may be eligible for special benefit if, after arriving in Australia, your circumstances change for reasons beyond your control resulting in severe hardship.
If you have children you may be immediately eligible for family allowance and maternity allowance.

For further information on payments you should contact the Department of Social Security by telephone on 13 2468 or the Department's Multilingual Telephone Information Service on 13 1202 from anywhere in Australia."

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The points test applied to applicants in the Independent and the Skilled Australian Linked visa classes is being reviewed. The issue of whether a minimum level of capital available for transfer to Australia should be a requirement for these two categories will be considered by the review.

(4) The Minister is aware of three cases where Independent migrants have apparently been unable to support themselves soon after their arrival in Australia. Such cases, are the exception rather than the rule in respect of Independent migrants. Research has shown that on average Independent migrants bring assets to Australia to the value of over $25,000. Further, the underlying rationale of the Independent migrant category is that migrants selected under this category will be able to make a positive contribution to the Australian economy on the basis of their youth, their ability to speak English and educational or skill levels. Officers assessing such applications overseas are conscious of the need to assess the ability of the migrant to settle successfully in Australia, and do in some cases reject applicants on this basis despite the applicant otherwise being eligible for a visa. Ultimately it is a decision for the applicant whether or not they actually migrate to Australia and what assets they bring with them to assist in their settlement in Australia.
(5) The Minister for Social Security is aware of the issue.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Memorandum of Understanding: Fire Fighting Facilities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the department have a contract or memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Australian Construction Services for conversion of fire fighting facilities at HMAS Creswell, Cerberus and Stirling or some other MOU issued pursuant to request for tender DMCP‐N 127.
(2) Is the arrangement ongoing.

(3) Were the details of the MOU published in the Commonwealth Government Gazette in accordance with regulation 43B of the Finance Regulations, which requires any contract signed by the Commonwealth to be published; if so, when were they published; if not, why not.
(4) What is the total estimated liability under the MOU in accordance with regulation 43B of the Finance Regulations.
(5) What is the period of the arrangement under the MOU.
(6) Has the service been provided solely by Australian Construction Services or by sub‐contractors or both.
(7) If sub‐contractors are, or have been, involved: (a) who were they; and (b) what is the value of the work to date by each sub‐contractor.
(8) Can a copy of the MOU be provided.
(9) Can copies of any agreements between Australian Construction Services and its sub‐contractors be provided.
(10) What is the total value of work done to date at HMAS Creswell, Cerberus and Stirling.
(11) What is the total value of work done to date by sub‐contractors at the above facilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister For Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 28 February 1994, my Department signed an Arrangement (No. 8530DV) with Australian Construction Services for the conversion of fire fighting training facilities at HMAS Creswell, Cerberus and Stirling to automated liquid propane gas burning systems. This Arrangement was issued pursuant to Request for Tender No. DMCP‐N 127/93.
(2) The Arrangement was satisfactorily finalised on 9 December 1996.
(3) Details of the Arrangement were published in the Commonwealth of Australia Purchasing and Disposals Gazette No. PD 15 of 20 April 1994, on page 2103.

(4) The estimated liability under the Arrangement, as published in Gazette No. PD15 in accordance with regulation 43B of the Finance Regulations, was $4,063,109.00. The total final liability authorised by the Department under the Arrangement was $4,323,408.50.
(5) The period of the Arrangement was from 28 February 1994 to 9 December 1996.
(6) The service was provided by Australian Construction Services and by subcontractors.
(7) (a) Subcontractors to Australian Construction Services were Industrial Control Technology Pty Ltd, International Code Services Inc, and Kilpatrick Green Pty Ltd.

(b) My Department is unable to provide details of the value of work by each subcontractor as this information is only held by the Department of Administrative Services, which regards the information as Commercial‐In‐Confidence. That Department was responsible for the operations of the former Australian Construction Services organisation.
(8) A copy of the Arrangement cannot be provided as it contains Commercial‐In‐Confidence information.

(9) Copies of any agreements between Australian Construction Services and its subcontractors cannot be provided by my Department. Consultations with the Department of Administrative Services indicate that the documents would not be releaseable as they contain Commercial‐In‐Confidence information.
(10) The total value of work done at HMAS Creswell, Cerberus and Stirling under the Arrangement is $4,323,408.50.

(11) Details of the total value of work done by subcontractors under the Arrangement are only held by the Department of Administrative Services and will not be disclosed as this data is Commercial‐In‐Confidence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 20 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Sports Commission provide funding or any other form of support to the Aerobica Event staged in Perth from 28 May to 2 June 1997.
(2) If funding or any other form of support was provided, can details be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, funding from the Australian Sports Commission's Sports Assistance Scheme (SAS) was provided to the Australian Gymnastics Federation (AGF) for the conduct of this event, which was sanctioned by the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) as a pinnacle event on its international competition calendar.

(2) Under SAS guidelines for hosting international events in Australia the Australian Sports Commission Board considered an application from the AGF and approved a grant of $50,000 towards the conduct of the FIG 3rd World Championships in Sport Aerobics which were held in Perth from 31 May to 1 June 1997.
The grant was provided to offset the costs of staging the Championships, budgeted at $445,000, and the AGF is bound by contract to provide a report on the event and a full acquittal of the $50,000.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to a special visa category that will allow some 8 000 people to remain in Australia as long‐term temporary residents, announced on 13 June 1997 by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock):
(1) Is this new visa category designed to resolve the status of people who have been living in Australia for many years in a state of uncertainty.

(2) (a) In what way does the situation of the 1 360 East Timorese asylum seekers, some of who have been here for 7 years, differ from that of others granted the new visa category; and (b) why were the East Timorese excluded.
(3) Is it a fact that many of the 1 360 East Timorese asylum seekers have lost family members and been subjected to detention, torture and rape in East Timor.
(4) Has the Portuguese Government made it clear that they will not accept East Timorese asylum seekers deported from Australia.
(5) Are the 1 360 East Timorese asylum seekers at present being forced to go through a futile and costly determination process, further adding to their trauma and uncertainty.
(6) Will the Minister create another special visa category specifically designed to cover the unique circumstances of the 1 360 East Timorese asylum seekers, if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minster for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the new visa category is intended to resolve the status of certain citizenship groups who, for humanitarian reasons, were the subject of previous specific temporary stay arrangements.
(2) (a) Unlike the intended recipients of the new visa, the East Timorese asylum seekers have not been the subject of specific earlier humanitarian temporary stay concessions.
(b) In my answer to 2(a) I have already addressed this question.

(3) The Government is not in the position to provide information about the circumstances of East Timorese asylum seekers and their families as a whole. Each asylum seeker's circumstances differ and my Department is under an obligation to consider all applications on a case by case basis. Further to this, I am unable to provide information about the circumstances of individual cases due to privacy considerations.

(4) The Portuguese government has confirmed that, as East Timor was a non‐self‐governing territory under Portuguese administration, some East Timorese are Portuguese citizens under relevant Portuguese nationality law. Those East Timorese citizens who are Portuguese citizens may avail themselves of the protection of Portugal and, upon application, receive relevant documentation.

(5) East Timorese applicants are being processed in line with Australia's international obligations under the terms of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees. Australia is recognised internationally as having a high quality refugee determination procedure delivering fair, lawful and just decisions.

(6) The Government has made it clear that applications from East Timorese asylum seekers will be assessed on a case by case basis in accordance with Australia's international obligations under the Refugee's Convention and in accordance with domestic law.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice on 23 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What provision has been made in the 1997-98 budget for the establishment of a national repository for nuclear waste.
(2) At what stage is the process to select a site for the repository
(3) When is a final decision on site selection expected to be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Refer to `Portfolio Budget Statements 1997-98: Primary Industries and Energy Portfolio' Budget Related Paper No 1.12. The 1997-98 Budget has allocated funds of $M1.784 and a further $M3.354 to June 2001 for the national radioactive waste repository program. The program is budget neutral with costs to be recovered through user disposal charges.

(2) Phase 3 of the study to select a suitable site for a national repository for low level and short-lived intermediate level radioactive waste is proceeding. A public report which will identify a preferred region from the eight regions identified in the 1994 Phase 2 report is expected to be released within a year.

(3) On the basis of field investigations and public consultation, a site within the preferred region is expected to be identified by the end of 1998 for detailed environmental and safety assessment. A final decision on the suitability of the identified site is expected to be made on completion of these studies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the sinking of HMAS Sydney on 19 and 20 November 1941:

(1) (a) Did John Doohan of Willagee, Convenor of the End Secrets on Sydney Group write to the Prime Minister on 25 June 1997 informing him that the presence and identity of Nazi Raider Kormoran, then known as Steiermark, on Australia's north west coast were known to Australian Military Intelligence from various sources, from October 1941 until 19 November 1941; and (b) did he provide the Prime Minister with a confirming statutory declaration of 30 January 1995 by Group Captain CAV Bourne, a retired Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) officer who participated in an aerial search for the raider during that period.

(2) Can confirmation be given of the content of Group Captain Bourne's declaration that such aerial searches for Steiermark were carried out in October and November 1941 and that photographs of Steiermark were then in possession of the RAAF as sworn by Group Captain Bourne.

(3) If confirmation cannot be given, will the Prime Minister then deny the content of Group Captain Bourne's 30 January 1995 statutory declaration and provide a comprehensive explanation of this denial; if not, why not.

(4) (a) Did John Doohan write to the Prime Minister on 25 June 1997 requesting information on the claimed `high frequency cathode ray direction finder' (HFCRDF) tracking of the Nazi Raider Kormoran, then known as Steiermark, in November 1941; and (b) will the Prime Minister confirm the statutory declaration by Reginald E Lander, a specialist technician who participated in that tracking of Kormoran; if not, why not.

(5) Will the Minister confirm the content of Reginald E Lander's declaration of 30 April 1997 that Kormoran was tracked during the November period from HFCRDF facilities installed at Holsworthy Army Remount Depot, Ingleburn, New South Wales; Qantas Empire Airways Flying Boat Base, Rose Bay, New South Wales and Pearce RAAF Station, Western Australia.

(6) If confirmation cannot be given, will the Prime Minister deny the content of Reginald E Lander's 30 April 1997 statutory declaration and provide a comprehensive explanation of this denial; if not, why not.
(7) Were the above named bases in New South Wales and Western Australia equipped with HFCRDF facilities in 1941.

(8) Did John Doohan write to the Prime Minister on 25 June 1997 in relation to written and media published statements by Lutheran Pastor Ivan Wittwer of Cleve, South Australia, that a Kormoran Nazi survivor, Gerhardt Heinz Grossmann, had informed Brigadier, then Colonel, Spry of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) in May 1951 that a Japanese submarine in company with Kormoran had torpedoed HMAS Sydney and that Sydney's survivors where then murdered by Japanese small arms fire.

(9) (a) Did John Doohan on 25 June 1997 provide the Prime Minister with a copy of Pastor Wittwer's written statement of 2 June 1997 and a copy of the Eyre Peninsula Tribune of 1 May 1997, confirming that Pastor Wittwer has made these significant statements; and (b) what is the Prime Minister's view of these statements.

(10) Will the Prime Minister immediately obtain from all Government agencies and departments concerned, particularly the Australian Federal Police, ASIO and the Department of Immigration, all details of claimed Grossman interviews with ASIO and others and the subsequent deportation of Grossmann; if not, will the Prime Minister comprehensively explain the reasons for denial.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes, Mr Doohan has sent a facsimile letter regarding the loss of HMAS Sydney in 1941. The letter referred to three attachments which were not received. The original letter has not been received.
(b) No, a Statutory Declaration of 30 January 1995 by Group Captain CAV Bourne was not provided.
(2)—(3) Without Group Captain Bourne's declaration I am unable to comment further.
(4a) Yes.
(4b)—(6) The Statutory Declaration referred to in the letter was not provided. Without Mr Reginald Lander's declaration I am unable to comment further.

(7) It is assumed that the question refers to High Frequency Direction Finding (HF/DF) equipment. Defence has advised that this type of facility was established at RAAF Base Pearce, Western Australia in 1937. If the question refers to Radio Direction Finding (RDF), later known as Radar, the first station was not established in Western Australia until November 1942.
(8) Yes.
(9) (a) No, the media article and written statement referred to in the letter were not provided.
(b) Without Pastor Wittwer's written statement I am unable to comment further.

(10) ASIO has made a detailed search of its records regarding both HMAS Sydney and the alleged contact in 1951 between Colonel Spry, formerly Director‐General of Security, and Gerhardt Grossmann. This search was a result of two requests from researchers via Australian Archives. No records concerning either event were located.

The Australian Archives has advised that they have undertaken a detailed search of their holdings for any records relating to Gerhardt Grossmann's alleged interview with ASIO officers and his alleged deportation. They have been unable to identify any relevant records in their custody.
The Australian Federal Police and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs have advised that they hold no records relating to a Gerhardt Heinz Grossmann.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: asked the minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 27 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Apart from Senator Colston, whose travelling allowance details have been extensively tabled and debated in the Senate, for the period 1 July 1993 to 27 May 1997.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Milk Fed Veal: Code of Practice

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 27 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a relevant Australian Code of Practice which prohibits milk fed veal.
(2) Is it the case that this code is not legally enforceable.
(3) Do the relevant farming or producer organisations maintain that self-regulation of this code is ensuring it is adhered to.
(4) Is there any evidence that restaurants and/or butchers are offering milk fed veal for sale.
(5) Is it the case that any restaurants or butchers who do advertise milk fed veal would be misrepresenting what they are selling, or would this mean that the code is not being adhered to.
(6) In relation to (5), what action is able to be taken if either eventuality proved to be the case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The relevant code is the Australian Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals—Cattle which includes a section which provides for artificial rearing of calves.

(2) Constitutional responsibility to animal welfare and livestock production matters rests with individual State and Territory Governments. The States and Territories exercise their legislative control over animal welfare through State/Territory animal welfare legislation. I understand that animal welfare Codes of Practice are not legally enforceable in all States/Territories.

(3) I am advised that the Cattle Council of Australia maintains that self regulation of the Code of Practice ensures, to the extent possible, that it is adhered to, and that legislation will not necessarily ensure that the Code of Practice will be adhered to.

(4) I am advised that most veal offered for sale in Australia is derived from bobby calves, ie. male calves from dairy herds sold as soon as possible after birth. However, a small quantity of veal is derived from calves raised, at least initially, on milk.

(5) Restaurants and butchers who do advertise milk fed veal would not necessarily be misrepresenting what they are selling, nor would it necessarily mean that the Code of Practice is not being adhered to.
(6) I am advised that action against misrepresentation of product may be taken under Commonwealth and State/Territory consumer protection laws.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 30 June 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Is the minister still practising surgery; if so: (a) on what basis; and (b) with what regularity.

(2) If the minister is not currently practising surgery, has he performed any surgery after 7 May 1996; if so: (a) on what basis; (b) how often; and (c) when did the minister cease performing surgery.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) At the request of former patients needing follow‐up from earlier treatment, since 7 May 1996 I have seen patients for consultations on 19 days and performed surgery 5 times—an average of about twice per month in all, with an average of about 1 hour per week spent on consultations or surgery.

It was necessary for me to perform a minimum amount of surgery to be able to renew accreditation with the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. I have also during this period completed 40 years' continuous membership of the medical malpractice insurance scheme, necessary in order to qualify for compounded life membership.
I have incurred an operating loss during this period because of the cost of retaining rooms for such a limited practice.
The arrangements were approved by the Prime Minister on the understanding that my ministerial duties are paramount, including a requirement that I only see patients when Parliament is not sitting.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Women in Science, Engineering and Technology : Report

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department examined the report entitled Women in Science, Engineering and Technology (also known as the WISET report).

(2) Will creating a broad, positive environment in which all Australians have the maximum opportunity to achieve their potential improve the participation of women in science, engineering and technology careers.
(3) Are there any structural barriers to women participating in science, engineering or technology careers.
(4) Are there any programs directed at the participation of women in science, engineering or technology careers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Yes. See the answer to question on notice no 447, in Senate Hansard, 24 March 1997, p 2340.
(2) Yes. See the answer to question on notice no 447, in Senate Hansard, 24 March 1997, p 2340.
(3) The Government is not aware of any structural barriers to women participating in science, engineering or technology careers.
(4) There are a number of programs directed at women's' participation in science, engineering and technology careers. Government programs include:

Higher Education . The Government's Higher Education policy places an emphasis on quality, diversity and choice. It is committed to ensuring that financial, social and geographic factors do not act as a barrier to higher education for appropriately qualified students.

The Government is providing over $5 million per annum to universities under the Higher Education Equity Program (HEEP) to support strategies to increase participation by the equity target groups, including women in non‐traditional areas and post‐graduate study. Typical strategies employed by universities to improve educational outcomes for women in non‐traditional areas and post‐graduate study include re‐entry scholarships, school liaison programs, support and mentoring programs, publications and bridging courses.

The Government introduced, as part of the August 1996 Budget measures, a new system of merit‐based scholarships to assist members of equity target groups, including women in non‐traditional areas of study, to participate in higher education. The scholarships are to be awarded by universities on the basis of merit to non‐overseas students commencing an undergraduate course in 1997 or later, who are members of an equity target group. 1000 full‐time equivalent new merit‐based HECS exemption scholarships have been approved for each year from 1997, to a total of 4000 full‐time equivalent scholarships by the year 2000.

Vocational Education and Training . The Government's reform package for the apprenticeship and traineeship system will expand and improve training and employment opportunities for women. The National Apprenticeship Scheme (NAS) has the objective of strengthening enterprise training in Australia. NAS is a comprehensive set of reforms in vocational education and training which will simplify and improve the system of national qualifications and standards and ensure that enterprises can readily obtain training for employees which will enhance their productivity and profitability. These reforms include access and equity objectives, which will be pursued through individual choice and should include appropriate support for an individual in pursuing a particular option. Thus the access and equity focus will be on the training needs of the individual, rather than on their membership of a specific group. Of particular benefit to women with child care or other responsibilities will be the introduction of part‐time traineeships and other flexible arrangements.

In 1996, the National Women's Vocational Education and Training Strategy was endorsed by State, Territory and Commonwealth Ministers for Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs. The Strategy sets a national direction for governments, industry and providers of vocational education and training to ensure that the needs of women are consistently addressed as a priority in policy making, planning, resourcing, implementing and monitoring vocational education and training. Key outcomes expected from the strategy include a broader distribution of women across all fields of study, an increase in the number of women with qualifications at all levels and an increase in the participation and improved outcomes for specific groups of women, including young women. A wide range of implementation projects are being funded ($1.3 million) by ANTA to support the National Women's Vocational Education and Training Strategy. Projects include training and staff development, skills recognition, standards and curriculum, equity and change, decision making and continuous improvement measures

Primary and Secondary Education . The Commonwealth has provided funding for a number of programs and curriculum projects to challenge teacher, parent and community attitudes and extend post‐school life options for all students within the principles enumerated in the report of the Gender Equity Taskforce. These programs include:

Gender Equity Needs Analysis . This project will develop and trial a package of materials for use by schools which will include data gathering material which will assist school communities to gather data within their schools to inform them on a range of aspects of gender equity, and an interpretative framework consisting of guidelines to analyse and use the data gathered to develop focused gender equity programs incorporating goals, standards and benchmarks to assess progress;

Gender and School Education . This study sought to assess progress against selected indicators from the National Action Plan for the Education of Girls, focusing on those indicators not readily collected through normal administrative processes. Students' understanding of sex‐based harassment and their views on its incidence received particular attention;

Who Wins at School: Boys and Girls in Australian Secondary Education . This publication analyses the link between course selection, educational achievement and outcomes in relation to academic and career options, and socio‐economic backgrounds of male and female students. It relates higher retention rates of girls from all social groups in Years 11 and 12 to more restricted post‐school pathways for girls.

Science and Technology . The Department of Industry, Science and Tourism administers a Science and Technology Awareness Program which aims to increase awareness and understanding of the central role which science and technology play in Australia's economic and social well‐being.

In recognising the low participation rate of women at all levels of activity in science and technology and the need to make women and girls more aware of science and technology in career choices, the Science and Technology Awareness Program targets women particularly in the secondary education, tertiary education and employment arenas.

The S&T Awareness Project Grants for 1996‐97 supported two projects which specifically aimed at increasing women's awareness of science and technology. One of these is aimed at attracting women to forestry sciences through dispelling myths about the destructive or macho nature of the forestry industry. It will use teaching kits for Years 5‐9, published through the Internet, and teaching kits, displays and visits by women foresters for older students. The other project is intended to raise the profile of science among young people, particularly schoolgirls, through production and distribution of a special schools issue of the WISENET journal. It will seek to interest and inform girls as well as boys and teachers through short illustrated resumes of successful young scientists and descriptions of exciting scientific projects.

The Government is committed to support for a reconstituted science, engineering and technology awareness program to address issues such as remuneration and career paths for scientists; the low participation rate of women in the physical sciences and engineering; and career guidance in schools in SET and enterprise areas.

Australia plays an active role in the APEC Industrial Science and Technology Working Group (ISTWG), which will be holding an experts policy workshop in 1997 to discuss problems related to gathering and analysing gender‐disaggregated data on the participation of women in science, engineering and technology. It will also create an Ad Hoc Group of interested economies to share best gender practices, design a gender and S&T information site on the APEC Web page, and provide an informal forum for the exchange of policy ideas on gender and S&T.

The Women's Technology Network (WTN), a program of the ATSIC funded centre for Appropriate Technology, provides information, advice and support to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women and encourages them to be more involved in making decisions about technologies in their communities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 7 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How will the cut of $10.2 million to the Cooperative Research Centres (CRCs), announced in the 1997‐98 Budget, be allocated to CRCs.
(2) Will CRCs be subject to an efficiency dividend; if so: (a) how much; and (b) over what period.
(3) Does public good research and development need Government funding.
(4) Should public good research and development be funded from other sources; if so, what sources.
(5) What are the relevant criteria for determining whether to fund public good research.

(6) (a) What is Australia's ratio of research and development to gross domestic product (GDP); (b) how does this compare with other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries; (c) are the differences a concern to the Government; and (d) what measures does the Government propose to implement if Australia's ratio of research and development to GDP is significantly less than other OECD countries.
(7) Is there a link between science and technology research and development and future wealth, jobs and lifestyles.
(8) (a) Has the Government examined the long‐term costs associated with reduced funding to Australian research and development; and (b) what are these costs.
(9) Are the unfunded salary increases in the higher education sector a cut in funding for research and development in the higher education sector.
(10) Does Australian business and industry benefit from Australian research and development; if so, does the Government support this research and development.
(11) Does the Government have a science and technology policy; if so, what is it; if not, does the Government plan to develop such a policy and when will it be released.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cut in funding, $1 million in 1997‐98 and $9.2 million in 1998‐99, is less than 2% of funding for the Program over the current budget cycle. Payments to existing Cooperative Research Centres (CRCs) will not be affected.
(2) The CRC Program will be subject to an efficiency dividend. A 3% dividend will apply in 1998‐99 and a 1% dividend will apply each year thereafter.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes. Those undertaking public good research should be free to seek funds from all possible sources: from industry and from the wider community.
(5) No simple criteria can be outlined, but relevant factors to be considered would include:
. the perceived benefits of the research area for Australia's socio‐economic objectives (social, health, environmental, economic, defence, rural, cultural etc);
. the availability of satisfactory financial resources, facilities, and people with appropriate skills—all in relation to competing demands;
. the timescale that might be necessary for a satisfactory outcome;

. the degree of any spillover benefits that might be associated with the research (for example, in enhancing skills that might also be applied in other useful areas, that might lead to the identification of opportunities, or that might contribute to the solution of other problems); and

. the existence or absence of similar research being undertaken in other countries. Clearly, assessment of factors such as these might often require a wide range of consultation of expert and other opinion. It is for this reason that Australia has evolved advisory mechanisms and priority‐setting mechanisms of the kind described in Section 1 of the Science and Technology Budget Statement 1997‐98.
(6) (a) 1.62% is the most recent estimate (for the year 1994‐95).
(b) Recent comparisons are available in Table 7 of the Science and Technology Budget Statement 1997‐98.

(c) The differences are a matter of concern in that the Government believes Australia should always strive to increase its investment in R&D and not complacently accept the status quo however reassuring it may appear to some. Australia's public sector R&D is relatively well funded, while R&D expenditure in Australia's business sector is relatively low—see Tables 8 and 9 of the Science and Technology Budget Statement 1997‐98. Some improvement is apparent in data the Australian Bureau of Statistics has published subsequent to release of the Statement—Australia's business expenditure on R&D has now increased to 0.87% of GDP (in 1995‐96), so that Table 9 should be read with that in mind.

(d) Several mechanisms are in place—for example, the R&D tax concession, the R&D Start Program, and other AusIndustry activities—to encourage higher levels of R&D expenditure and greater innovation in the business sector.

(7) It is clear that most of today's wealth has emerged from past technological developments and that most of these are linked to advances in scientific understanding. Beyond that, the links between research and development, future wealth and jobs are highly complex and not yet well understood while lifestyles are partly a matter of choice that will depend upon levels of wealth and the nature of jobs. Around the world, a substantial number of studies is proceeding in relation to the implications of technological change, including some work being undertaken in relation to the OECD's Technology, Productivity and Jobs Project.

(8) No, because the Government is maintaining public sector R&D at levels which are relatively high in OECD terms, and at the same time has a number of measures in place to encourage more R&D in the business sector (see answer to question 6(d)).

(9) No. Higher education institutions have received separate indexation for salary increases on the basis of the Safety Net Adjustment (SNA) determined by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The SNA for 1997 provides indexation of 1.3 per cent. If institutions wish to provide

a salary increase over this amount, they are responsible for initiating their own reforms to achieve the productivity improvements necessary to fund an increase. The Government also adjusts the non‐salary component of funding to maintain its real value, based on the Treasury Measure of Underlying Inflation (TMUI). The TMUI is based on the consumer price index but removes elements affected by seasonal and policy factors. In 1997 the TMUI is equivalent to 2.9 per cent. It should be noted that the Government has also provided substantial increases in funding for research. Over 1996 levels, funds for targeted research programs rise by $22.4 million, $50 million and $40 million, representing increases of 5.8 per cent, 13.0 per cent and 10.4 per cent in 1997, 1998 and 1999 respectively. In total, $90 million has been provided for research infrastructure and $39.3 million for Collaborative Research Grants and Australian Postgraduate Awards.
(10) Yes and yes. See the answer to question 6(d).

(11) Yes. In very broad terms, the Government's science and technology policy is to maintain the strength of science and technology in Australia's public sector, strengthen innovation within the business sector, and improve linkages and synergies between public sector research and business innovation. A more extensive outline of the thrust of the Government's policy exists in the document Investing in Tomorrow, released prior to the 1996 election, while immediate policy priorities are provided in Section 5 of the Science and Technology Budget Statement 1997‐98.
